llm_translation: And what is the difference until here? The command of intent and reading, as it is written, "upon your heart ... and you shall speak of them." There, too, it is written, "upon your hearts ... to speak of them."

hebrew_text: הַהוּא מִבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְרַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּאָמַר: ״וְשַׂמְתֶּם אֶת דְּבָרַי אֵלֶּה״ — צְרִיכָה שֶׁתְּהֵא שִׂימָה כְּנֶגֶד הַלֵּב.
human_translation: That verse is necessary to derive Rabbi Yitzḥak, who said: “And you shall place these words” that the placement must be opposite the heart.
llm_translation: That one asked of Rav Yitzchak who said: "And you shall set these words" - it requires that it should be placed opposite the heart.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר, רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה אוֹמֵר: עַד כָּאן מִצְוַת קְרִיאָה, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ — מִצְוַת כַּוָּונָה. מַאי שְׁנָא מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ מִצְוַת כַּוָּונָה — מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב ״עַל לְבַבְכֶם״, הָכָא נָמֵי הָא כְּתִיב ״עַל לְבָבֶךָ״!
human_translation: The Master said, Rabbi Yoshiya says: To this point the mitzva of recitation; from here on the mitzva of intent. What is different, from here on, the mitzva of intent? because it is written upon your heart”? here too, it is written: “Upon your heart.”
llm_translation: Master said, Rabbi Yoshiyah says: Up to here is the mitzvah of reading the Megillah, from here on and onwards — the mitzvah of intention. What is different from here on and onwards, the mitzvah of intention? — Because it is written "upon your hearts," here it is also written "upon your heart"!

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר: עַד כָּאן, מִצְוַת קְרִיאָה וְכַוָּונָה, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ — כַּוָּונָה בְּלֹא קְרִיאָה.
human_translation: he is saying as follows: To this point, the mitzva of recitation and intent, from here on, intent without recitation.
llm_translation: So it was stated: Until here, the obligation of reading the Megillah and intention to fulfill the mitzvah is required; from here onward — intention without reading suffices.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא עַד כָּאן מִצְוַת קְרִיאָה וְכַוָּונָה — דִּכְתִיב ״עַל לְבָבֶךָ״ ״וְדִבַּרְתָּ בָּם״, הָתָם נָמֵי הָא כְּתִיב ״עַל לְבַבְכֶם … לְדַבֵּר בָּם״!
human_translation: And what is different, to this point, the mitzva of recitation and intent as it is written: Upon your heart And you shall speak of them? There, too, isn’t it written: upon your heart to speak of them?
llm_translation: And what is the difference until here the mitzvah of reading the Shema and intention - for it is written "upon your heart" "and you shall speak of them," there too it is written "upon your hearts ... to speak of them"!

hebrew_text: הַהוּא בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה כְּתִיב. וְהָכִי קָאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: אַגְמִירוּ בְּנַיְיכוּ תּוֹרָה, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלִיגְרְסוּ בְּהוּ.
human_translation: That Torah study And the Torah says the following: Teach your children Torah, that they will be well-versed in them.
llm_translation: That one in matters of Torah is written. And thus says the Merciful One: "Teach your children Torah, so that they may engage in it."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ ה׳ אֶחָד״ — עַד כָּאן צְרִיכָה כַּוָּונַת הַלֵּב, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. אָמַר רָבָא: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: The Sages taught “Hear, Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is One.” Intent of the heart is required to this point. the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rava said: the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "Hear, O Israel: the Lord our God, the Lord is one" - up to here requires intention of the heart, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rava said: The halakha is according to Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא סוֹמְכוֹס אוֹמֵר: כָּל הַמַּאֲרִיךְ בְּ״אֶחָד״, מַאֲרִיכִין לוֹ יָמָיו וּשְׁנוֹתָיו. אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב: וּבַדָּלֵית. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יַחֲטוֹף בַּחֵית.
human_translation: It was taught Sumakhos says: One who extends of One [ eḥad ] his days and years are extended. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: the dalet , Rav Ashi said: only so long as one does not ḥet hurriedly.
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita: Somchos says: Anyone who prolongs the recitation of "Echad" (Deuteronomy 6:4), his days and years are prolonged for him. Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: And in the separation. Rav Ashi said: And as long as he does not stumble in the reading.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה הֲוָה יָתֵיב קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי [חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא], חַזְיֵיהּ דַּהֲוָה מַאֲרֵיךְ טוּבָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כֵּיוָן דְּאַמְלֵיכְתֵּיהּ לְמַעְלָה וּלְמַטָּה וּלְאַרְבַּע רוּחוֹת הַשָּׁמַיִם — תּוּ לָא צְרִיכַתְּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya was seated before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba. He saw that he was greatly extending He said to him: Once you have crowned Him over above, below, and in the four corners of the heavens, you need not further.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya was sitting before Rabbi Chiya bar Abba, he saw that he was very troubled, he said to him: "Since you have crowned Him above and below and in the four winds of heaven - you have no need."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נָתָן בַּר מָר עוּקְבָא אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: ״עַל לְבָבֶךָ״ בַּעֲמִידָה. ״עַל לְבָבֶךָ״ סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ?! אֶלָּא אֵימָא עַד ״עַל לְבָבֶךָ״ בַּעֲמִידָה. מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ — לֹא. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר כָּל הַפָּרָשָׁה כּוּלָּהּ בַּעֲמִידָה.
human_translation: Rav Natan bar Mar Ukva said Rav Yehuda said: upon your heart, while standing Does it enter your mind upon your heart Rather, say: until upon your heart standing From here on, not Rabbi Yoḥanan said: the entire portion standing
llm_translation: Rav Natan bar Mar Ukva said in the name of Rav Yehuda: "On your heart" refers to standing. "On your heart" - is it possible that it is on your mind?! Rather, say until "on your heart" refers to standing. From here and onwards - no. And Rabbi Yochanan said the entire portion is with standing.

hebrew_text: וְאַזְדָּא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי אַחָא שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan and follows his reasoning Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Aḥa who said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda;
llm_translation: And it was established according to the reasoning of Rabbi Yochanan, as Rabba bar bar Chana said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Acha who said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ ה׳ אֶחָד״ זוֹ קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע שֶׁל רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַנָּשִׂיא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב לְרַבִּי חִיָּיא: לָא חֲזֵינָא לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי דִּמְקַבֵּל עֲלֵיהּ מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בַּר פַּחֲתֵי, בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁמַּעֲבִיר יָדָיו עַל פָּנָיו, מְקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם.
human_translation: The Sages taught “Hear, Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is One”; this is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s recitation of Shema . Rav said to Rabbi Ḥiyya: I did not see Rabbi accept the kingship of Heaven upon himself, said to him: Son of noblemen [ bar paḥtei when passed his hands over his face he accepted the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven upon himself,
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "Hear, O Israel: the Lord our God, the Lord is one" - this is the recitation of the Shema of Rabbi Yehuda the Prince. Rav said to Rabbi Chiya: I have not seen Rabbi, that he accepts upon himself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven. He said to him: Son of the governors, at the moment when he passes his hand over his face, he accepts upon himself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven.

hebrew_text: חוֹזֵר וְגוֹמְרָהּ, אוֹ אֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר וְגוֹמְרָהּ? בַּר קַפָּרָא אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר וְגוֹמְרָהּ. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בְּרַבִּי אוֹמֵר: חוֹזֵר וְגוֹמְרָהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ בַּר קַפָּרָא לְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בְּרַבִּי: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְדִידִי דְּאָמֵינָא ״אֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר וְגוֹמְרָהּ״, הַיְינוּ דִּמְהַדַּר רַבִּי אַשְּׁמַעְתָּא דְּאִית בַּהּ יְצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם. אֶלָּא לְדִידָךְ דְּאָמְרַתְּ חוֹזֵר וְגוֹמְרָהּ, לְמָה לֵיהּ לְאַהְדּוֹרֵי?
human_translation: Does he complete later or does he not complete it later? Bar Kappara says: He does not complete it later. Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi says: He completes it later. Bar Kappara said to Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Granted, according to my that I say that does not complete later, that is why Rabbi seek a topic that included the exodus from Egypt, But according to you, who says that he completes later, why, would seek
llm_translation: Returning and completing it, or not returning and completing it? Bar Kappara says: Not returning and completing it. Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi says: Returning and completing it. Bar Kappara said to Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi: According to my opinion that "he does not return and complete it," that means that Rabbi Ashma's teaching about the Exodus from Egypt is repeated. But according to your opinion that "he returns and completes it," why does he need to repeat it?

hebrew_text: כְּדֵי לְהַזְכִּיר יְצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם בִּזְמַנָּהּ.
human_translation: in order to mention the exodus from Egypt at its time,
llm_translation: In order to mention the exodus from Egypt at its proper time.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אִילָא בְּרֵיהּ דְרַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר מָרְתָּא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְרַב: אָמַר ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ ה׳ אֶחָד״ וְנֶאֱנַס בְּשֵׁינָה — יָצָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן לְדָרוּ עַבְדֵּיהּ: בִּפְסוּקָא קַמָּא — צַעֲרַן, טְפֵי — לָא תְּצַעֲרַן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב יוֹסֵף לְרַב יוֹסֵף בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבָּה: אֲבוּךְ הֵיכִי הֲוָה עָבֵיד? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בִּפְסוּקָא קַמָּא הֲוָה קָא מְצַעַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ, טְפֵי — לָא הֲוָה מְצַעַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ila, son of Rav Shmuel bar Marta, said in the name of Rav: One who recited “Hear, Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is One,” and was overcome by sleep, fulfilled Rav Naḥman said to his slave, Daru: bother me the first verse, do not bother me more Rav Yosef said to Rav Yosef, son of Rabba: What would your father do? said to him: He would exert himself the first verse, he would not exert himself more
llm_translation: Rabbi Ila, son of Rav Shmuel bar Marta, said in the name of Rav: He said, "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is One," and he fell asleep involuntarily - he fulfilled his obligation. Rav Nachman said to his servant: In the first sleep - our sleep is troubled, in the second - our sleep is not troubled. Rav Yosef said to Rav Yosef, son of Raba: How did your father used to conduct himself? He said to him: In the first sleep, he would trouble himself, in the second - he would not trouble himself.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: פְּרַקְדָּן, לֹא יִקְרָא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע. מִקְרָא הוּא דְּלָא לִיקְרֵי, הָא מִיגְנָא שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי? וְהָא רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי לָיֵיט אַמַּאן דְּגָנֵי אַפַּרְקִיד!
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: One who is lying [ perakdan ] on his back may not recite Shema , one may not recite but to lying is permissible? Didn’t Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi curse one who lying on his back?
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: A dancer should not recite the Shema. It is a verse that should not be read, but is it not proper for a shield? And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi would say: Where the grains are, there the locusts gather!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי, מִיגְנָא כִּי מַצְלֵי — שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי, מִקְרָא אַף עַל גַּב דְּמַצְלֵי נָמֵי — אָסוּר.
human_translation: If one while leaning it is permissible. to recite even though he is leaning, is prohibited.
llm_translation: They said, "From a shield when it is found - its value is good, a verse even though it is found - prohibited."

hebrew_text: וְהָא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מַצְלֵי וְקָרֵי!
human_translation: Wouldn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan lean and recite
llm_translation: And behold, Rabbi Yochanan finds and reads!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּבַעַל בָּשָׂר הֲוָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan is different, he was corpulent
llm_translation: The difference of Rabbi Yochanan is regarding one who has relations with an animal.

hebrew_text: בַּפְּרָקִים שׁוֹאֵל וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: At the paragraphs, one may greet
llm_translation: In the chapters, "Shoel, etc."

hebrew_text: מֵשִׁיב מֵחֲמַת מַאי? אִילֵּימָא מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד, הַשְׁתָּא מִשְׁאָל שָׁאֵיל, אַהְדּוֹרֵי מִבַּעְיָא?! אֶלָּא: שׁוֹאֵל — מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד, וּמֵשִׁיב שָׁלוֹם — לְכָל אָדָם. אֵימָא סֵיפָא: ״וּבָאֶמְצַע שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה, וּמֵשִׁיב״.
human_translation: respond due to what If you say due to respect; now that one may greet is it necessary one may respond Rather, One may greet due to respect and respond with a greeting to any person. say the latter clause In the middle one may greet due to fear and return
llm_translation: The one who responds out of anger, what is the reason? If you say it is due to honor, now when one asks a question, should he respond with anger?! Rather, one asks out of honor, and responds with peace to everyone. Perhaps the latter part: "And in the middle, one asks out of fear, and responds."

hebrew_text: מֵשִׁיב מֵחֲמַת מַאי? אִילֵּימָא מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה — הַשְׁתָּא מִשְׁאַל שָׁאֵיל, אַהְדּוֹרֵי מִבַּעְיָא? אֶלָּא — מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד. הַיְינוּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה! — דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בָּאֶמְצַע — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה וּמֵשִׁיב מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד, וּבַפְּרָקִים — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד וּמֵשִׁיב שָׁלוֹם לְכָל אָדָם?
human_translation: respond due to what If you say due to fear; now that one may greet is it necessary one may respond Rather, due to honor. that is Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned In the middle one may greet due to fear and respond due to respect. At the paragraphs, one may greet due to respect and respond with a greeting to any person.
llm_translation: One who responds out of anger, what is the reason? If you say it is out of fear - is it proper to ask a question and then return it? Rather - it is out of honor. This is like Rabbi Yehuda! - as we learned, Rabbi Yehuda says: In private - one asks out of fear and responds out of honor, but in public - one asks out of honor and responds peaceably to everyone.

hebrew_text: חַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: בַּפְּרָקִים — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁהוּא מֵשִׁיב. וּבָאֶמְצַע — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁהוּא מֵשִׁיב, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בָּאֶמְצַע — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה וּמֵשִׁיב מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד,
human_translation: is incomplete; and it teaches the following: At the paragraphs, one may greet due to respect, and, needless to say, he may respond In the middle one may greet due to fear, and, needless to say, he may respond statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: In the middle one may greet due to fear and respond due to respect.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Hasorei mechassera, vehachi katanei: Baparakhim — shoel mifnei hakavod, ve'ein tzarich loimar shehu meshiv. Uvaemtsa — shoel mifnei hayirah, ve'ein tzarich loimar shehu meshiv, divrei Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda omer: Baemtsa — shoel mifnei hayirah umeshiv mifnei hakavod." Translation: "The lacking are lacking, and thus it is taught: In the outskirts — one asks out of respect, needless to say that he responds. And in the middle — one asks out of fear, needless to say that he responds, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: In the middle — one asks out of fear and responds out of respect."

hebrew_text: וּבַפְּרָקִים — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד וּמֵשִׁיב שָׁלוֹם לְכׇל אָדָם.
human_translation: And at the paragraphs one may greet due to respect and respond with a greeting to any person.
llm_translation: In the chapters - one asks due to honor and responds peace to all people.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע וּפָגַע בּוֹ רַבּוֹ אוֹ גָּדוֹל הֵימֶנּוּ, בַּפְּרָקִים — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁהוּא מֵשִׁיב, וּבָאֶמְצַע — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר שֶׁהוּא מֵשִׁיב. דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בָּאֶמְצַע — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַיִּרְאָה וּמֵשִׁיב מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד, וּבַפְּרָקִים — שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד וּמֵשִׁיב שָׁלוֹם לְכׇל אָדָם.
human_translation: This was also taught One who is reciting Shema and happens upon his teacher or one who is greater than he, at the paragraphs he may greet him due to respect and, needless to say, he may respond. And in the middle he may greet due to fear and, needless to say, he may respond. statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: In the middle one may greet due to fear and respond due to respect. And in the paragraphs one may greet due to respect and respond with a greeting to any person.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Namai the Elder said: One who recites the Shema and his teacher or an elder meets him, in the open areas - he should interrupt due to respect, and needless to say that he responds. And in a narrow alley - he should interrupt due to fear, and needless to say that he responds. These are the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: In a narrow alley - he interrupts due to fear and responds due to respect, and in the open areas - he interrupts due to respect and responds with peace to everyone.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ אַחַי תַּנָּא דְבֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא מֵרַבִּי חִיָּיא: בְּהַלֵּל וּבַמְגִילָּה מַהוּ שֶׁיַּפְסִיק? אָמְרִינַן קַל וָחוֹמֶר: קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא — פּוֹסֵק, הַלֵּל דְּרַבָּנַן מִבַּעְיָא?! אוֹ דִלְמָא פַּרְסוֹמֵי נִיסָּא עֲדִיף.
human_translation: Aḥai, the tanna in the school of Rabbi Ḥiyya, raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ḥiyya: May one interrupt during hallel and the Megilla, we say that a fortiori inference; Shema , which is biblical one may interrupt all the more so, hallel , which is rabbinic one may interrupt? Or, perhaps, publicizing the miracle is more significant,
llm_translation: He asked of them, the brothers, a Tanna of the school of Rabbi Hiyya from Rabbi Hiyya's teachings: In Hillel and in Megillah, what is the law regarding interruption? We say: a fortiori argument: the recitation of the Shema, which is from the Torah, one must interrupt, does Hillel, which is of Rabbinic origin, require it?! Or perhaps the publicizing of the miracle is preferable.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: פּוֹסֵק, וְאֵין בְּכָךְ כְּלוּם. אָמַר רַבָּה: יָמִים שֶׁהַיָּחִיד גּוֹמֵר בָּהֶן אֶת הַהַלֵּל, בֵּין פֶּרֶק לְפֶרֶק פּוֹסֵק, בְּאֶמְצַע הַפֶּרֶק — אֵינוֹ פּוֹסֵק, וְיָמִים שֶׁאֵין הַיָּחִיד גּוֹמֵר בָּהֶן אֶת הַהַלֵּל — אֲפִילּוּ בְּאֶמְצַע הַפֶּרֶק פּוֹסֵק.
human_translation: said to him: One interrupts and it is of no concern. Rabba said: days when the individual completes hallel , may interrupt between one paragraph and another; one may not interrupt in the middle of the paragraph. days where the individual does not complete hallel , one may interrupt even in the middle of the paragraph.
llm_translation: He said to him: He concludes, and there is no disgrace in this. Rabba said: Days that an individual completes the Hallel in them, whether from section to section he concludes, in the middle of the section he does not conclude. And days that an individual does not complete the Hallel in them, even in the middle of the section he concludes.

hebrew_text: אִינִי?! וְהָא רַב בַּר שְׁבָא אִיקְּלַע לְגַבֵּיהּ דְּרָבִינָא, וְיָמִים שֶׁאֵין הַיָּחִיד גּוֹמֵר אֶת הַהַלֵּל הֲוָה, וְלָא פְּסֵיק לֵיהּ!
human_translation: It that so? Didn’t Rav bar Shaba once happen before Ravina the days when the individual does not complete hallel , did not interrupt
llm_translation: I?! And this, Rav bar Sheva encountered Rabina, and days when no individual completes the Hallel were, and did not cease from him!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי רַב בַּר שְׁבָא דְּלָא חֲשִׁיב עֲלֵיהּ דְּרָבִינָא.
human_translation: is different, as Rav bar Shaba was not considered important Ravina.
llm_translation: The opinion of Rav bar Sheva is not considered by Ravina.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ אַשְׁיָאן תַּנָּא דְבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי מֵרַבִּי אַמֵּי: הַשָּׁרוּי בְּתַעֲנִית מַהוּ שֶׁיִּטְעוֹם? אֲכִילָה וּשְׁתִיָּה קַבֵּיל עֲלֵיהּ — וְהָא לֵיכָּא. אוֹ דִילְמָא: הֲנָאָה קַבֵּיל עֲלֵיהּ — וְהָא אִיכָּא.
human_translation: Ashyan, the tanna in the school of Rabbi Ami, raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ami: May one who is fasting taste Did he accept upon himself eating and drinking, and that not Or, perhaps, he accepted upon himself pleasure and that is
llm_translation: He asked Ashyaan: It was taught in the school of Rabbi Ammi from Rabbi Ammi: If one is released on a fast, what should he taste? Eating and drinking he should accept upon himself - but there is no need. Or perhaps: Enjoyment he should accept upon himself - but there is something.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לֵיהּ: טוֹעֵם וְאֵין בְּכָךְ כְּלוּם. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: מַטְעֶמֶת אֵינָהּ טְעוּנָה בְּרָכָה, וְהַשָּׁרוּי בְּתַעֲנִית טוֹעֵם וְאֵין בְּכָךְ כְּלוּם.
human_translation: said to him: He tastes and it is of no concern. This was also taught Tasting does not require a blessing and one who is fasting taste and it is of no concern.
llm_translation: He said to him: Tasting and there is nothing in it. It was taught similarly: A taste that requires a blessing, and one who is fasting tastes and there is nothing in it.

hebrew_text: עַד כַּמָּה?
human_translation: How much
llm_translation: Until when?

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אַמֵּי וְרַבִּי אַסִּי טָעֲמִי עַד שִׁיעוּר רְבִיעֲתָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi they would taste up to a quarter
llm_translation: Rabbi Ammi and Rabbi Assi tasted until the measurement of a quarter-log.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: כָּל הַנּוֹתֵן שָׁלוֹם לַחֲבֵירוֹ קוֹדֶם שֶׁיִּתְפַּלֵּל כְּאִילּוּ עֲשָׂאוֹ בָּמָה. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״חִדְלוּ לָכֶם מִן הָאָדָם אֲשֶׁר נְשָׁמָה בְּאַפּוֹ כִּי בַמֶּה נֶחְשָׁב הוּא״. אַל תִּקְרֵי, ״בַּמֶּה״ אֶלָּא ״בָּמָה״.
human_translation: Rav said: Anyone who greets another before he prayed, it is as if he built an altar as it is stated: “Cease you from man, in whose nostrils there is breath, for how little is he to be accounted” And do not read bameh , how; but rather, bama , altar.
llm_translation: Rav said: Anyone who greets his fellow before praying, it is as if he made him an altar. As it is stated: "Cease from man, whose breath is in his nostrils, for in what is he to be esteemed." Do not read it as "in what," rather read it as "in an altar."

hebrew_text: וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: בַּמֶּה חֲשַׁבְתּוֹ לָזֶה וְלֹא לָאֱלוֹהַּ?
human_translation: And Shmuel said: How did you consider him and not God?
llm_translation: And Samuel said: "With what did you consider this and not the Almighty?"

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: בַּפְּרָקִים שׁוֹאֵל מִפְּנֵי הַכָּבוֹד וּמֵשִׁיב!
human_translation: Rav Sheshet raises an objection: in the paragraphs one may greet due to respect, and respond
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet raises an objection: In the chapters, one may ask out of respect and answer!

hebrew_text: תַּרְגְּמַהּ רַבִּי אַבָּא: בְּמַשְׁכִּים לְפִתְחוֹ.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba explained this: when one early to his door.
llm_translation: Translate: Rabbi Abba interpreted it: "In the morning at its opening."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָה אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: כָּל הָעוֹשֶׂה חֲפָצָיו קוֹדֶם שֶׁיִּתְפַּלֵּל — כְּאִלּוּ בָּנָה בָּמָה. אָמְרוּ לוֹ ״בָּמָה״ אָמְרַתְּ? אָמַר לְהוּ: לָא, ״אָסוּר״ קָא אָמֵינָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yona said Rabbi Zeira said: Anyone who tends to his own affairs before he prays, it is as though he built an altar. They said to Rabbi Yona: Did you say an altar? responded to them: No; I said prohibited.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yonah said, Rabbi Zeira said: Anyone who does his desires before praying - as if he built a high place. They said to him, "Did you say 'high place'?" He said to them: No, I meant 'forbidden.'

hebrew_text: (וְכִדְרַב אִידִי בַּר אָבִין דְּאָמַר) רַב אִידִי בַּר אָבִין אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אַשְׁיָאן: אָסוּר לוֹ לָאָדָם לַעֲשׂוֹת חֲפָצָיו קוֹדֶם שֶׁיִּתְפַּלֵּל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״צֶדֶק לְפָנָיו יְהַלֵּךְ וְיָשֵׂם לְדֶרֶךְ פְּעָמָיו״.
human_translation: And as Rav Idi bar Avin said Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashyan said: A person is prohibited to attend to his own affairs before he prays, as it is stated: “Righteousness shall go before Him, and shall make His footsteps on a path”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: (And as Rav Idi bar Avin said) Rav Idi bar Avin said Rav Yitzchak bar Ashyasan: It is forbidden for a person to do his desires before he prays, as it is stated: "He shall walk in righteousness before Him, and shall set his steps on the way."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב אִידִי בַּר אָבִין אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אַשְׁיָאן: כָּל הַמִּתְפַּלֵּל וְאַחַר כָּךְ יוֹצֵא לַדֶּרֶךְ, הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא עוֹשֶׂה לוֹ חֲפָצָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״צֶדֶק לְפָנָיו יְהַלֵּךְ וְיָשֵׂם לְדֶרֶךְ פְּעָמָיו״.
human_translation: Rav Idi bar Avin said Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashyan said: Anyone who prays and then sets out on his way, the Holy One, Blessed be He, tends to his affairs, as it is stated: “Righteousness shall go before Him, and shall make His footsteps on a path.”
llm_translation: And Rav Idi the son of Avin said in the name of Rav Yitzchak the son of Ashyaya: Anyone who prays and afterwards goes on his way, the Holy One, blessed be He, fulfills his desires for him, as it is stated: "Righteousness will go before Him and will make His footsteps a way."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָה אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: כָּל הַלָּן שִׁבְעַת יָמִים בְּלֹא חֲלוֹם נִקְרָא ״רַע״, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְשָׂבֵעַ יָלִין בַּל יִפָּקֶד רָע״, אַל תִּקְרֵי ״שָׂבֵעַ״ אֶלָּא ״שֶׁבַע״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yona said Rabbi Zeira said: One who goes seven nights without a dream, is called evil, as it is stated: “He who has it will abide satisfied [ save’a ], he will not be visited by evil” Do not read save’a , satisfied, but sheva , seven.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yonah said in the name of Rabbi Zeira: Anyone who sleeps seven days without a dream is called "evil," as it is stated: "And a full night's sleep without a dream will not be visited by evil." Do not read "full" but rather "seven."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא: הָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כָּל הַמַּשְׂבִּיעַ עַצְמוֹ מִדִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָה וְלָן — אֵין מְבַשְּׂרִין אוֹתוֹ בְּשׂוֹרוֹת רָעוֹת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְשָׂבֵעַ יָלִין בַּל יִפָּקֶד רָע״.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, said to him: Rabbi Ḥiyya said Rabbi Yoḥanan said as follows: Anyone who fills himself with matters of Torah and goes to sleep, they do not deliver evil tidings to him, as it is stated: “He who lies satisfied, will not be visited by evil.”
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Ahah son of Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba: So said Rabbi Hiyya in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Anyone who satisfies himself with the words of Torah and sleeps - they do not announce to him bad news, as it is said: "And he shall dwell satisfied, and not be visited with evil."

hebrew_text: אֵלּוּ הֵן בֵּין הַפְּרָקִים וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: These are between the paragraphs
llm_translation: These are the differences between the chapters, etc.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר בֵּין ״אֱלֹהֵיכֶם״ לֶ״אֱמֶת וְיַצִּיב״ לֹא יַפְסִיק. אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה — דִּכְתִיב:
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda who said that one may not interrupt between eloheikhem and emet veyatziv . Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s as it is written:
llm_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: The halakha is according to Rabbi Yehudah who said, "Between 'your God' and 'truth' and 'established,' one should not interrupt." Rabbi Abbahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: What is the reason for Rabbi Yehudah's opinion? Because it is written:

hebrew_text: ״וַה׳ אֱלֹהִים אֱמֶת״.
human_translation: “And the Lord, God, is True”
llm_translation: "And Hashem, God, is truth."

hebrew_text: חוֹזֵר וְאוֹמֵר ״אֱמֶת״, אוֹ אֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר וְאוֹמֵר ״אֱמֶת״?
human_translation: Does one repeat emet or does he not repeat emet ?
llm_translation: He returns and says "truth," or does he not return and say "truth"?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: חוֹזֵר וְאוֹמֵר ״אֱמֶת״. רַבָּה אָמַר: אֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר וְאוֹמֵר ״אֱמֶת״. הָהוּא דִּנְחֵית קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבָּה. שַׁמְעֵיהּ רַבָּה דְּאָמַר ״אֱמֶת״ ״אֱמֶת״ תְּרֵי זִימְנֵי. אֲמַר רַבָּה: כֹּל ״אֱמֶת״ ״אֱמֶת״ תַּפְסֵיהּ לְהַאי.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He repeats emet . Rabba said: He does not repeat emet . This person who descended before Rabba, Rabba heard that he said emet , emet twice. Rabba said: Every emet , emet has caught this one;
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: One repeats and says "truth." Rabbah said: One does not repeat and say "truth." That one who stood before Rabbah. Rabbah heard him saying "truth" "truth" two times. Rabbah said: Every "truth" "truth" he holds for this.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: כַּמָּה מְעַלְּיָא הָא שְׁמַעְתְּתָא, דְּכִי אֲתָא רַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר יְהוּדָה אֲמַר: אָמְרִי בְּמַעְרְבָא עַרְבִית — ״דַּבֵּר אֶל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם אֲנִי ה׳ אֱלֹהֵיכֶם אֱמֶת״.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: How excellent is this tradition as when Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda came In Eretz Yisrael, at the evening prayer they say “Speak to the children of Israel and say to them…I am the Lord, your God, True”
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: How excellent is this teaching that you have heard, for when Rav Shmuel bar Yehudah came, he said: They say in the West, in Aramaic: "Speak to the children of Israel and say to them: I am the Lord your God, truth."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: מַאי מְעַלְּיוּתָא? וְהָא אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר רַב: לֹא יַתְחִיל, וְאִם הִתְחִיל — גּוֹמֵר. וְכִי תֵּימָא ״וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם״ לָא הָוֵי הַתְחָלָה — וְהָאָמַר רַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר יִצְחָק אָמַר רַב: ״דַּבֵּר אֶל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״ לָא הָוֵי הַתְחָלָה, ״וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם״ הָוֵי הַתְחָלָה.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: What is excellent Didn’t Rav Kahana say Rav said: One not begin but if he does begin, he completes And if you say that: and say to them, is not considered the beginning didn’t Rav Shmuel bar Yitzḥak say Rav said: Speak to the children of Israel, is not a beginning and say to them, is a beginning.
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: What is the issue of beginning? But Rav Kahana said in the name of Rav: One should not begin, but if one did begin - one may finish. And if you might say, "And you shall say to them" is not considered a beginning - but Rav Shmuel bar Yitzchak said in the name of Rav: "Speak to the children of Israel" is not a beginning, but "And you shall say to them" is a beginning.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: קָסָבְרִי בְּמַעְרְבָא ״וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם״ נָמֵי לָא הָוְיָא הַתְחָלָה עַד דְּאָמַר ״וְעָשׂוּ לָהֶם צִיצִית״.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: In Eretz Yisrael, they hold and say to them, is not a beginning, until he said: And make for them ritual fringes.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: I maintain in the West that "and you shall say to them" is also not considered an initial statement until it says "and they shall make for themselves tzitzit."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הִלְכָּךְ, אֲנַן אַתְחוֹלֵי מַתְחֲלִינַן, דְּקָא מַתְחֲלִי בְּמַעְרְבָא, וְכֵיוָן דְּאַתְחֲלִינַן — מִגְמָר נָמֵי גָּמְרִינַן. דְּהָא אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר רַב לֹא יַתְחִיל, וְאִם הִתְחִיל גּוֹמֵר.
human_translation: Abaye said: Therefore, we begin since they begin in Eretz Yisrael. And once we begin we complete it as well, as Rav Kahana said Rav said: One not begin but if he does begin, he completes
llm_translation: Abaye said: Therefore, we are lenient to begin, for he begins in the west, and once we have begun - we complete. For Rav Kahana said in the name of Rav: One should not begin, but if he began, he should complete.

hebrew_text: חִיָּיא בַּר רַב אָמַר: אָמַר ״אֲנִי ה׳ אֱלֹהֵיכֶם״, צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר ״אֱמֶת״. לֹא אָמַר ״אֲנִי ה׳ אֱלֹהֵיכֶם״ — אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לוֹמַר ״אֱמֶת״.
human_translation: Ḥiyya bar Rav said: If one recited I am the Lord, your God, he must recite: True emet if he did not recite: I am the Lord, your God, he need not recite emet
llm_translation: Chiya bar Rav said: He said, "I am the Lord your God," needs to say "truth." If he did not say, "I am the Lord your God," he does not need to say "truth."

hebrew_text: וְהָא בָּעֵי לְאַדְכּוֹרֵי יְצִיאַת מִצְרַיִם!
human_translation: Isn’t he required to mention the exodus from Egypt
llm_translation: And this requires investigation: the exodus from Egypt!

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר הָכִי: ״מוֹדִים אֲנַחְנוּ לָךְ ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ שֶׁהוֹצֵאתָנוּ מֵאֶרֶץ מִצְרַיִם וּפְדִיתָנוּ מִבֵּית עֲבָדִים וְעָשִׂיתָ לָנוּ נִסִּים וּגְבוּרוֹת עַל הַיָּם וְשַׁרְנוּ לָךְ״.
human_translation: he said the following We give thanks to You, Lord, our God, Who took us out from Egypt and redeemed us from the house of bondage, and performed miracles and mighty deeds on our behalf on the sea, and we sang unto You,
llm_translation: So it was said: "Thus: 'We acknowledge to You, Hashem our God, that You have taken us out from the land of Egypt, and redeemed us from the house of bondage, and performed miracles and mighty deeds for us by the sea, and we sang to You.'"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה: לָמָּה קָדְמָה פָּרָשַׁת ״שְׁמַע״ וְכוּ׳.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa said: Why did the portion of Shema precede
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha: Why did the portion of "Shema" precede, etc.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי אוֹמֵר: בַּדִּין הוּא שֶׁיַּקְדִּים ״שְׁמַע״, לִ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״ — שֶׁזֶּה לִלְמוֹד, וְזֶה לְלַמֵּד. ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״ לְ״וַיֹּאמֶר״ — שֶׁזֶּה לִלְמוֹד, וְזֶה לַעֲשׂוֹת.
human_translation: It was taught Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: By right, Shema should precede VeHaya im Shamoa because to learn, while to teach. VeHaya im Shamoa VaYomer , to teach, while to perform.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai says: In judgment, one should first say "Shema" and then "Vehaya im shamo'a" - this is to learn and this is to teach. "Vehaya im shamo'a" to "Vayomer" - this is to learn and this is to do.

hebrew_text: אַטּוּ ״שְׁמַע״ — לִלְמוֹד אִית בֵּיהּ, לְלַמֵּד וְלַעֲשׂוֹת לֵית בֵּיהּ?! וְהָא כְּתִיב: ״וְשִׁנַּנְתָּם״, ״וּקְשַׁרְתָּם״, ״וּכְתַבְתָּם״! וְתוּ: ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״ — לְלַמֵּד הוּא דְּאִית בֵּיהּ, וְלַעֲשׂוֹת לֵית בֵּיהּ? וְהָא כְּתִיב: ״וּקְשַׁרְתֶּם״, ״וּכְתַבְתָּם״!
human_translation: Is that to say that Shema contains to learn it does not contain to teach and perform? Isn’t it written: “And you shall teach them “And you shall bind them “And write them Furthermore, does VeHaya im Shamoa contain to teach it does not contain to perform? Isn’t it written: “And you shall bind them
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Atu 'shema' — lilmod eit beih, lelamed velasot leit beih?! Veha k'tiv: 'veshinantam', 'uks hartam', 'uktavtam'! Ve'tu: 've'hayah im shamo'a' — lelamed hu deit beih, velasot leit beih? Veha k'tiv: 'uks hartem', 'uktavtam'!" English translation: "They said: 'Hear' — to learn from it, is there not in it to teach and to do?! But it is written: 'And you shall teach them diligently', 'and you shall bind them', 'and you shall write them'! And further: 'And it shall come to pass, if you shall hearken' — to teach that there is in it, and to do there is not? But it is written: 'and you shall bind them', 'and you shall write them'!"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָכִי קָאָמַר: בַּדִּין הוּא שֶׁתִּקְדַּם ״שְׁמַע״ לִ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״, שֶׁזֶּה לִלְמוֹד וּלְלַמֵּד וְלַעֲשׂוֹת. ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״ לְ״וַיֹּאמֶר״, שֶׁזֶּה יֵשׁ בָּהּ לְלַמֵּד וְלַעֲשׂוֹת, ״וַיֹּאמֶר״ אֵין בָּהּ אֶלָּא לַעֲשׂוֹת בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: Rather, said as follows: By right, Shema should precede VeHaya im Shamoa because to learn, to teach, and to perform, VeHaya im Shamoa should precede VaYomer because to teach and to perform, while only to perform.
llm_translation: Rather, thus he said: In the same manner, that "Hear" precedes "and it shall be if you hearken," for this is to learn and to teach and to do. "And it shall be if you hearken" to "and He said," for this contains in it to teach and to do, "and He said" only contains to do.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִדְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה! חֲדָא וְעוֹד קָאָמַר, חֲדָא: כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם תְּחִלָּה וְאַחַר כָּךְ יְקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מִצְוֹת, וְעוֹד — מִשּׁוּם דְּאִית בַּהּ הָנֵי מִילֵּי אַחְרָנְיָיתָא.
human_translation: Let him derive this, from Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa. He stated one and another. One so that one will first accept the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven upon himself and afterward the yoke of the mitzvot; and because contains these other elements
llm_translation: And they brought out from Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha! One and furthermore he said, one: in order that he should accept upon himself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven first, and afterwards he should accept upon himself the yoke of mitzvot, and furthermore — because there are in it those final matters.

hebrew_text: רַב מְשִׁי יְדֵיהּ, וּקְרָא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, וְאַנַּח תְּפִילִּין וְצַלִּי. וְהֵיכִי עָבֵיד הָכִי? וְהָתַנְיָא הַחוֹפֵר כּוּךְ לְמֵת בַּקֶּבֶר — פָּטוּר מִקְּרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמִן הַתְּפִלָּה וּמִן הַתְּפִילִּין וּמִכׇּל מִצְוֹת הָאֲמוּרוֹת בַּתּוֹרָה. הִגִּיעַ זְמַן קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע — עוֹלֶה וְנוֹטֵל יָדָיו, וּמַנִּיחַ תְּפִילִּין, וְקוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, וּמִתְפַּלֵּל.
human_translation: Rav washed his hands, recited Shema , donned phylacteries, and prayed How could he do that? Wasn’t it taught One who digs a grave for the dead is exempt from the recitation of Shema , from prayer, from phylacteries, and from all mitzvot mentioned in the Torah. the time for the recitation of Shema arrives, he emerges washes his hands, dons phylacteries, recites Shema , and prays.
llm_translation: Rav Meshi washed his hands, and he recited the Shema, and he put on tefillin and prayed. And how did he do this? As it was taught: One who is digging a grave for a deceased person is exempt from reciting the Shema, from prayer, from wearing tefillin, and from all the commandments stated in the Torah. When the time for reciting the Shema arrives, he raises his hands, puts on tefillin, recites the Shema, and prays.

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא, רֵישָׁא אָמַר פָּטוּר, וְסֵיפָא חַיָּיב?!
human_translation: This itself is difficult; The first clause stated is exempt and the latter clause he is obligated
llm_translation: This body is difficult, the beginning said exempt, and the end obligated?!

hebrew_text: הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא: סֵיפָא בִּתְרֵי, וְרֵישָׁא בְּחַד.
human_translation: That is not difficult. The latter clause of two The first clause of one
llm_translation: The matter is not difficult: the end is with two, and the beginning is with one.

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא לְרַב. רַב כְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קָרְחָה סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, דְּאָמַר עוֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם תְּחִלָּה וְאַחַר כָּךְ עוֹל מִצְוֹת.
human_translation: In any case, this contradicts Rav Rav holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa, who said the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven come first, followed by the yoke of the mitzvot.
llm_translation: From every place, a question to Rav. Rav, like Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha, holds it plausible, as he said, "The yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven first, and then the yoke of commandments."

hebrew_text: אֵימַר דַּאֲמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה — לְהַקְדִּים קְרִיאָה לִקְרִיאָה, קְרִיאָה לַעֲשִׂיָּה מִי שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ?!
human_translation: Say Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa said give precedence to recitation recitation did you hear him recitation over performance?
llm_translation: Saying that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha said - to prioritize reading over reading, reading over action, who will listen to him?!

hebrew_text: וְתוּ, מִי סָבַר לֵיהּ כְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה? וְהָאָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי: זִמְנִין סַגִּיאִין הֲוָה קָאֵימְנָא קַמֵּיהּ דְרַב, וּמַקְדֵּים וּמָשֵׁי יְדֵיהּ, וּמְבָרֵךְ, וּמַתְנֵי לַן פִּרְקִין, וּמַנַּח תְּפִילִּין, וַהֲדַר קָרֵי קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע. וְכִי תֵּימָא: בִּדְלָא מְטָא זְמַן קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, אִם כֵּן מַאי אַסְהַדְתֵּיהּ דְרַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי?
human_translation: And furthermore, does really hold in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa? But didn’t Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi say: Many times I stood before Rav, and he first washed his hands, recited a blessing, taught us our lesson, donned phylacteries, and then recited Shema . And if you say: the time for the recitation of Shema had not arrived then what is the testimony of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi?
llm_translation: And come, who thinks like Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha? And Rav Chiya bar Ashe said: Sometimes he was standing before Rav, and he would precede and extend his hands, and bless, and teach us chapters, and place tefillin, and then read the Shema. And if you say: If the time for reading the Shema had not yet arrived, what was the testimony of Rav Chiya bar Ashe?

hebrew_text: לְאַפּוֹקֵי מִמַּאן דְּאָמַר לַמִּשְׁנָה אֵין צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ, קָמַשְׁמַע לַן דְּאַף לְמִשְׁנָה נָמֵי צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ.
human_translation: to exclude the one who said that one need not recite the blessing for mishna. It teaches us that even for mishna, one must recite a blessing.
llm_translation: To go out from the one who said to the Mishnah, "It is not necessary to bless," it teaches us that even for the Mishnah one must bless.

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא לְרַב! שְׁלוּחָא הוּא דְּעַוֵּית.
human_translation: In any case is difficult for Rav. The messenger was at fault
llm_translation: From all places difficult for Rav! A question it is that you have asked.

hebrew_text: אָמַר עוּלָּא: כָּל הַקּוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע בְּלֹא תְּפִילִּין, כְּאִילּוּ מֵעִיד עֵדוּת שֶׁקֶר בְּעַצְמוֹ. אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כְּאִילּוּ הִקְרִיב עוֹלָה בְּלֹא מִנְחָה, וְזֶבַח בְּלֹא נְסָכִים.
human_translation: Ulla said: Anyone who recites Shema without phylacteries, it is as if he has borne false testimony against himself, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: it is as if he has offered a burnt-offering without a meal-offering or a peace-offering without libations.
llm_translation: Ula said: Anyone who recites the Shema without Tefillin, it is as though he bears false witness against himself. Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: It is as though he offered up a burnt offering without a meal offering, and a sacrifice without libations.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הָרוֹצֶה שֶׁיְּקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם שְׁלֵמָה
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who seeks to accept upon himself the complete yoke of the kingdom of Heaven
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said: One who wishes to accept upon himself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven in its entirety.

hebrew_text: יִפָּנֶה, וְיִטּוֹל יָדָיו, וְיַנִּיחַ תְּפִילִּין, וְיִקְרָא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, וְיִתְפַּלֵּל, וְזוֹ הִיא מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם שְׁלֵמָה.
human_translation: should relieve himself, wash his hands, don phylacteries, recite Shema , and pray, and that is the complete Kingdom of Heaven.
llm_translation: He should turn, and wash his hands, and place the tefillin, and recite the Shema, and pray, and this is the complete Kingdom of Heaven.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כָּל הַנִּפְנֶה, וְנוֹטֵל יָדָיו, וּמַנִּיחַ תְּפִילִּין, וְקוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, וּמִתְפַּלֵּל — מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִלּוּ בָּנָה מִזְבֵּחַ וְהִקְרִיב עָלָיו קׇרְבָּן, דִּכְתִיב: ״אֶרְחַץ בְּנִקָּיוֹן כַּפָּי וַאֲסוֹבְבָה אֶת מִזְבַּחֲךָ ה׳״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: לָא סָבַר לַהּ מָר כְּאִילּוּ טָבַל, דִּכְתִיב: ״אֶרְחַץ [בְּנִקָּיוֹן]״ — וְלָא כָּתַב ״אַרְחִיץ [כַּפָּי]״.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Anyone who relieves himself, washes his hands, dons phylacteries, recites Shema , and prays, the verse ascribes to him as if he built an altar and offered a sacrifice upon it, as it is written: “I will wash in purity my hands, and I will encircle the altar of the Lord” Rava said to him: Do you not maintain, Master, it is as if he immersed as it is written: “I will wash in purity,” and it is not written: “I will wash my hands”?
llm_translation: Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Anyone who turns, washes his hands, puts on tefillin, recites the Shema, and prays - the Scripture regards him as if he had built an altar and offered a sacrifice upon it, as it is written: "I will wash my hands in innocence, and I will go around Your altar, O Lord." Rava said to him: The Master does not hold this opinion as if he had immersed, as it is written: "I will wash in innocence" - and it does not say "I will wash my hands."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרָבָא: חֲזִי מָר הַאי צוּרְבָּא מֵרַבָּנָן דַּאֲתָא מִמַּעְרְבָא וְאָמַר: מִי שֶׁאֵין לוֹ מַיִם לִרְחוֹץ יָדָיו — מְקַנֵּחַ יָדָיו בְּעָפָר וּבִצְרוֹר וּבְקִסְמִית.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rava: My Master, look at this Torah scholar [ tzurva merabbanan ] who came from and said One who has no water with which to wash his hands, he wipes his hands with earth, a rock, or a sliver
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rava: "See, master, this elder scholar who came from the West and said: 'One who does not have water to wash his hands - he should rub his hands in dust, and in pebbles, and in charcoal.'"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שַׁפִּיר קָאָמַר, מִי כְּתִיב ״אֶרְחַץ בְּמַיִם״? ״בְּנִקָּיוֹן״ כְּתִיב — כֹּל מִידֵּי דִּמְנַקֵּי, דְּהָא רַב חִסְדָּא לָיֵיט אַמַּאן דִּמְהַדַּר אַמַּיָּא בְּעִידָּן צְלוֹתָא.
human_translation: replied to He spoke well, is it written: I will wash with water? In purity, is written as Rav Ḥisda curse one who to seek water at the time of prayer.
llm_translation: He said to him: "Well said! Who is it written 'I will wash with water'? It is written 'in cleanliness' — everything that is washed, for Rav Ḥisdah used to say, whoever is careful with washing his hands, for behold, the mother of the world (i.e., God) will bring water at the time of drought."

hebrew_text: וְהָנֵי מִילֵּי לִקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, אֲבָל לִתְפִלָּה מְהַדַּר. וְעַד כַּמָּה? — עַד פַּרְסָה. וְהָנֵי מִילֵּי לְקַמֵּיהּ, אֲבָל לַאֲחוֹרֵיהּ — אֲפִילּוּ מִיל אֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר. [וּמִינַּהּ] מִיל הוּא דְּאֵינוֹ חוֹזֵר, הָא פָּחוֹת מִמִּיל — חוֹזֵר.
human_translation: This applies only to the recitation of Shema , However, for prayer, one to seek And how As far as a parasang [ parsa ]. And this, applies only before him but behind him, he need not return even one mil . From this he need not return one mil , but one must return less than one mil .
llm_translation: These are the matters regarding the recitation of the Shema, but for prayer, one may return. And until when? — Until the heel. And these are the matters for standing before it, but behind it — even a word does not return. And from it, it is a word that does not return, this is less than a word — it returns.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע וְלֹא הִשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ — יָצָא. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: One who recites Shema and did not audible to his own ear, fulfilled Rabbi Yosei says: He did not fulfill
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who reads the Shema but does not hear it with his own ears - he has fulfilled his obligation. Rabbi Yosei says: He has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: קָרָא וְלֹא דִּקְדֵּק בְּאוֹתִיּוֹתֶיהָ, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: יָצָא. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: One who recited was not precise in its letters, Rabbi Yosei says: He fulfilled Rabbi Yehuda says: He did not fulfill
llm_translation: He read and did not scrutinize its letters, Rabbi Yosei says: he fulfilled his obligation. Rabbi Yehuda says: he did not fulfill his obligation.

hebrew_text: הַקּוֹרֵא לְמַפְרֵעַ — לֹא יָצָא. קָרָא וְטָעָה — יַחְזוֹר לִמְקוֹם שֶׁטָּעָה.
human_translation: One who recited out of order, he did not fulfill One who recited and erred, should return to the place that he erred.
llm_translation: The one who reads for the one who is negligent - he has not fulfilled his obligation. If he read and made a mistake - he should return to the place where he made the mistake.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי? מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב ״שְׁמַע״ — הַשְׁמַע לְאׇזְנְךָ מָה שֶׁאַתָּה מוֹצִיא מִפִּיךָ. וְתַנָּא קַמָּא סָבַר, ״שְׁמַע״ — בְּכָל לָשׁוֹן שֶׁאַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ.
human_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yosei’s Because it is written: Shema , Make your ears hear what your mouth utters. The first tanna , holds Shema , in any language that one hear
llm_translation: Talmudic text: What is the reason for Rabbi Yosei? Because it is written "Hear" - listen with your ears to what you are uttering from your mouth. And the first Tanna holds, "Hear" - in every language that you hear.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, תַּרְתֵּי שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yosei Derive two from
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yosei, two names heard from it.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: חֵרֵשׁ הַמְדַבֵּר וְאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ — לֹא יִתְרוֹם. וְאִם תָּרַם — תְּרוּמָתוֹ תְּרוּמָה.
human_translation: We learned there A deaf person who can speak but cannot hear may not separate teruma But if he did separate it, his teruma is teruma .
llm_translation: We learned there: A deaf-mute who speaks but does not hear - he shall not contribute. And if he contributed - his contribution is valid.

hebrew_text: מַאן תְּנָא חֵרֵשׁ הַמְדַבֵּר וְאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ דִּיעֲבַד — אִין, לְכַתְּחִלָּה — לָא?
human_translation: Who is tanna a deaf person who can speak but cannot hear it is after the fact, ab initio not
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that a deaf person who speaks but does not hear, what is the law? Initially, no?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא, דִּתְנַן: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת ״שְׁמַע״ וְלֹא הִשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ — יָצָא, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yosei, as we learned One who recites Shema and did not audible to his own ear, he fulfilled This is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: He did not fulfill
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: Rabbi Yosei, that is, as we learned: One who recites the "Shema" but did not hear it with his ear—has fulfilled his obligation, the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: He has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי לֹא יָצָא, אֶלָּא גַּבֵּי קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, אֲבָל תְּרוּמָה — מִשּׁוּם בְּרָכָה הוּא, וּבְרָכָה דְּרַבָּנַן וְלָא בִּבְרָכָה תַּלְיָא מִילְּתָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei only stated did not fulfill with regard to the recitation of Shema , biblical But teruma , due to the blessing recited over And the blessing is rabbinic law, is not contingent upon the blessing.
llm_translation: Until here did not say Rabbi Yosei did not go out, rather regarding the recitation of the Shema which is from the Torah, but regarding Terumah — it is due to a blessing, and a blessing of the Rabbis and not dependent on a blessing is the matter.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא, דִּילְמָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא? וְאָמַר גַּבֵּי קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע נָמֵי דִּיעֲבַד — אִין, לְכַתְּחִלָּה — לָא. תֵּדַע, דְּקָתָנֵי: ״הַקּוֹרֵא״, דִּיעֲבַד — אִין, לְכַתְּחִלָּה — לָא.
human_translation: And from where this is Rabbi Yosei? Perhaps it is Rabbi Yehuda, and he said that with regard to the recitation of Shema as well, he has after the fact, ab initio not Know it was taught One who recites after the fact. yes, ab initio , not
llm_translation: From where does the opinion of Rabbi Yosei come? Perhaps it is the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? And it was stated regarding the recitation of the Shema: Indeed, it is so after the fact, but ideally, no. Know that it is taught: "The one who reads," after the fact — yes, but ideally — no.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: הַאי דְּקָתָנֵי ״הַקּוֹרֵא״, לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחוֹ דְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי דְּאָמַר דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא. דְּאִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי יָצָא.
human_translation: they say: that taught One who recited, is to convey the far-reaching of Rabbi Yosei, who said that after the fact, he did not fulfill As, if it Rabbi Yehuda, even ab initio he fulfill
llm_translation: They said: This that is taught "the one who reads," to inform you the power of Rabbi Yosei who said that it should not be done. For if it were Rabbi Yehuda, even initially it would be permissible.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי אוֹקִימְתָּא — כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי? וְאֶלָּא הָא דְתַנְיָא: לֹא יְבָרֵךְ אָדָם בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן בְּלִבּוֹ, וְאִם בֵּירַךְ — יָצָא.
human_translation: How did you establish In accordance with Rabbi Yosei, But that which was taught One may not recite the Grace after Meals, in his heart, and if he recited he fulfilled
llm_translation: In what did you establish it - like Rabbi Yosei? But rather, this that it teaches: A person should not bless the grace after meals in his heart, and if he did bless - he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: מַנִּי? לָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי וְלָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. דְּאִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — הָא אָמַר, לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי יָצָא? אִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי, דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא!
human_translation: whose is this It is neither Rabbi Yosei nor Rabbi Yehuda. As if Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say ab initio he may fulfill if Rabbi Yosei; after the fact, he did not
llm_translation: Who is it? Not Rabbi Yosei and not Rabbi Yehuda. For if it were Rabbi Yehuda - did he not say, "Initially, did he not fulfill his obligation?" If it were Rabbi Yosei, he would not have acted thus!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מַאי, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. וְדִיעֲבַד — אִין, לְכַתְּחִלָּה — לָא.
human_translation: Rather, what Rabbi Yehuda after the fact, yes, ab initio , no,
llm_translation: Rather, what is it, Rabbi Yehuda. And if it happened - no, initially - no.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָא דְתָנֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי: חֵרֵשׁ הַמְדַבֵּר וְאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ — תּוֹרֵם לְכַתְּחִלָּה, מַנִּי?
human_translation: But that which was taught by Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi: A deaf who speaks but does not hear may, ab initio , separate teruma . whose is that
llm_translation: Rather, this that Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, teaches: A deaf person who speaks but does not hear - is he liable for the first offense, is it counted?

hebrew_text: לָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְלָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי. אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — הָא אָמַר דִּיעֲבַד אִין, לְכַתְּחִלָּה לָא. אִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי — הָא אָמַר דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא?
human_translation: it is neither Rabbi Yehuda nor Rabbi Yosei. As if Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say after the fact, yes, ab initio , no, if Rabbi Yosei, didn’t he say even after the fact he not
llm_translation: Not Rabbi Yehuda and not Rabbi Yosei. If Rabbi Yehuda - this one said it is forbidden, initially it is not. If Rabbi Yosei - this one said it is forbidden also?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי. וְלָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא — דִידֵיהּ, הָא — דְרַבֵּיהּ. דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע צָרִיךְ שֶׁיַּשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל ה׳ אֱלֹהֵינוּ ה׳ אֶחָד״. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי מֵאִיר: הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״אֲשֶׁר אָנֹכִי מְצַוְּךָ הַיּוֹם עַל לְבָבֶךָ״ — אַחַר כַּוָּנַת הַלֵּב הֵן הֵן הַדְּבָרִים.
human_translation: Rather, actually it is Rabbi Yehuda, and even ab initio , also And this is not difficult as this is his and that is his teacher’s As it was taught Rabbi Yehuda said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya: One who recites Shema must make it audible to his ears, as it is stated: “Hear, Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is One.” Rabbi Meir said to him: It says: “Which I command you this day, upon your heart;” the words follows the intention of the heart
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, Rabbi Yehuda, and even initially agree. And not difficult, this - his, this - his teacher. As we learned, Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah: One who recites the Shema must hear it with his own ear, as it is stated: "Hear, O Israel: the Lord our God, the Lord is one." Rabbi Meir said to him: Behold, it says, "which I command you today upon your heart" - after the intention of the heart, these are the words.

hebrew_text: הַשְׁתָּא דְּאָתֵית לְהָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה כְּרַבֵּיהּ סְבִירָא לֵיהּ. וְלָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר, הָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Now that you have arrived at this even you say Rabbi Yehuda holds in accordance with his teacher, it is, not difficult this Rabbi Meir, this Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: The Gemara: The case where you come to this, even if you say Rabbi Yehuda agrees with his colleague. And it is not difficult: this is Rabbi Meir, this is Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: הַכֹּל כְּשֵׁרִים לִקְרוֹת אֶת הַמְּגִילָּה, חוּץ מֵחֵרֵשׁ, שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר בְּקָטָן.
human_translation: We learned there All are fit to read the Megilla except a deaf person, an imbecile, and a minor. And Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit.
llm_translation: We learned there: All are fit to read the Megillah, except for a deaf person, an imbecile, and a minor. And Rabbi Yehudah deems a minor fit.

hebrew_text: מַאן תָּנָא חֵרֵשׁ דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא? אָמַר רַב מַתְנָה: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא. דִּתְנַן: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת ״שְׁמַע״ וְלֹא הִשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ — יָצָא, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: Who is the tanna after the fact, a deaf person not Rav Mattana said: It is Rabbi Yosei, as we learned One who recites Shema and did not audible to his own ear, fulfilled This is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: He did not fulfill
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that a deaf person can fulfill the obligation of hearing? Rav Matnah said: It is Rabbi Yosei. As we learned: One who recites the "Shema" but does not hear it with his ear - he has fulfilled his obligation, the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: He has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא וְדִיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא,
human_translation: From where Rabbi Yosei, and after the fact also not
llm_translation: From what is the statement of Rabbi Yosei? And it is established that it is not so.

hebrew_text: דִּילְמָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וּלְכַתְּחִלָּה הוּא דְּלָא, הָא דִיעֲבַד — שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Perhaps it is Rabbi Yehuda, and ab initio not after the fact is valid?
llm_translation: Perhaps it is Rabbi Yehuda, and initially it is not, what has happened - it is good, the price is right.

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דְּקָתָנֵי, חֵרֵשׁ דּוּמְיָא דְּשׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן. מָה שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא — אַף חֵרֵשׁ דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא.
human_translation: This could not enter your mind, as it was taught: a deaf-mute similar an imbecile and a minor. Just as an imbecile and a minor, even after the fact, not so too a deaf-mute, even after the fact, not
llm_translation: Your request is to translate the following Talmudic text into English word-for-word, maintaining the original style and format of Talmudic discourse. Here is the translation: Talmudic text: "לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דְּקָתָנֵי, חֵרֵשׁ דּוּמְיָא דְּשׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן. מָה שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא — אַף חֵרֵשׁ דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא." English translation: "Not as you think, for it was taught: A deaf-mute resembling a fool and a minor. Just as a fool and a minor do not acquire — so too, a deaf-mute does not acquire."

hebrew_text: וְדִילְמָא הָא כִּדְאִיתָא וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא.
human_translation: And perhaps this as it is and that as it is;
llm_translation: And perhaps this one as that one, and this one as that one.

hebrew_text: וּמִי מָצֵית לְאוֹקְמַהּ כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? וְהָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר בְּקָטָן, מִכְּלָל דְּרֵישָׁא לָאו רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא?!
human_translation: And can you establish in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda? But from what was taught in the latter clause And Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit by inference that the beginning is not Rabbi Yehuda?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And who found the law to be like Rabbi Yehudah? But it is taught in the latter clause: Rabbi Yehudah deems a minor fit to perform certain actions, does this not imply that the first clause is not in accordance with Rabbi Yehudah?!

hebrew_text: וְדִילְמָא כּוּלַּהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא וּתְרֵי גַוְונֵי קָטָן, וְחַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: הַכֹּל כְּשֵׁרִין לִקְרוֹת אֶת הַמְּגִילָּה, חוּץ מֵחֵרֵשׁ שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן. בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּקָטָן שֶׁלֹּא הִגִּיעַ לְחִנּוּךְ, אֲבָל קָטָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לְחִנּוּךְ — אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה כָּשֵׁר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, שֶׁרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר בְּקָטָן.
human_translation: And perhaps the entire is Rabbi Yehuda, two types of minors, and the mishna is incomplete and it teaches as follows: All are fit to read the Megilla except a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor. In what is this said? a minor who has not reached training However a minor who has reached training, even ab initio he is fit statement of Rabbi Yehuda, as Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit,
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And perhaps it is all according to Rabbi Yehuda, and two types of minors, and those lacking understanding, and thus it was taught: All are fit to read the Megillah, except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor. In what case are these words said? In the case of a minor who has not reached the age of education, but a minor who has reached the age of education — even initially is fit, the words of Rabbi Yehuda, for Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit."

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי אוֹקִימְתָּא, כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה — וְדִיעֲבַד אִין, לְכַתְּחִלָּה לָא? אֶלָּא הָא דְתָנֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי, חֵרֵשׁ הַמְדַבֵּר וְאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ — תּוֹרֵם לְכַתְּחִלָּה,
human_translation: with whose did you establish In accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, after the fact, yes, ab initio , no, However, that which was taught by Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi: A deaf who speaks but does not hear may, ab initio , separate teruma .
llm_translation: With what did you establish it, like Rabbi Yehuda — and it happened, not initially? Rather, this that Rabbi Yehuda teaches, the son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazzi, a deaf-mute who speaks but does not hear — contributes initially.

hebrew_text: מַנִּי? לָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְלָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי. אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דִּיעֲבַד אִין לְכַתְּחִילָּה לָא. אִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי, דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא!
human_translation: whose is this Neither Rabbi Yehuda nor Rabbi Yosei. As, if Rabbi Yehuda’s after the fact, yes, ab initio , no, if Rabbi Yosei’s even after the fact he not
llm_translation: Who is the authority? Not Rabbi Yehuda and not Rabbi Yosei. If it is Rabbi Yehuda, it is not effective initially. If it is Rabbi Yosei, it is also not effective!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מַאי, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — וַאֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי? אֶלָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: לֹא יְבָרֵךְ אָדָם בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן בְּלִבּוֹ, וְאִם בֵּירֵךְ — יָצָא, מַנִּי?
human_translation: But rather, what, Rabbi Yehuda, and also even ab initio ? However, that which was taught One may not recite the Grace after Meals in his heart, and if he recited he fulfilled whose
llm_translation: Rather, what is the meaning of "Rabbi Yehuda — and even initially it is agreeable?" Rather, this that was taught: A person should not bless the grace after meals in his heart, and if he did bless, has he fulfilled his obligation, who is the authority?

hebrew_text: לָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְלָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי. אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הָא אָמַר אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי, וְאִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי, הָא אָמַר אֲפִילּוּ דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא!
human_translation: neither Rabbi Yehuda nor Rabbi Yosei. if Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say ab initio he may fulfill if Rabbi Yosei, didn’t he say even after the fact he not
llm_translation: Not Rabbi Yehuda and not Rabbi Yosei. If Rabbi Yehuda, this one said even initially also, and if Rabbi Yosei, this one said even after the fact also not!

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וַאֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה נָמֵי. וְלָא קַשְׁיָא הָא — דִידֵיהּ, הָא — דְרַבֵּיהּ. דְּתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע צָרִיךְ שֶׁיַּשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי מֵאִיר: הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״אֲשֶׁר אָנֹכִי מְצַוְּךָ הַיּוֹם עַל לְבָבֶךָ״, אַחַר כַּוָּנַת הַלֵּב הֵן הֵן הַדְּבָרִים.
human_translation: Actually, is Rabbi Yehuda, also even ab initio . there is no difficulty, as this is his and that is his teacher’s As it was taught Rabbi Yehuda said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya: One who recites Shema must make it audible to his ears, as it is stated: “Hear, Israel, Rabbi Meir said to him: But it says: “Which I command you this day, upon your heart”; the words follows the intention of the heart
llm_translation: Forever Rabbi Yehudah it is, and even at the outset it is agreeable. And it is not difficult: his, that of his teacher. As it was taught, Rabbi Yehudah said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah: One who recites the Shema must hear it with his own ear, as it is stated: "Hear, O Israel." Rabbi Meir said to him: Behold, it says, "Which I command you today upon your heart," after the intention of the heart, these are the matters.

hebrew_text: הַשְׁתָּא דְּאָתֵית לְהָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה כְּרַבֵּיהּ סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, וְלָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הָא — רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: Now that you have arrived at this even you say Rabbi Yehuda holds in accordance with his teacher, it is, not difficult. this Rabbi Yehuda, this Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: The instance when it comes to this, even if you were to say Rabbi Yehuda is like his teacher, it is plausible to him, and not difficult, this - Rabbi Yehuda, this - Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר רַב שֵׁילָא: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה, וַהֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said Rav Sheila said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, and the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said in the name of Rav Sheilah: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehudah who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah, and the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehudah.

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא, דְּאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה, קָמַשְׁמַע לַן הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה.
human_translation: And are necessary, as had taught us the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, I would have said, even ab initio . he teaches us the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya;
llm_translation: And it is necessary, for if we were to hear the halakha according to Rabbi Yehuda, I would say even initially, it teaches us the halakha according to Rabbi Yehuda who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא צָרִיךְ וְאֵין לוֹ תַּקָּנָה. קָמַשְׁמַע לַן הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: And had taught us the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, I would have said must also he has no remedy he teaches us the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda;
llm_translation: And if we were to hear the halakha according to Rabbi Yehudah who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah, I would have thought that it is necessary and he has no remedy. It was taught to us that the halakha is according to Rabbi Yehudah.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מַחֲלוֹקֶת בִּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, אֲבָל בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל לֹא יָצָא, דִּכְתִיב: ״הַסְכֵּת וּשְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: dispute is in the recitation of Shema , but with regard to the rest of the mitzvot, everyone agrees that he does not fulfill as it is written: “Pay attention, and hear, Israel”
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: Dispute in the recitation of the Shema, but in other commandments — the words of everyone did not fulfill, as it is written: "Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is One."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: לֹא יְבָרֵךְ אָדָם בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן בְּלִבּוֹ, וְאִם בֵּירֵךְ — יָצָא. אֶלָּא אִי אִתְּמַר — הָכִי אִתְּמַר: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף מַחֲלוֹקֶת בִּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, דִּכְתִיב ״שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״, אֲבָל בִּשְׁאָר מִצְוֹת — דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל יָצָא.
human_translation: objects One may not recite the Grace after Meals in his heart, and if he recited he fulfilled Rather, If this was said, it was said as follows; Rav Yosef said: dispute is in the recitation of Shema , as it is written: “Hear, Israel.” But regarding the rest of the mitzvot, all agree that fulfills
llm_translation: Challenger: One should not bless the Grace after Meals in his heart, and if he did bless - he has fulfilled his obligation. Rather, if it was stated - it was stated thus: Rav Yosef said the dispute is regarding the recitation of the Shema, as it is written "Hear, O Israel," but regarding other commandments - it is the view of all that he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: וְהָכְתִיב ״הַסְכֵּת וּשְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״!
human_translation: Isn’t it written: “Pay attention, and hear, Israel”?
llm_translation: And it is written, "Hear, O Israel, and be silent!"

hebrew_text: הַהוּא בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה כְּתִיב.
human_translation: That is written with regard to matters of Torah;
llm_translation: That one, in matters of Torah, it is written.

hebrew_text: ״קָרָא וְלֹא דִּקְדֵּק בְּאוֹתִיּוֹתֶיהָ״.
human_translation: One who recited was not precise in its letters,
llm_translation: "He read and did not scrutinize its letters."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי טָבִי אָמַר רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה: הֲלָכָה כְּדִבְרֵי שְׁנֵיהֶם לְהָקֵל.
human_translation: Rabbi Tavi said Rabbi Yoshiya said: The halakha is in accordance with the statements in both leniently
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Tavi said Rabbi Yoshiyah: The halakha follows the words of both of them to be lenient.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי טָבִי אָמַר רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״שָׁלוֹשׁ הֵנָּה לֹא תִשְׂבַּעְנָה. שְׁאוֹל וְעֹצֶר רָחַם״. וְכִי מָה עִנְיַן שְׁאוֹל אֵצֶל רֶחֶם? אֶלָּא לוֹמַר לָךְ: מָה רֶחֶם מַכְנִיס וּמוֹצִיא, אַף שְׁאוֹל מַכְנִיס וּמוֹצִיא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Tavi said Rabbi Yoshiya said: What is written: “There are three that are never satisfied…the grave and the barren womb” What does a grave have to do with a womb? Rather, to tell you: Just as a womb takes in and gives forth, so too a grave takes in and gives forth
llm_translation: And Rabbi Tavi said in the name of Rabbi Yoshiyah: What is the meaning of what is written, "These three will not be satisfied, the grave, the barren womb"? And what connection does the grave have with the womb? Rather, to tell you: Just as the womb brings in and takes out, so too the grave brings in and takes out.

hebrew_text: וַהֲלֹא דְבָרִים קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה רֶחֶם שֶׁמַּכְנִיסִין בּוֹ בַּחֲשַׁאי, מוֹצִיאִין מִמֶּנּוּ בְּקוֹלֵי קוֹלוֹת. שְׁאוֹל שֶׁמַּכְנִיסִין בּוֹ בְּקוֹלֵי קוֹלוֹת, אֵינוֹ דִין שֶׁמּוֹצִיאִין מִמֶּנּוּ בְּקוֹלֵי קוֹלוֹת? מִכָּאן תְּשׁוּבָה לָאוֹמְרִים אֵין תְּחִיַּית הַמֵּתִים מִן הַתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: And is this not an a fortiori inference: Just as is placed into the womb in private, is removed from it with loud cries the grave into which is placed with loud cries is it not right that be removed with loud cries? From this a refutation to those who say that there is no Torah resurrection of the dead.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And are not these matters a fortiori: And just as the womb that one introduces into it a fetus, one extracts from it with loud voices. The grave that one introduces into it with loud voices, is it not logical that one should extract from it with loud voices? From here is a refutation to those who say that the resurrection of the dead is not from the Torah.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא: ״וּכְתַבְתָּם״ — הַכֹּל בִּכְתָב, אֲפִילּוּ צַוָּאוֹת.
human_translation: Rabbi Oshaya taught before Rava: “And you shall write them [ ukhtavtam ] Everything must be in writing even the commands
llm_translation: Rebbe Oshaia taught before Rava: "And you shall write" - everything in writing, even the commands.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לֵיהּ: דַּאֲמַר לָךְ מַנִּי — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר גַּבֵּי סוֹטָה — אָלוֹת כּוֹתֵב, צַוָּאוֹת אֵינוֹ כּוֹתֵב. וְהָתָם הוּא דִכְתִיב: ״וְכָתַב אֶת הָאָלוֹת הָאֵלֶּה״, אֲבָל הָכָא דִּכְתִיב: ״וּכְתַבְתָּם״ — אֲפִילּוּ צַוָּאוֹת נָמֵי.
human_translation: said to him: Who said to you? It was Rabbi Yehuda, said with regard to sota one writes curses, one does not write commands There, in it is written: “And shall write [ vekhatav ] these curses But here where it is written: “And you shall write them ukhtavtam even the commands also
llm_translation: He said to him: that which he said to you "mani" - it is Rabbi Yehuda, who said regarding the case of the Sotah - if he writes curses, he does not write commands. And there, where it is written: "And he shall write these curses," but here, where it is written: "And you shall write them" - even commands also.

hebrew_text: אַטּוּ טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב ״וְכָתַב״? טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיב ״אָלוֹת״. אָלוֹת אִין, צַוָּאוֹת — לָא.
human_translation: Is that to say Rabbi Yehuda’s reason is because says: “And shall write [ vekhatav ],” Rabbi Yehuda’s reason is because it is written curses, curses, yes, commands, no.
llm_translation: The taste of Rabbi Yehuda is because it is written "and he shall write"? The taste of Rabbi Yehuda is because it is written "curses." Curses - no, commands - yes.

hebrew_text: אִצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא נֵילַף ״כְּתִיבָה״ ״כְּתִיבָה״ מֵהָתָם: מָה הָתָם — אָלוֹת אִין, צַוָּאוֹת לָא. אַף הָכָא נָמֵי — צַוָּאוֹת לָא. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״וּכְתַבְתָּם״ — אֲפִילּוּ צַוָּאוֹת.
human_translation: was necessary, it might have entered your mind to say: Let us derive writing from writing there, just as there curses, yes, commands, no; so too here, commands, no. the Torah wrote: And you shall write them even the commands.
llm_translation: It is necessary, as your mind has raised, I say, to derive "writing" "writing" from there: Just as there — oaths are not, commandments are. So too here — commandments are not. The Merciful One wrote "and you shall write" — even commandments.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי רַב עוֹבַדְיָה קַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא: ״וְלִמַּדְתֶּם״ שֶׁיְּהֵא לִמּוּדְךָ תָּם — שֶׁיִּתֵּן רֶיוַח בֵּין הַדְּבָקִים.
human_translation: Rav Ovadya taught before Rava: “And you shall teach them [ velimadtem ] your teaching must be complete [ tam ] that one leave space between adjacent
llm_translation: It was taught: Rav Avadyah taught before Rava: "And you shall learn" - that your learning should be complete, to provide space between the joints.

hebrew_text: עָנֵי רָבָא בָּתְרֵיהּ: כְּגוֹן ״עַל לְבָבֶךָ״, ״עַל לְבַבְכֶם״, ״בְּכָל לְבָבְךָ״, ״בְּכָל לְבַבְכֶם״, ״עֵשֶׂב בְּשָׂדְךָ״, ״וַאֲבַדְתֶּם מְהֵרָה״, ״הַכָּנָף פְּתִיל״, ״אֶתְכֶם מֵאֶרֶץ״.
human_translation: Rava responded after him For example, al levavekha al levavkhem , bekhol levavekha , bekhol levavkhem , esev besadkha , va’avadtem mehera , hakanaf petil , etkhem me’eretz .
llm_translation: The poor of Rava said to him: such as "on your heart", "on your hearts", "with all your heart", "with all your hearts", "grass in your field", "and you will perish quickly", "the corner of a garment", "from the land".

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: כָּל הַקּוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּמְדַקְדֵּק בְּאוֹתִיּוֹתֶיהָ מְצַנְּנִין לוֹ גֵּיהִנָּם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בְּפָרֵשׂ שַׁדַּי מְלָכִים בָּהּ תַּשְׁלֵג בְּצַלְמוֹן״ — אַל תִּקְרֵי ״בְּפָרֵשׂ״ אֶלָּא ״בְּפָרֵשׁ״, אַל תִּקְרֵי ״בְּצַלְמוֹן״ אֶלָּא ״בְּצַלְמָוֶת״.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: Anyone who recites Shema and is punctilious in its letters, Gehenna is cooled for him, as it is stated: “When the Almighty scatters [ befares ] kings over it, it will snow in Tzalmon” Do not read befares , but befaresh , Do not read beTzalmon , but betzalmavet ,
llm_translation: Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Anyone who recites the Shema and is meticulous with its letters, Gehinnom cools for him, as it is stated: "When the Almighty scattered kings therein, it snowed in Tzalmon" (Psalms 68:15). Do not read it as "scattered" but as "scattered"; do not read it as "Tzalmon" but as "Tzalmavet."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: לָמָּה נִסְמְכוּ
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, also said: Why were
llm_translation: And Rabbi Hama, son of Rabbi Hanina, said: Why were they juxtaposed?

hebrew_text: אֹהָלִים לִנְחָלִים, דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּנְחָלִים נִטָּיוּ כְּגַנּוֹת עֲלֵי נָהָר כַּאֲהָלִים נָטַע וְגוֹ׳״ — לוֹמַר לְךָ: מָה נְחָלִים מַעֲלִין אֶת הָאָדָם מִטּוּמְאָה לְטׇהֳרָה — אַף אֹהָלִים מַעֲלִין אֶת הָאָדָם מִכַּף חוֹבָה לְכַף זְכוּת.
human_translation: tents juxtaposed to streams, as it is written: “As streams stretched forth, as gardens by the riverside; as aloes [ ahalim ] planted to tell you: Just as streams elevate a person from ritual impurity to purity so too tents elevate a person from the scale of guilt to the scale of merit.
llm_translation: Tents to streams, as it is written: "They spread out like streams, like gardens by the river, like aloes the Lord has planted, etc." — to tell you: just as streams elevate a person from impurity to purity, so too tents elevate a person from liability to merit.

hebrew_text: ״הַקּוֹרֵא לְמַפְרֵעַ לֹא יָצָא וְכוּ׳״.
human_translation: One who recited out of order did not fulfill
llm_translation: "The one who reads for the one who is negligent has not fulfilled his obligation, etc."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אַמֵּי וְרַבִּי אַסִּי הֲווֹ קָא קָטְרִין לֵיהּ גְּנָנָא לְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר. אֲמַר לְהוּ: אַדְּהָכִי וְהָכִי אֵיזִיל וְאֶשְׁמַע מִלְּתָא דְבֵי מִדְרְשָׁא, וְאֵיתֵי וְאֵימָא לְכוּ. אֲזַל אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ לְתַנָּא דְּקָתָנֵי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן:
human_translation: Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi were once tying a wedding canopy for Rabbi Elazar. He said to them: In the meantime, I will go and hear something in the study hall, and I will come and say it to you. He went and found the tanna who was reciting before Rabbi Yoḥanan:
llm_translation: Rabbi Ammi and Rabbi Assi were offering incense to Rabbi Elazar. He said to them: "Until now, I would go and hear a matter from the study hall, and then come and tell you." He went and found it written in the Mishnah before Rabbi Yochanan.

hebrew_text: קָרָא וְטָעָה וְאֵינוֹ יוֹדֵעַ לְהֵיכָן טָעָה, בְּאֶמְצַע הַפֶּרֶק — יַחְזוֹר לָרֹאשׁ. בֵּין פֶּרֶק לְפֶרֶק — יַחְזוֹר לְפֶרֶק רִאשׁוֹן. בֵּין כְּתִיבָה לִכְתִיבָה — יַחְזוֹר לִכְתִיבָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: One who recited and erred, and does not know where he erred; in the middle of a paragraph he must return to the beginning if between one paragraph and another he must return to the first paragraphs. if one erred between writing and writing, he must return to the first writing.
llm_translation: He read and erred and does not know where he erred, in the middle of the chapter - he should go back to the beginning. Between one chapter and another - he should go back to the first chapter. Between one writing and another - he should go back to the first writing.
