human_translation: Rabbi added to it elements And may he be very successful with all his possessions, and may his possessions and our possessions be successful and near the city, and may Satan control neither his deeds nor our deeds, and may no thought of sin, iniquity, or transgression stand before him or before us from now and for evermore.
llm_translation: Rabbi adds in it words: "And he shall succeed greatly in all his possessions, and his possessions and our possessions shall be successful and close to the city, and let no adversary have dominion neither over his actions nor over our actions, and let no thought of sin, transgression, or iniquity penetrate neither before him nor before us from now and forever."

hebrew_text: עַד הֵיכָן בִּרְכַּת הַזִּמּוּן.
human_translation: Until where the zimmun blessing
llm_translation: Until where is the blessing of the invitation.

hebrew_text: רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר עַד ״נְבָרֵךְ״, וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר, עַד ״הַזָּן״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says: until: Let us bless. Rav Sheshet says until Who feeds
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said until "nevarach," and Rav Sheshet said, until "hazan."

hebrew_text: נֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי, דְּתָנֵי חֲדָא: בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן שְׁנַיִם וּשְׁלֹשָׁה, וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ: שְׁלֹשָׁה וְאַרְבָּעָה. סַבְרוּהָ, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הִיא, מַאי לָאו בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי: מַאן דְּאָמַר שְׁתַּיִם וְשָׁלֹשׁ קָסָבַר עַד ״הַזָּן״. — וּמַאן דְּאָמַר שָׁלֹשׁ וְאַרְבַּע קָסָבַר עַד ״נְבָרֵךְ״.
human_translation: Let us say is parallel to a between the tanna’im . As one taught: Grace after Meals two and three and another taught: Grace after Meals three and four assumed that everyone Who is good and does good, is not by Torah law. What Is it not that they disagree about this: The one who said two and three holds that the zimmun blessing extends until Who feeds Who feeds And the one who said three and four holds until: Let us bless,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Neima k'tanaei, d'tanei chada: birkat ha'mazon shnayim u'shlosha, v'tan'ya idach: shlosha v'arba'a. Savruha, d'chulei olma 'ha'tov v'ha'metiv' la'av d'orayta hi, mai lav b'ha kamiflagi: man d'amr sh'tayim v'shalosh kasavar ad 'ha'zan'. — u'man d'amr shalosh v'arba kasavar ad 'ne'varech'." English translation: "It was stated by some Tannaim: the Grace after Meals is two and three, and it was taught by another: three and four. They thought, since 'the Good and the Beneficent' is not from the Torah, why do they differ in this matter: One who says two and three holds until 'He feeds'. — And one who says three and four holds until 'we will bless'."

hebrew_text: לָא, רַב נַחְמָן מְתָרֵץ לְטַעְמֵיהּ, וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת מְתָרֵץ לְטַעְמֵיהּ:
human_translation: No; Rav Naḥman explains in accordance with his reasoning and Rav Sheshet explains in accordance with his reasoning.
llm_translation: No, Rav Nachman resolves according to his reasoning, and Rav Sheshet resolves according to his reasoning.

hebrew_text: רַב נַחְמָן מְתָרֵץ לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא עַד ״נְבָרֵךְ״. מַאן דְּאָמַר שָׁלֹשׁ וְאַרְבַּע — שַׁפִּיר, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר שְׁתַּיִם וְשָׁלֹשׁ — אָמַר לָךְ הָכָא בְּבִרְכַּת פּוֹעֲלִים עָסְקִינַן, דְּאָמַר מָר, פּוֹתֵחַ בְּ״הַזָּן״ וְכוֹלֵל ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״ בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman explains in accordance with his reasoning; everyone until Let us bless. the one who said three and four well. And the one who said two and three said to you: Here we are dealing with the blessing recited by laborers, as the Master said he begins with Who feeds and includes Who builds Jerusalem, in the blessing of the land.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman resolves according to his reasoning, that the entire world is blessed until "we bless." One who says three and four - it is proper, and one who says two and three - here we are dealing with the blessing of actions, as the Master said, one begins with "Who nourishes" and concludes with "Who builds Jerusalem" in the blessing of the land.

hebrew_text: רַב שֵׁשֶׁת מְתָרֵץ לְטַעְמֵיהּ, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא עַד ״הַזָּן״. מַאן דְּאָמַר שְׁתַּיִם וְשָׁלֹשׁ — שַׁפִּיר, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר שָׁלֹשׁ וְאַרְבַּע קָסָבַר ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הִיא.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet explains in accordance with his reasoning; everyone until Who feeds the one who said two and three well; and the one who said three and four holds Who is good and does good, is by Torah law.
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet interprets according to his reasoning, for everyone until "ha-zan." One who says two and three - it is proper, and one who says three and four holds that "ha-tov ve-ha-meitiv" is from the Torah.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: תִּדַּע דְּ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא — שֶׁהֲרֵי פּוֹעֲלִים עוֹקְרִים אוֹתָהּ.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Know Who is good and does good, is not by Torah law, as laborers eliminate it.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: Know that "good and pleasing" is not from the Torah - for workers uproot it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר מָרְתָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב תִּדַּע דְּ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא שֶׁהֲרֵי פּוֹתֵחַ בָּהּ בְּ״בָרוּךְ״ וְאֵין חוֹתֵם בָּהּ בְּ״בָרוּךְ״, כִּדְתַנְיָא: כׇּל הַבְּרָכוֹת כּוּלָּן פּוֹתֵחַ בָּהֶן בְּ״בָרוּךְ״ וְחוֹתֵם בָּהֶן בְּ״בָרוּךְ״, חוּץ מִבִּרְכַּת הַפֵּירוֹת וּבִרְכַּת הַמִּצְווֹת, וּבְרָכָה הַסְּמוּכָה לַחֲבֶרְתָּהּ, וּבְרָכָה אַחֲרוֹנָה שֶׁבִּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, יֵשׁ מֵהֶן שֶׁפּוֹתֵחַ בָּהֶן בְּ״בָרוּךְ״ וְאֵין חוֹתֵם בְּ״בָרוּךְ״,
human_translation: Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta said in the name of Rav: Know Who is good and does good, is not by Torah law, begins with: Blessed, but does not conclude reciting it with: Blessed. as it was taught All blessings, begins them with: Blessed, and concludes them with: Blessed, except for blessings over fruit, blessings over mitzvot, a blessing that is juxtaposed to another and the final blessing after Shema . There are among these those that begins with: Blessed, but does not conclude reciting it with: Blessed;
llm_translation: Rav Yitzchak bar Shmuel bar Marta said in the name of Rav: Do you know that the phrase "He who is good and does good" is not from the Torah, for it begins with "Baruch" and does not end with "Baruch," as it was taught: All blessings, all of them, begin with "Baruch" and end with "Baruch," except for the blessing after eating fruits and the blessing after performing a mitzvah, and a blessing adjacent to its companion, and the final blessing in the Shema recitation. There are some of them that begin with "Baruch" and do not end with "Baruch."

hebrew_text: וְיֵשׁ מֵהֶן שֶׁחוֹתֵם בָּהֶן בְּ״בָרוּךְ״ וְאֵין פּוֹתֵחַ בְּ״בָרוּךְ״. וְ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ פּוֹתֵחַ בְּ״בָרוּךְ״ וְאֵין חוֹתֵם בְּ״בָרוּךְ״. מִכְּלָל דִּבְרָכָה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמָהּ הִיא.
human_translation: and there are among these that concludes with: Blessed, but does not begin with: Blessed. Who is good and does good, begins with: Blessed, but does not conclude with: Blessed. by inference that it is an independent blessing.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And there are some who conclude with "Baruch" and do not begin with "Baruch." And "He who is good and does good" begins with "Baruch" and does not conclude with "Baruch." From the principle of blessing, it is by itself.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: תִּדַּע דְּ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא — שֶׁהֲרֵי עוֹקְרִין אוֹתָהּ בְּבֵית הָאֵבֶל. כִּדְתַנְיָא: מָה הֵם אוֹמְרִים בְּבֵית הָאֵבֶל? — ״בָּרוּךְ הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: ״בָּרוּךְ דַּיַּין הָאֱמֶת״.
human_translation: And Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Know Who is good and does good, is not by Torah law, as it is eliminated in the house of the mourner, as it was taught What do they say in the house of the mourner? Blessed…Who is good and does good. Rabbi Akiva says: Blessed…the true Judge.
llm_translation: And Rav Nachman son of Yitzchak said: Know that "the Good and the Doer of Good" is not from the Torah - for they uproot it in the house of mourning. As it was taught: What do they say in the house of mourning? "Blessed is the Good and the Doer of Good." Rabbi Akiva says: "Blessed is the True Judge."

hebrew_text: ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ — אִין, ״דַּיַּין אֱמֶת״ — לָא?! אֶלָּא אֵימָא אַף ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״.
human_translation: Who is good and does good, yes, the true Judge, no, Rather, say: Who is good and does good, as well.
llm_translation: "The good and the one who does good" - is it not considered "a true judge"? Rather say also "the good and the one who does good."

hebrew_text: מָר זוּטְרָא אִיקְּלַע לְבֵי רַב אָשֵׁי, אִיתְּרַע בֵּיהּ מִלְּתָא, פְּתַח וּבָרֵיךְ: ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב, אֵל אֱמֶת, דַּיַּין אֱמֶת, שׁוֹפֵט בְּצֶדֶק, לוֹקֵחַ בַּמִּשְׁפָּט, וְשַׁלִּיט בְּעוֹלָמוֹ לַעֲשׂוֹת בּוֹ כִּרְצוֹנוֹ, כִּי כׇל דְּרָכָיו מִשְׁפָּט, שֶׁהַכֹּל שֶׁלּוֹ וַאֲנַחְנוּ עַמּוֹ וַעֲבָדָיו, וּבַכֹּל אֲנַחְנוּ חַיָּיבִים לְהוֹדוֹת לוֹ וּלְבָרְכוֹ, גּוֹדֵר פְּרָצוֹת בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל הוּא יִגְדּוֹר אֶת הַפִּרְצָה הַזֹּאת בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לְחַיִּים״.
human_translation: Mar Zutra happened to Rav Ashi’s home incident of befell began and recited: Who is good and does good, God of truth, the true Judge, Who judges with righteousness, takes away with justice, and is the ruler of His world to do in it as He wills, as all His ways are just, that all is His and we are His people and His servants, and in everything we are obligated to thank Him and bless Him, Who repairs the breaches in Israel, He will repair this breach in Israel for life.
llm_translation: Mar Zutra came to the house of Rav Ashi, a matter happened to him, he opened and blessed: "The good and the beneficent, God of truth, a true judge, judging with righteousness, taking with justice, and ruling in His world to do with it as He pleases, for all His ways are just, for everything is His, and we are His nation and His servants, and in everything we are obligated to thank and bless Him, He who fences breaches in Israel, may He fence this breach in Israel for life."

hebrew_text: לְהֵיכָן הוּא חוֹזֵר? רַב זְבִיד מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּאַבָּיֵי אָמַר: חוֹזֵר לָרֹאשׁ, וְרַבָּנַן אָמְרִי לַמָּקוֹם שֶׁפָּסַק, וְהִלְכְתָא לַמָּקוֹם שֶׁפָּסַק.
human_translation: To where does he return Rav Zevid in the name of Abaye said: He returns to the beginning And the Rabbis say: He returns to the place that he stopped. And the halakha is: He returns to the place that he stopped,
llm_translation: To where does it return? Rav Zevid in the name of Abbaye said: It returns to the head, and the Rabbis say: to the place where it stopped, and the halakha is in accordance with the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא לְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת: אַף עַל גַּב דְּרַבָּנַן קַשִּׁישֵׁי אַתּוּן, פָּרְסָאֵי בְּצׇרְכֵי סְעוּדָה בְּקִיאִי מִינַּיְיכוּ. בִּזְמַן שֶׁהֵן שְׁתֵּי מִטּוֹת, גָּדוֹל — מֵסֵב בָּרֹאשׁ, וְשֵׁנִי לוֹ — לְמַעְלָה הֵימֶנּוּ. וּבִזְמַן שֶׁהֵם שָׁלֹשׁ, גָּדוֹל — מֵסֵב בָּאֶמְצַע, שֵׁנִי לוֹ — לְמַעְלָה הֵימֶנּוּ, שְׁלִישִׁי לוֹ — לְמַטָּה הֵימֶנּוּ.
human_translation: The Exilarch said to Rav Sheshet: Although you are elderly Sages, the Persians are more expert than you with regard to the required meals. when there are two divans the greater reclines first and the second to him above him, When there are three the greatest reclines the one second to him above him, and the one third to him below
llm_translation: He said to him, the head of the exile to Rav Sheshet: Even though the sages are strict, you are experts in the matters of the meal, you are knowledgeable. When there are two beds, the elder one sits at the head, and the younger one next to him. And when there are three beds, the elder one sits in the middle, the younger one next to him, and the third one below him.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, וְכִי בָּעֵי אִישְׁתַּעוֹיֵי בַּהֲדֵיהּ, מְתָרֵיץ תָּרוֹצֵי וְיָתֵיב וּמִשְׁתַּעֵי בַּהֲדֵיהּ?! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שָׁאנֵי פָּרְסָאֵי, דְּמַחְוֵי לֵיהּ בְּמָחוֹג.
human_translation: said to If wishes to speak with he must straighten up and sit and speak to him. answered: The Persians are different, as they signal with gestures,
llm_translation: He said to him, "Does a man seek to engage in marital relations with his wife, that he runs and sits and engages in marital relations with her?!" He said to him: "The Persians are different, for they engage in marital relations in a circle."

hebrew_text: מַיִם רִאשׁוֹנִים מֵהֵיכָן מַתְחִילִין? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִן הַגָּדוֹל.
human_translation: the first waters. from where do they begin? said to him: They begin from the greatest.
llm_translation: First waters, from where do they originate? He said to him: From the great sea.

hebrew_text: יֵשֵׁב גָּדוֹל וְיִשְׁמוֹר יָדָיו עַד שֶׁנּוֹטְלִין כּוּלָּן? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לְאַלְתַּר מַיְיתוּ תַּכָּא קַמֵּיהּ.
human_translation: should the greatest sit and keep his hands clean everyone has washed said to him: They bring him his table [ takka ] immediately,
llm_translation: Sitting Gadol and guarding his hands until they all take? He said to him: "Immediately bring a cup before him."

hebrew_text: מַיִם אַחֲרוֹנִים מֵהֵיכָן מַתְחִילִין? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִן הַקָּטָן.
human_translation: the final waters. from where do they begin? said to him: They begin with the least significant
llm_translation: Last waters, from where do they begin? He said to him: From the small one.

hebrew_text: וְגָדוֹל יָתֵיב וְיָדָיו מְזוֹהָמוֹת עַד שֶׁנּוֹטְלִין כּוּלָּן? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא מְסַלְּקִי תַּכָּא מִקַּמֵּיהּ עַד דְּנִימְטֵי מַיָּא לְגַבֵּיהּ.
human_translation: should the greatest sit with dirty hands until everyone washes said to him: They do not remove the table from before him until the water reaches him;
llm_translation: The great one sat and his hands were soiled until they all left? He said to him: Do not remove the sack from before him until the water is poured on his feet.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: אֲנָא מַתְנִיתָא יָדַעְנָא, דְּתַנְיָא: כֵּיצַד סֵדֶר הֲסִבָּה? — בִּזְמַן שֶׁהֵן שְׁתֵּי מִטּוֹת — גָּדוֹל מֵסֵב בָּרֹאשׁ, וְשֵׁנִי לוֹ לְמַטָּה הֵימֶנּוּ. בִּזְמַן שֶׁהֵן שָׁלֹשׁ מִטּוֹת — גָּדוֹל מֵסֵב בָּרֹאשׁ, שֵׁנִי לוֹ לְמַעְלָה הֵימֶנּוּ, שְׁלִישִׁי לוֹ לְמַטָּה הֵימֶנּוּ. מַיִם הָרִאשׁוֹנִים מַתְחִילִין מִן הַגָּדוֹל. מַיִם אַחֲרוֹנִים, בִּזְמַן שֶׁהֵם חֲמִשָּׁה — מַתְחִילִין מִן הַגָּדוֹל, וּבִזְמַן שֶׁהֵם מֵאָה — מַתְחִילִין מִן הַקָּטָן עַד שֶׁמַּגִּיעִים אֵצֶל חֲמִישִׁי, וְחוֹזְרִין וּמַתְחִילִין מִן הַגָּדוֹל. וְלִמְקוֹם שֶׁמַּיִם אַחֲרוֹנִים חוֹזְרִין — לְשָׁם בְּרָכָה חוֹזֶרֶת.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said: I know a baraita , as it was taught: What is the order of reclining? When there are two divans the greater reclines first, and the second to him below him. When there are three divans, the greatest reclines first, the one second to him above him, and the one third to him below The first waters they begin with the greatest The final waters; when they are five they begin with the greatest When they are one hundred, they begin with the least significant until they reach the five greatest they return and begin with the greatest And to the place that the final waters return the blessing also reverts,
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: I have learned a Mishnah that teaches: How is the arrangement of the sprinkling? — When there are two beds — the first one is placed at the head, and the second one is below it. When there are three beds — the first one is placed at the head, the second one is above it, and the third one is below it. The first waters begin from the larger one. The latter waters, when they are five — begin from the larger one, and when they are a hundred — they begin from the smaller one until they reach the fifth, then they return and begin from the larger one. And when the latter waters return to their place — blessing returns there.

hebrew_text: מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַב, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַב: כׇּל הַנּוֹטֵל יָדָיו בָּאַחֲרוֹנָה תְּחִלָּה — הוּא מְזוּמָּן לִבְרָכָה.
human_translation: This supports Rav, as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said Rav said: Whoever washes his hands first at the end is designated to the blessing
llm_translation: Assisting him to Rav, for Rabbi Chiya bar Ashe said in the name of Rav: Anyone who washes his hands last first - he is prepared for a blessing.

hebrew_text: רַב וְרַבִּי חִיָּיא הֲווֹ יָתְבִי בִּסְעוֹדְתָּא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי לְרַב: קוּם, מְשִׁי יְדָךְ. חַזְיֵיהּ דְּקָא מְרַתֵּת. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בַּר פַּחֲתֵי, ״עַיֵּין בְּבִרְכַּת מְזוֹנָא״ קָאָמַר לָךְ.
human_translation: Rav and Rabbi Ḥiyya were seated at a meal before Rabbi Rabbi said to Rav: Stand, wash your hands. saw that was trembling said to him: Son of noblemen, he is saying to you to review Grace after Meals,
llm_translation: Rav and Rabbi Chiya were sitting at a meal before Rabbi. Rabbi said to Rav: "Get up, wash your hands." He saw that he was delaying. He said to him: "Son of officials, 'look at the blessing of the food' I am saying to you."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין מְכַבְּדִין לֹא בִּדְרָכִים וְלֹא בִּגְשָׁרִים,
human_translation: The Sages taught: one shows deference neither on roads nor on bridges,
llm_translation: The sages taught: One does not show respect neither on roads nor on bridges.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא בְּיָדַיִם מְזוֹהָמוֹת.
human_translation: nor with dirty hands,
llm_translation: And not with hands defiled.

hebrew_text: רָבִין וְאַבָּיֵי הֲווֹ קָא אָזְלִי בְּאוֹרְחָא, קַדְמֵיהּ חֲמָרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּין לִדְאַבָּיֵי וְלָא אֲמַר לֵיהּ ״נֵיזִיל מָר״. אֲמַר: מִדִּסְלִיק הַאי מֵרַבָּנַן מִמַּעְרְבָא, גַּס לֵיהּ דַּעְתֵּיהּ. כִּי מְטָא לְפִתְחָא דְבֵי כְנִישְׁתָּא אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נֵיעַל מָר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְעַד הַשְׁתָּא לָאו מָר אֲנָא? אֲמַר לֵיהּ, הָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֵין מְכַבְּדִין אֶלָּא בְּפֶתַח שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ מְזוּזָה.
human_translation: Ravin and Abaye were traveling along the road Ravin’s donkey preceded Abaye’s and did not say Let the Master go said since this one of the Sages, ascended from the West, he has become arrogant. When they reached the door of the synagogue, said to Let the Master enter said to him: Until now was I not Master? said to him: Rabbi Yoḥanan said the following: One only defers at a doorway that has a mezuza ,
llm_translation: Rav and Abaye were walking on the road, Rav's donkey was walking in front of Abaye, and he did not say to him, "Move, sir." He said: Since this Rabbi is removing himself from the west, let his mind be at ease. When they arrived at the entrance of the synagogue, he said to him: "Enter, sir." He said to him: "And until now, have I not been a sir?" He said to him, so said Rabbi Yochanan: We only show respect at a doorway that has a mezuzah.

hebrew_text: דְּאִית בַּהּ מְזוּזָה — אִין, דְּלֵית בַּהּ מְזוּזָה — לָא, אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, בֵּית הַכְּנֶסֶת וּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, דְּלֵית בְּהוּ מְזוּזָה, הָכִי נָמֵי דְּאֵין מְכַבְּדִין? אֶלָּא אֵימָא: בְּפֶתַח הָרָאוּי לִמְזוּזָה.
human_translation: that has a mezuza , yes, that does not have a mezuza , no, If so, a synagogue or study hall that has no mezuza , too, does one not defer Rather, say at a doorway of a mezuza ,
llm_translation: If it has a mezuzah - yes, if it does not have a mezuzah - no. Rather, from now on, a synagogue and a study hall that do not have a mezuzah, is this not the same as not showing respect? Instead, say: at the entrance that is fitting for a mezuzah.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר שִׁילַת מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב: אֵין הַמְסוּבִּין רַשָּׁאִין לֶאֱכוֹל כְּלוּם עַד שֶׁיִּטְעוֹם הַבּוֹצֵעַ. יָתֵיב רַב סָפְרָא וְקָאָמַר: ״לִטְעוֹם״ אִיתְּמַר.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda, son of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, said in the name of Rav: Those reclining may not eat anything until the one breaking bread has tasted Rav Safra sat and said: taste, was stated
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah, son of Rav Shmuel, son of Shilat, said in the name of Rav: The guests are not permitted to eat anything until the host tastes it. Rav Safra was sitting and saying: "To taste" is stated.

hebrew_text: לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? שֶׁחַיָּיב אָדָם לוֹמַר בִּלְשׁוֹן רַבּוֹ.
human_translation: What difference does make one must say in the language by his teacher
llm_translation: For what does it come out? That a person is obligated to speak in the language of his teacher.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שְׁנַיִם מַמְתִּינִין זֶה לָזֶה בַּקְּעָרָה, שְׁלֹשָׁה — אֵין מַמְתִּינִין. הַבּוֹצֵעַ הוּא פּוֹשֵׁט יָדוֹ תְּחִלָּה, וְאִם בָּא לַחֲלוֹק כָּבוֹד לְרַבּוֹ אוֹ לְמִי שֶׁגָּדוֹל הֵימֶנּוּ — הָרְשׁוּת בְּיָדוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Two people from a single dish must wait for each other, three, they need not wait the one who breaks bread extends his hand first, if he wishes to defer to his teacher or to one who is greater he has permission
llm_translation: The sages taught: Two wait for each other in the bowl, three - do not wait. The one who takes out his hand first, and if he intends to give honor to his teacher or to one greater than himself - the permission is in his hand.

hebrew_text: רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה הֲוָה עָסֵיק לֵיהּ לִבְרֵיהּ בֵּי רַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר רַב קַטִּינָא, קָדֵים וְיָתֵיב וְקָמַתְנֵי לֵיהּ לִבְרֵיהּ: אֵין הַבּוֹצֵעַ רַשַּׁאי לִבְצוֹעַ עַד שֶׁיִּכְלֶה ״אָמֵן״ מִפִּי הָעוֹנִים. רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר מִפִּי רוֹב הָעוֹנִים.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana engaged in for his son’s in the house of Rav Shmuel bar Rav Ketina. He arrived early and sat and taught his son The one who breaks bread may not break until amen has ended from the mouths of those responding. Rav Ḥisda said: from the mouths of the majority of those responding.
llm_translation: Rabbah bar bar Ḥanah was engaged with his son in the study hall of the house of Rav Shemu'el bar Rav Qatina. He would stand, sit, and repeat to his son: "The one who recites the blessing is not permitted to conclude until he hears 'Amen' from the mouths of the responders." Rav Ḥisdah said: "From the mouths of the majority of the responders."

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: מַאי שְׁנָא רוּבָּא — דְּאַכַּתִּי לָא כָּלְיָא בְּרָכָה, מִיעוּטָא נָמֵי לָא כָּלְיָא בְּרָכָה?
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama said to him: What is different the majority That the blessing has not yet concluded. the minority as well, the blessing has not yet concluded.
llm_translation: Ramei bar Ḥama said to him: What is the difference between the majority and the minority? — Because I have not yet completed the blessing, is it not the case that even a small amount is not yet completed in the blessing?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹמֵר, כׇּל הָעוֹנֶה ״אָמֵן״ יוֹתֵר מִדַּאי — אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא טוֹעֶה.
human_translation: said to him: Because I say anyone who answers amen excessive is merely mistaken.
llm_translation: He said to him: "I say, whoever answers 'Amen' more than necessary - he is only mistaken."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין עוֹנִין לֹא ״אָמֵן״ חֲטוּפָה, וְלֹא ״אָמֵן״ קְטוּפָה, וְלֹא ״אָמֵן״ יְתוֹמָה, וְלֹא יִזְרוֹק בְּרָכָה מִפִּיו.
human_translation: the Sages taught: One should not respond an abbreviated [ ḥatufa ] amen, and a truncated [ ketufa ] amen, and an orphaned [ yetoma ] amen, one should not discharge a blessing from his mouth.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One does not respond with "Amen" hastily, nor with "Amen" in a clipped manner, nor with "Amen" in the case of an orphan, and one should not cast a blessing from his mouth.

hebrew_text: בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: כׇּל הָעוֹנֶה ״אָמֵן״ יְתוֹמָה — יִהְיוּ בָּנָיו יְתוֹמִים, חֲטוּפָה — יִתְחַטְּפוּ יָמָיו, קְטוּפָה — יִתְקַטְּפוּ יָמָיו. וְכׇל הַמַּאֲרִיךְ בְּ״אָמֵן״ — מַאֲרִיכִין לוֹ יָמָיו וּשְׁנוֹתָיו.
human_translation: Ben Azzai says: Anyone who recites an orphaned amen, his children will be orphaned; abbreviated his days will be abbreviated a truncated his days will be truncated. One who extends his amen, they will extend his days and years for him.
llm_translation: Ben Azzai says: Anyone who responds "Amen" with regard to an orphan - his children will become orphans, a stolen item - his days will be stolen, a cut-off item - his days will be cut off. And anyone who prolongs the saying of "Amen" - they prolong his days and years.

hebrew_text: רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל הֲווֹ יָתְבִי בִּסְעוֹדְתָּא. אֲתָא רַב שִׁימִי בַּר חִיָּיא, הֲוָה קָמְסַרְהֵב וְאָכֵיל. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב: מָה דַעְתָּךְ — לְאִיצְטְרוֹפֵי בַּהֲדַן, אֲנַן אֲכִילְנָא לַן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ שְׁמוּאֵל: אִלּוּ מַיְיתוּ לִי אַרְדִּילַיָּא וְגוֹזָלַיָּא לְאַבָּא, מִי לָא אָכְלִינַן?
human_translation: Rav and Shmuel were sitting at a meal Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya arrived and was hurrying and eating. Rav said to him: What is your thinking? to join together with us We have already eaten our Shmuel said to if they brought me truffles or a young pigeon for Abba, wouldn’t we eat it?
llm_translation: Rav and Shmuel were sitting at a meal. Rav Shimi bar Chiya came, riding on a donkey, and eating. Rav said to him: What is your opinion - to join us at the meal, or should we eat by ourselves? Shmuel said to him: If they would bring me my saddlebags and my wallet to my father, would we not eat?

hebrew_text: תַּלְמִידֵי דְּרַב הֲווֹ יָתְבִי בִּסְעוֹדְתָּא. עָל רַב אַחָא. אָמְרִי: אֲתָא גַּבְרָא רַבָּא דִּמְבָרֵךְ לַן. אָמַר לְהוּ: מִי סָבְרִיתוּ דְּגָדוֹל מְבָרֵךְ? עִיקָּר שֶׁבַּסְּעוּדָה מְבָרֵךְ. וְהִלְכְתָא גָּדוֹל מְבָרֵךְ, אַף עַל גַּב דַּאֲתָא לְבַסּוֹף.
human_translation: Rav’s students were seated at a meal Rav Aḥa entered. said: A great man has come who can recite the blessing on our behalf. said to them: Do you think that the greatest recites the blessing? the main of the meal recites the blessing. The halakha is that the greatest recites the blessing, even if he arrived at the end
llm_translation: The disciples of Rav were sitting at a meal. On Rav Ahah. They said: A great man who blesses has come to us. He said to them: Do you think that a great man blesses? The main person at the meal blesses. And the halacha is that the greatest person blesses, even though he came at the end.

hebrew_text: אָכַל דְּמַאי וְכוּ׳: הָא לָא חֲזֵי לֵיהּ! כֵּיוָן דְּאִי בָּעֵי מַפְקַר לְהוּ לְנִכְסֵיהּ וְהָוֵי עָנִי, וַחֲזֵי לֵיהּ, דִּתְנַן: מַאֲכִילִין אֶת הָעֲנִיִּים דְּמַאי, וְאֶת הָאַכְסַנְיָא דְּמַאי. וְאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: תָּנָא, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: אֵין מַאֲכִילִין אֶת הָעֲנִיִּים וְאֶת הָאַכְסַנְיָא דְּמַאי.
human_translation: one ate doubtfully tithed produce [ demai ], But is not fit for his because, if he wants, he could declare all of his property ownerless [ hefker ] and he would be a pauper, fit for his As we learned One may feed the impoverished demai and soldiers [ akhsania ], demai . And Rav Huna said: It was taught Beit Shammai say: One may not feed the impoverished and soldiers demai .
llm_translation: Talmudic text: He ate Demai, etc.: This does not appear to him! Since if he wants to declare his property ownerless and become poor, and it appears to him, for we learned: They feed the poor with Demai, and the guests with Demai. And Rav Huna said: It was taught, Beit Shammai say: They do not feed the poor and the guests with Demai.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֵׂר רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁנִּטְּלָה תְּרוּמָתוֹ: פְּשִׁיטָא? לָא צְרִיכָא אֶלָּא שֶׁהִקְדִּימוֹ בַּשִּׁבֳּלִים, וְהִפְרִישׁ מִמֶּנּוּ תְּרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר, וְלֹא הִפְרִישׁ מִמֶּנּוּ תְּרוּמָה גְּדוֹלָה, וְכִדְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מַעֲשֵׂר רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁהִקְדִּימוֹ בַּשִּׁבֳּלִים — פָּטוּר מִתְּרוּמָה גְּדוֹלָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַהֲרֵמֹתֶם מִמֶּנּוּ תְּרוּמַת ה׳ מַעֲשֵׂר מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר״ — מַעֲשֵׂר מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר אָמַרְתִּי לְךָ, וְלֹא תְּרוּמָה גְּדוֹלָה וּתְרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: first tithe from which its teruma was taken, It is obvious It was only necessary in preceded on the stalks, and he separated the teruma of the tithes did not separate the teruma gedola . And in accordance with Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu said Reish Lakish said: First tithe preceded on the stalks is exempt from teruma gedola , as it is stated: “And you shall set apart from it a gift for the Lord, even a tenth part of the tithe” teaches a tenth part of the tithe, and not teruma gedola and the teruma of the tithe.
llm_translation: First tithe that its terumah was taken: obvious? No need except that they prioritized it in the sheaves, and separated from it the terumah of the tithe, and did not separate from it a large terumah, as Rabbi Abbahu said. For Rabbi Abbahu said Reish Lakish said: First tithe that they prioritized in the sheaves - exempt from a large terumah, as it says: "And you shall lift from it the Lord's terumah, a tithe from the tithe" - I said a tithe from the tithe to you, not a large terumah and terumah of the tithe from the tithe.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ הִקְדִּימוֹ בִּכְרִי נָמֵי! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: עָלֶיךָ אָמַר קְרָא
human_translation: Rav Pappa said to Abaye: If so, even if preceded in a pile, said to him: With regard to your the verse stated:
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Papa to Abbaye: If so, even if they placed him in a furnace! He said to him: Upon you the verse said.

hebrew_text: ״מִכֹּל מַעְשְׂרֹתֵיכֶם תָּרִימוּ״. וּמָה רָאִיתָ? הַאי אִידְּגַן וְהַאי לָא אִידְּגַן.
human_translation: “From all of that is given to you, you shall set apart And what did you see This, has become grain, and that, did not become grain.
llm_translation: "From all your tithes you shall give." And what did you see? This one is fertile, and this one is not fertile.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי וְהֶקְדֵּשׁ שֶׁנִּפְדּוּ: פְּשִׁיטָא! הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁנָּתַן אֶת הַקֶּרֶן, וְלֹא נָתַן אֶת הַחוֹמֶשׁ. וְהָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּאֵין חוֹמֶשׁ מְעַכֵּב.
human_translation: second tithe and consecrated food that were redeemed, It is obvious With what are we dealing here? a case where one gave the principal, but he did not give the fifth and teaches us the fifth does not invalidate
llm_translation: Second tithe and consecrated items that were redeemed: It is obvious! Here, what are we dealing with - for example, when one gave the principal but did not give the fifth. And here it is implied to us that the fifth does not prevent.

hebrew_text: הַשַּׁמָּשׁ שֶׁאָכַל כְּזַיִת: פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְתֵימָא: שַׁמָּשׁ לָא קָבַע — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: The waiter who ate an olive-bulk It is obvious. Lest you say that the waiter did not establish teaches us
llm_translation: The sun that consumed like an olive: It is obvious! What might you say: if the sun did not set — it implies to us.

hebrew_text: וְהַכּוּתִי מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו: אַמַּאי? לֹא יְהֵא אֶלָּא עַם הָאָרֶץ! וְתַנְיָא אֵין מְזַמְּנִין עַל עַם הָאָרֶץ!
human_translation: a Samaritan [ Kuti ] may be included in a zimmun . Why? let him be merely an am ha’aretz , and it was taught An am ha’aretz may not be included in a zimmun .
llm_translation: The Samaritans invite him. Why? He should only be considered an 'Am Ha'aretz (ignorant person)! And it was taught: One does not invite an 'Am Ha'aretz!

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי אָמַר בְּכוּתִי חָבֵר. רָבָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא בְּכוּתִי עַם הָאָרֶץ, וְהָכָא בְּעַם הָאָרֶץ דְּרַבָּנַן דִּפְלִיגִי עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר עָסְקִינַן, דְּתַנְיָא: אֵיזֶהוּ עַם הָאָרֶץ? — כֹּל שֶׁאֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל חוּלָּיו בְּטָהֳרָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: כֹּל שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְעַשֵּׂר פֵּירוֹתָיו כָּרָאוּי. וְהָנֵי כּוּתָאֵי עַשּׂוֹרֵי מְעַשְּׂרִי כְּדַחֲזֵי, דִּבְמַאי דִּכְתִיב בְּאוֹרָיְיתָא מִזְהָר זְהִירִי. דְּאָמַר מָר כׇּל מִצְוָה שֶׁהֶחֱזִיקוּ בָּהּ כּוּתִים — הַרְבֵּה מְדַקְדְּקִין בָּהּ, יוֹתֵר מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: Abaye said: Kuti who is a ḥaver , Rava said: Even if you say a Kuti am ha’aretz , and here am ha’aretz the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Meir, as it was taught Who is an am ha’aretz ? Anyone who does not eat non-sacred food in ritual purity. the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: anyone who does not appropriately tithe his produce. And these Kutim tithe appropriately, as they are scrupulous with regard to that which is written in the Torah, as the Master said: Any mitzva that the Kutim embraced they are more exacting in its than Jews.
llm_translation: Abaye said in the name of a Kutite colleague. Rava said: Even if you say a Kutite is an Am Ha'aretz, here we are dealing with Am Ha'aretz who are Rabbinic scholars, as it was taught: Who is considered an Am Ha'aretz? — Anyone who does not eat his food in a state of purity, according to the words of Rabbi Meir. And the Sages say: Anyone who does not tithe his produce properly. And these Kutim tithe their tithes as they see fit, as it is written in the Torah, "Beware and be cautious." For the Master said, any commandment that the Kutim have taken upon themselves, they are more meticulous in its observance than the Israelites.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵיזֶהוּ עַם הָאָרֶץ? — כֹּל שֶׁאֵינוֹ קוֹרֵא קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע עַרְבִית וְשַׁחֲרִית, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁאֵינוֹ מַנִּיחַ תְּפִילִּין. בֶּן עַזַּאי אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁאֵין לוֹ צִיצִית בְּבִגְדוֹ. רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁאֵין מְזוּזָה עַל פִּתְחוֹ. רַבִּי נָתָן בַּר יוֹסֵף אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ בָּנִים וְאֵינוֹ מְגַדְּלָם לְתַלְמוּד תּוֹרָה. אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים: אֲפִילּוּ קָרָא וְשָׁנָה וְלֹא שִׁמֵּשׁ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים הֲרֵי זֶה עַם הָאָרֶץ. אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: הֲלָכָה כַּאֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Who is an am ha’aretz ? One who does not recite Shema in the evening and morning. This is the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. one who does not don phylacteries. Ben Azzai says: one who does not have ritual fringes on his garment. Rabbi Natan says: one who does not have a mezuza on his doorway. Rabbi Natan bar Yosef says: one who has children but does not raise them to Torah study. Aḥerim say: Even if one read the Bible and studied Mishna and did not serve Torah scholars that is an am ha’aretz . Rav Huna said: The halakha is in accordance with Aḥerim .
llm_translation: The sages taught: Who is considered an 'am ha'aretz (ignorant person)? — Anyone who does not recite the Shema in the evening and morning, according to the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says: Anyone who does not lay tefillin. Ben Azzai says: Anyone who does not have tzitzit on his garment. Rabbi Natan says: Anyone who does not have a mezuzah on his doorpost. Rabbi Natan bar Yosef says: Anyone who has children but does not raise them to study Torah. Others say: Even if one reads and studies but does not serve Torah scholars, he is considered an 'am ha'aretz. Rav Huna said: The halakha is in accordance with the others.

hebrew_text: רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא לָא אַזְמֵין עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַב מְנַשְּׁיָא בַּר תַּחְלִיפָא דְּתָנֵי סִיפְרָא וְסִפְרֵי וְהִלְכְתָא. כִּי נָח נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּרָמֵי בַּר חָמָא, אָמַר רָבָא: לָא נָח נַפְשֵׁיהּ דְּרָמֵי בַּר חָמָא אֶלָּא דְּלָא אַזְמֵין אַרַב מְנַשְּׁיָא בַּר תַּחְלִיפָא. וְהָתַנְיָא — אֲחֵרִים אוֹמְרִים אֲפִילּוּ קָרָא וְשָׁנָה וְלֹא שִׁמֵּשׁ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים הֲרֵי זֶה עַם הָאָרֶץ? שָׁאנֵי רַב מְנַשְּׁיָא בַּר תַּחְלִיפָא דִּמְשַׁמַּע לְהוּ לְרַבָּנַן, וְרָמֵי בַּר חָמָא הוּא דְּלָא דָּק אַבָּתְרֵיהּ. לִישָּׁנָא אַחֲרִינָא: דְּשָׁמַע שְׁמַעְתָּתָא מִפּוּמַּיְיהוּ דְרַבָּנַן וְגָרֵיס לְהוּ — כְּצוֹרְבָא מֵרַבָּנָן דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama did not include Rav Menashya bar Taḥlifa, who studied Sifra , Sifrei, and halakhot, in a zimmun When Rami bar Ḥama passed away, Rava said: Rami bar Ḥama died only because he did not include Rabbi Menashya bar Taḥlifa in a zimmun . Was it not taught Aḥerim say: Even if one read the Bible and studied mishna and did not serve Torah scholars, that is an am ha’aretz ? Rav Menashya bar Taḥlifa is different, as he served the Sages. And it was Rami bar Ḥama who was not precise after him Another version who hears halakhot from the mouths of Sages and studies them is considered a Torah scholar.
llm_translation: Ramei bar Ḥama did not heed the teaching of Rav Menashya bar Taḥlifa who taught the Sefer, Sifrei, and Halakha. When Ramei bar Ḥama passed away, Rava said: It was not that Ramei bar Ḥama passed away, but rather that he did not heed the teaching of Rav Menashya bar Taḥlifa. And it was taught: Others say, even if one reads and studies but does not serve Torah scholars, he is considered an ignoramus? This is different with Rav Menashya bar Taḥlifa, as he would incline towards the teachings of the Rabbis, while Ramei bar Ḥama did not pay attention to them. Another interpretation: You have heard from their mouths the teachings of the Rabbis and have repeated them — it is like one who gathers from the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: אָכַל טֶבֶל וּמַעֲשֵׂר וְכוּ׳: טֶבֶל פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא בְּטֶבֶל טָבוּל מִדְּרַבָּנַן. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי — בְּעָצִיץ שֶׁאֵינוֹ נָקוּב.
human_translation: one who ate untithed produce and tithe etc. It is obvious It was only necessary untithed produce by rabbinic law, What are the circumstances? in an unperforated flowerpot,
llm_translation: He ate tevel and ma'aser, etc.: Tevel - it is obvious! It is not necessary to say that with tevel one must immerse according to the Rabbis. How so? - In an unperforated vessel.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֵׂר רִאשׁוֹן כּוּ׳: פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא כְּגוֹן שֶׁהִקְדִּימוֹ בִּכְרִי. מַהוּ דְתֵימָא כְּדַאֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן כִּדְשַׁנִּי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: first tithe It is obvious. It was only necessary where preceded in a pile. Lest you say as Rav Pappa said to Abaye, teaches us as responded
llm_translation: First tithe 106: It is obvious! Not necessary, such as when they prioritized it in the granary. What might you say, as Rav Papa said to Abbaye - he is teaching us as he taught it to him.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי וְכוּ׳: פְּשִׁיטָא! לָא צְרִיכָא, שֶׁנִּפְדּוּ וְלֹא נִפְדּוּ כְּהִלְכָתָן. מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי — כְּגוֹן שֶׁפְּדָאוֹ עַל גַּבֵּי אֲסִימוֹן, וְרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״וְצַרְתָּ הַכֶּסֶף בְּיָדְךָ״ — כֶּסֶף שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ עָלָיו צוּרָה. הֶקְדֵּשׁ — שֶׁחִלְּלוֹ עַל גַּבֵּי קַרְקַע, וְלֹא פְּדָאוֹ בְּכֶסֶף, וְרַחֲמָנָא אָמַר: ״וְנָתַן הַכֶּסֶף וְקָם לוֹ״.
human_translation: second tithe It is obvious? It was only necessary where they were redeemed, but not redeemed properly, i.e., second tithe that was redeemed with an unminted coin [ asimon ], And the Torah says: “And bind up [ vetzarta ] the money in your hand” money that has a form [ tzura ] upon it. Consecrated property; where he redeemed it for land instead of money, and the Torah states: “He will give the money and it will be assured to him”
llm_translation: Second tithe, etc.: It is obvious! Not necessary, that they were redeemed and not redeemed according to their law. Second tithe - for example, if one redeemed it with a coin of Asimon, and the Merciful One said: "And you shall put the money in your hand" - money that has a form. Hekdesh - that one consecrated it on the ground, and did not redeem it with money, and the Merciful One said: "And the money shall be given, and it shall be his."

hebrew_text: וְהַשַּׁמָּשׁ שֶׁאָכַל פָּחוֹת מִכְּזַיִת: פְּשִׁיטָא! אַיְּידִי דִּתְנָא רֵישָׁא ״כְּזַיִת״, תְּנָא סֵיפָא ״פָּחוֹת מִכְּזַיִת״.
human_translation: a waiter who ate less than an olive-bulk It is obvious. Since the first clause taught an olive-bulk, the latter clause taught less than an olive-bulk.
llm_translation: The sun that ate less than an olive's bulk: It is obvious! Since the first Tanna taught "an olive's bulk," the latter Tanna taught "less than an olive's bulk."

hebrew_text: וְהַנׇּכְרִי אֵין מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו: פְּשִׁיטָא! הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן, בְּגֵר שֶׁמָּל וְלֹא טָבַל. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לְעוֹלָם אֵינוֹ גֵּר עַד שֶׁיִּמּוֹל וְיִטְבּוֹל, וְכַמָּה דְּלָא טְבַל גּוֹי הוּא.
human_translation: a gentile is not included in a zimmun . It is obvious. With what are we dealing here? with a convert who was circumcised but not immerse as Rabbi Zeira said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One is never a proselyte until he is circumcised and immerses As long as he did not immerse he is a gentile.
llm_translation: The non-Jew, we do not appoint upon him. Obvious! Here, with what are we dealing? With a convert who circumcised but did not immerse. For Rabbi Zeira said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: A person is not considered a convert until he is circumcised and immersed, and if he did not immerse, he is still considered a non-Jew.

hebrew_text: נָשִׁים וַעֲבָדִים וּקְטַנִּים אֵין מְזַמְּנִין עֲלֵיהֶן. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: קָטָן הַמּוּטָּל בַּעֲרִיסָה מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: women, slaves, and minors are not included in a zimmun . Rabbi Yosei said: A minor lying in a cradle is included in a zimmun .
llm_translation: Women, slaves, and minors are not summoned. Rabbi Yosei said: A minor lying in a cradle is summoned.

hebrew_text: וְהָא תְּנַן: נָשִׁים וַעֲבָדִים וּקְטַנִּים אֵין מְזַמְּנִין עֲלֵיהֶם!
human_translation: Didn’t we learn that women, slaves, and minors are not included in a zimmun ?
llm_translation: And this we learned in a Mishnah: Women, slaves, and minors are not appointed over them!

hebrew_text: הוּא דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאָמְרוּ קָטָן הַמּוּטָּל בַּעֲרִיסָה אֵין מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו, אֲבָל עוֹשִׂין אוֹתוֹ סְנִיף לַעֲשָׂרָה.
human_translation: stated in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Although a minor lying in a cradle is not included in a zimmun , one may make him an adjunct to ten
llm_translation: He said as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Even though they said a minor who is lying in a cradle is not liable to have a blessing recited over him, nevertheless, they make him a branch for ten.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: תִּשְׁעָה וְעֶבֶד — מִצְטָרְפִין. מֵיתִיבִי: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר שֶׁנִּכְנַס לְבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת וְלֹא מָצָא עֲשָׂרָה, וְשִׁחְרֵר עַבְדּוֹ וְהִשְׁלִימוֹ לַעֲשָׂרָה. שִׁחְרֵר — אִין, לֹא שִׁחְרֵר — לָא. תְּרֵי אִיצְטְרִיכוּ, שַׁחְרֵר חַד וְנָפֵיק בְּחַד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Nine and a slave join together raises an objection: incident involving Rabbi Eliezer, who entered a synagogue and did not find ten, and he liberated his slave and he completed the ten. freed yes, did not free no, two were required freed one and fulfilled his obligation with one,
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Nine and a slave - combine. It was asked: It happened with Rabbi Eliezer that he entered the synagogue and did not find ten, so he freed his slave and completed the ten. If he freed - yes, if he did not free - no. Two are needed, free one and go out with one.

hebrew_text: וְהֵיכִי עָבֵיד הָכִי? וְהָאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה כׇּל הַמְשַׁחְרֵר עַבְדּוֹ עוֹבֵר בַּעֲשֵׂה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״? לִדְבַר מִצְוָה שָׁאנֵי: מִצְוָה הַבָּאָה בַּעֲבֵרָה הִיא! — מִצְוָה דְרַבִּים שָׁאנֵי.
human_translation: How did he do that? Didn’t Rav Yehuda say: Anyone who frees his slave violates a positive mitzva, as it is stated they will serve as bondsmen for you forever” a mitzva is different. It is a mitzva that comes through a transgression, A mitzva the many is different,
llm_translation: And how does he do so? And Rav Yehudah said: Anyone who frees his slave transgresses a positive commandment, as it is stated: "You shall serve them forever." This is different regarding a commandment, for it is a commandment that comes through transgression! — It is a commandment that involves the majority.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: לְעוֹלָם יַשְׁכִּים אָדָם לְבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּזְכֶּה וְיִמָּנֶה עִם עֲשָׂרָה הָרִאשׁוֹנִים, שֶׁאֲפִילּוּ מֵאָה בָּאִים אַחֲרָיו — קִבֵּל עָלָיו שְׂכַר כּוּלָּם. ״שְׂכַר כּוּלָּם״ סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ?! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: נוֹתְנִין לוֹ שָׂכָר כְּנֶגֶד כּוּלָּם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One should always rise early to the synagogue in order to have the privilege and be counted among the first ten as even if one hundred arrive after him, he receives the reward of them all, Does it enter your mind the reward of them all? Rather, say: He receives a reward equivalent to them all.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: A person should always rise early to the synagogue in order to merit and be counted with the first ten, for even if a hundred come after him - he receives the reward of all of them. "The reward of all of them" - is it your opinion?! Rather say: they give him the reward corresponding to all of them.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: תִּשְׁעָה וְאָרוֹן — מִצְטָרְפִין. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן: וְאָרוֹן גַּבְרָא הוּא? אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: תִּשְׁעָה נִרְאִין כַּעֲשָׂרָה — מִצְטָרְפִין. אָמְרִי לַהּ: כִּי מְכַנְּפִי. וְאָמְרִי לַהּ: כִּי מְבַדְּרִי.
human_translation: Rav Huna said: Nine plus an ark join Rav Naḥman said to him: Is an ark a man, Rather, Rav Huna said: Nine who appear like ten may join together. Some said this when they are gathered. And some said this when they are scattered,
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: Nine and an aron - combine. Rav Nachman said to him: Is an aron a person? Rather, Rav Huna said: Nine that appear like ten - combine. They said to him: Because you round up. And they said to him: Because you round down.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַמֵּי: שְׁנַיִם וְשַׁבָּת מִצְטָרְפִין. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן: וְשַׁבָּת גַּבְרָא הוּא?! אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: שְׁנֵי תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים הַמְחַדְּדִין זֶה אֶת זֶה בַּהֲלָכָה מִצְטָרְפִין. מַחְוֵי רַב חִסְדָּא: כְּגוֹן אֲנָא וְרַב שֵׁשֶׁת. מַחְוֵי רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: כְּגוֹן אֲנָא וְרַב חִסְדָּא.
human_translation: Rav Ami said: Two and Shabbat join Rav Naḥman said to him: Is Shabbat a person, Rather, Rav Ami said: Two Torah scholars who hone each other’s in halakhic join together Rav Ḥisda pointed For example, me and Rav Sheshet. Rav Sheshet pointed: For example, me and Rav Ḥisda.
llm_translation: Rav Ammi said: Two and Shabbat combine. Rav Nachman said to him: Shabbat is a man?! Rather, Rabbi Ammi said: Two Torah scholars who sharpen each other in halacha combine. For example, Rav Hisda and Rav Sheshet. Rav Sheshet said: For example, I and Rav Hisda.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: קָטָן פּוֹרֵחַ — מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: קָטָן שֶׁהֵבִיא שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו, וְשֶׁלֹּא הֵבִיא שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — אֵין מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו, וְאֵין מְדַקְדְּקִין בְּקָטָן. הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא, אָמְרַתְּ: הֵבִיא שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — אִין, לָא הֵבִיא — לָא. וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי אֵין מְדַקְדְּקִין בְּקָטָן. לְאֵתוּיֵי מַאי? לָאו
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A mature minor, is included in a zimmun . That was also taught A minor who grew two hairs, is included in a zimmun ; and one who did not grow two hairs is not included in a zimmun . And one is not exacting with regard to a minor. This itself is difficult. You said that who grew two hairs, yes, one who did not grow no, and then it taught that one is not exacting with regard to a minor. What to include? Is it not
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: A minor who produces pubic hair - we appoint him to fulfill religious obligations. It was taught in a baraita similarly: A minor who brought two pubic hairs - we appoint him to fulfill religious obligations, and if he did not bring two pubic hairs - we do not appoint him, and we are not meticulous with a minor. This is a difficult matter in itself, you say: If he brought two pubic hairs - no, if he did not bring them - no. And then it teaches: We are not meticulous with a minor. For what purpose? For no reason.

hebrew_text: לְאֵתוּיֵי קָטָן פּוֹרֵחַ?
human_translation: to include a mature minor?
llm_translation: For the inclusion of a minor, does he blossom?

hebrew_text: וְלֵית הִלְכְתָא כְּכׇל הָנֵי שְׁמַעְתָּתָא, אֶלָּא כִּי הָא דְּאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: קָטָן הַיּוֹדֵעַ לְמִי מְבָרְכִין — מְזַמְּנִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: The halakha is not in accordance with all of these statements. Rather, in accordance with this that Rav Naḥman said: A minor who knows to Whom one recites a blessing is included in a zimmun .
llm_translation: And there is no halakha like all those reports, but rather as Rav Nachman said: A minor who knows over whom we bless - we appoint him.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי וְרָבָא הֲווֹ יָתְבִי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבָּה. אֲמַר לְהוּ רַבָּה: לְמִי מְבָרְכִין? אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: לְרַחֲמָנָא. וְרַחֲמָנָא הֵיכָא יָתֵיב? — רָבָא אַחְוִי לִשְׁמֵי טְלָלָא. אַבָּיֵי נְפַק לְבַרָּא, אַחְוִי כְּלַפֵּי שְׁמַיָּא. אֲמַר לְהוּ רַבָּה: תַּרְוַיְיכוּ רַבָּנַן הָוֵיתוּ. הַיְינוּ דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: בּוּצִין בּוּצִין מִקִּטְפֵיהּ יְדִיעַ.
human_translation: Abaye and Rava, were seated before Rabba. Rabba said to them: To whom does one recite blessings? They said to him: To the All-Merciful. And where does the All-Merciful reside? Rava pointed to the ceiling. Abaye went outside and pointed toward the heaven. Rabba said to them: You will both become Sages. It is as the popular saying goes: A cucumber can be recognized from its blossoming
llm_translation: Abaye and Rava were sitting before Rabah. Rabah said to them: To whom do we bless? They said to him: To the Merciful One. Where does the Merciful One sit? Rava pointed to the shadow of the wall. Abaye went out and pointed towards the sky. Rabah said to them: You are true scholars. This is what people say: "He plucks knowledge from His palm."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר שִׁילַת מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב: תִּשְׁעָה אָכְלוּ דָּגָן וְאֶחָד אָכַל יָרָק — מִצְטָרְפִין. אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: בְּעַאי מִינֵּיהּ מֵרַב יְהוּדָה: שְׁמֹנָה מַהוּ? שִׁבְעָה מַהוּ? אָמַר לִי: לָא שְׁנָא. שִׁשָּׁה וַדַּאי לָא מִבַּעְיָא לִי. אָמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: שַׁפִּיר עֲבַדְתְּ דְּלָא אִיבַּעְיָא לְךָ, הָתָם טַעְמָא מַאי — מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיכָּא רוּבָּא, הָכָא נָמֵי אִיכָּא רוּבָּא. וְאִיהוּ סָבַר רוּבָּא דְמִינְּכַר בָּעֵינַן.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda, son of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, said in the name of Rav: nine ate grain and one ate vegetables, they join Rabbi Zeira said: I raised a dilemma before Rav Yehuda: What is eight What is seven He said to me: There is no difference. I certainly had no dilemma with regard to six, Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: You did well that you had no dilemma There, what is the reason Because there is a majority Here, too, there is a majority. held: We require an obvious majority.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah, son of Rav Shmuel bar Shilat, said in the name of Rav: If nine people ate grain and one person ate vegetables - they combine to form a group for certain legal purposes. Rabbi Zeira said to Rav Yehudah: If there are eight people, what is the law? If there are seven people, what is the law? He said to me: It does not matter. If there are six, for sure I do not need to ask. Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: You have done well by not needing to ask, for there the reason is because there is a majority, and here too there is a majority. And he Rav Yehudah holds that we require a majority that is recognizable.

hebrew_text: יַנַּאי מַלְכָּא וּמַלְכְּתָא כְּרִיכוּ רִיפְתָּא בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי, וּמִדִּקְטַל לְהוּ לְרַבָּנַן לָא הֲוָה לֵיהּ אִינִישׁ לְבָרוֹכֵי לְהוּ. אֲמַר לַהּ לִדְבֵיתְהוּ: מַאן יָהֵיב לַן גַּבְרָא דִּמְבָרֵךְ לַן? אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: אִשְׁתְּבַע לִי דְּאִי מַיְיתֵינָא לָךְ גַּבְרָא דְּלָא מְצַעֲרַתְּ לֵיהּ. אִשְׁתְּבַע לַהּ. אַיְיתִיתֵיהּ לְשִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן שָׁטַח אֲחוּהָ. אוֹתְבֵיהּ בֵּין דִּידֵיהּ לְדִידַהּ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: חָזֵית כַּמָּה יְקָרָא עָבֵידְנָא לָךְ. אָמַר לֵיהּ: לָאו אַתְּ קָא מוֹקְרַתְּ לִי אֶלָּא אוֹרָיְיתָא הִיא דְּמוֹקְרָא לִי, דִּכְתִיב: ״סַלְסְלֶהָ וּתְרוֹמְמֶךָּ תְּכַבֵּדְךָ כִּי תְחַבְּקֶנָּה״. אֲמַר לַהּ: קָא חָזֵית דְּלָא מְקַבֵּל מָרוּת.
human_translation: King Yannai and the queen ate bread together. And since executed the Sages, there was no one to recite the blessing on their behalf. He said to his wife: Who will provide us a man to recite the blessing on our behalf? She said to him: Swear to me that if I bring you a man, you will not harass him. He swore, she brought her brother, Shimon ben Shataḥ. She sat him between and hers. said to him: Do you see how much honor I am according you? He responded: not you who honors me; rather, the Torah honors me, as it is written: “Extol her and she will exalt you; she will bring you to honor when you embrace her” said to You see that he does not accept authority.
llm_translation: Yannai the king and the queen were sitting at a meal of radishes in the presence of Hadadei, and when he began to cut for them, the sages were not pleased with him. He said to his wife: Who will give us a man who will bless us? She said to him: Swear to me that if I bring you a man who will not belittle you, you will accept him. He swore to her. She brought him Shimon ben Shatach, her brother. She placed him between herself and her husband. He said to her: See how much honor we are doing for you. She said to him: You are not honoring me, but the Torah that honors me, as it is written: "She will place it on you and exalt you; when you embrace her." He said to her: You have seen that I do not accept authority.

hebrew_text: יְהַבוּ לֵיהּ כָּסָא לְבָרוֹכֵי. אֲמַר: הֵיכִי אֲבָרֵיךְ — ״בָּרוּךְ שֶׁאָכַל יַנַּאי וַחֲבֵירָיו מִשֶּׁלּוֹ״? שַׁתְיֵיהּ לְהָהוּא כָּסָא, יְהַבוּ לֵיהּ כָּסָא אַחֲרִינָא וּבָרֵיךְ.
human_translation: They gave a cup over which to recite He said: How shall I recite the blessing? Blessed is He from Whom Yannai and his companions have eaten? He drank that cup They gave him another cup, and he recited the blessing.
llm_translation: Give him a cup for the blessings. He said: How should I bless? "Blessed is the One who fed Yanai and his companions from His own." Give him that cup to drink, give him another cup and let him bless.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן שָׁטַח דַּעֲבַד — לְגַרְמֵיהּ הוּא דַּעֲבַד, דְּהָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לְעוֹלָם אֵינוֹ מוֹצִיא אֶת הָרַבִּים יְדֵי חוֹבָתָן עַד שֶׁיֹּאכַל כְּזַיִת דָּגָן.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, said Rabbi Yoḥanan said): That which Shimon ben Shataḥ did, he did on his own, as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said as follows: One cannot fulfill the obligation of others until he eats an olive-bulk of grain.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Abba son of Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said Rabbi Yochanan: Shimon ben Shatach who did — for himself he did, as thus said Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said Rabbi Yochanan: Always he does not exempt the many from their obligation until he eats an olive's worth of grain.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי, רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: עָלָה וְהֵסֵיב עִמָּהֶם אֲפִילּוּ לֹא טִבֵּל עִמָּהֶם אֶלָּא בְּצִיר, וְלֹא אָכַל עִמָּהֶם אֶלָּא גְּרוֹגֶרֶת אַחַת — מִצְטָרֵף.
human_translation: raises an objection Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One who entered and reclined together even if he only dipped with them in brine and ate with them only a single dry fig, he joins them.
llm_translation: The Tanna raises an objection: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If he went up and ate with them, even if he did not immerse with them except in a courtyard, and did not eat with them except one dried fig - he is considered to have joined them.

hebrew_text: אִיצְטְרוֹפֵי מִצְטָרֵף אֲבָל לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הָרַבִּים יְדֵי חוֹבָתָן — עַד שֶׁיֹּאכַל כְּזַיִת דָּגָן.
human_translation: he joins them, but satisfy the obligation of the many unless he has eaten an olive-bulk of grain.
llm_translation: The gatherings are combined, but to exempt the many from their obligation - until he eats an olive's worth of grain.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר נָמֵי, אָמַר רַב חָנָא בַּר יְהוּדָה מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: אֲפִילּוּ לֹא
human_translation: was also stated: Rav Ḥana bar Yehuda said in the name of Rava: Even if he only
llm_translation: It was stated similarly: Rav Ḥanina bar Yehuda said in the name of Rava: Even if not.

hebrew_text: טִבֵּל עִמָּהֶם אֶלָּא בְּצִיר, וְלֹא אָכַל עִמָּהֶם אֶלָּא גְּרוֹגֶרֶת אַחַת — מִצְטָרֵף. וּלְהוֹצִיא אֶת הָרַבִּים יְדֵי חוֹבָתָם — אֵינוֹ מוֹצִיא עַד שֶׁיֹּאכַל כְּזַיִת דָּגָן. אָמַר רַב חָנָא בַּר יְהוּדָה מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: הִלְכְתָא, אָכַל עֲלֵה יָרָק וְשָׁתָה כּוֹס שֶׁל יַיִן — מִצְטָרֵף. לְהוֹצִיא — אֵינוֹ מוֹצִיא עַד שֶׁיֹּאכַל כְּזַיִת דָּגָן.
human_translation: dipped with them in brine and ate with them only a single dry fig, he joins them. And to satisfy the obligation of the many, he does not satisfy until he eats an olive-bulk of grain. Rabbi Ḥana bar Yehuda said in the name of Rava the halakha is: ate a vegetable leaf and drank a cup of wine, he joins to satisfy he does not satisfy until he eats an olive-bulk of grain.
llm_translation: He immersed with them only in a courtyard, and did not eat with them except for one dried fig - he is included. And in order to exempt the majority from their obligation - he does not exempt until he eats the size of an olive of grain. Rav Ḥana bar Yehuda said in the name of Rava: It is a halakha, if one ate a leaf of lettuce and drank a cup of wine - he is included. To exempt - he does not exempt until he eats the size of an olive of grain.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: מֹשֶׁה תִּקֵּן לְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּרְכַּת ״הַזָּן״ בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁיָּרַד לָהֶם מָן. יְהוֹשֻׁעַ תִּקֵּן לָהֶם בִּרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ כֵּיוָן שֶׁנִּכְנְסוּ לָאָרֶץ. דָּוִד וּשְׁלֹמֹה תִּקְּנוּ ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״. דָּוִד תִּקֵּן ״עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל עַמֶּךָ וְעַל יְרוּשָׁלַיִם עִירֶךָ״, וּשְׁלֹמֹה תִּקֵּן ״עַל הַבַּיִת הַגָּדוֹל וְהַקָּדוֹשׁ״. ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ בְּיַבְנֶה תִּקְּנוּהָ כְּנֶגֶד הֲרוּגֵי בֵּיתָר. דְּאָמַר רַב מַתְנָא: אוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם שֶׁנִּיתְּנוּ הֲרוּגֵי בֵּיתָר לִקְבוּרָה תִּקְנוּ בְּיַבְנֶה ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״. ״הַטּוֹב״ — שֶׁלֹּא הִסְרִיחוּ, ״וְהַמֵּטִיב״ — שֶׁנִּיתְּנוּ לִקְבוּרָה.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said: Moses instituted for Israel the blessing of: Who feeds when the manna descended for them Joshua instituted the blessing of the land when they entered Eretz Yisrael. David and Solomon instituted the Who builds Jerusalem, David instituted “…on Israel Your people and on Jerusalem Your city…” and Solomon instituted “…on the great and Holy Temple…” They instituted Who is good and does good, at Yavne in reference to the slain of Beitar As Rav Mattana said: On the same day that the slain of Beitar were brought to burial, they instituted Who is good and does good, at Yavne. Who is good, did not decompose and does good, that they were brought to burial.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: Moses instituted for Israel the blessing of "HaZan" at the time when the manna descended for them. Joshua instituted for them the blessing of the land once they entered the land. David and Solomon instituted "Boneh Yerushalayim." David instituted "Upon Israel Your people and upon Jerusalem Your city," and Solomon instituted "Upon the great and holy house." "HaTov VeHaMeitiv" in Yavneh they instituted it opposite the slain of Beitar. As Rav Matna said: On that day when the slain of Beitar were given for burial, they instituted in Yavneh "HaTov VeHaMeitiv." "HaTov" — that they did not decompose, "VeHaMeitiv" — that they were given for burial.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן, סֵדֶר בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן כָּךְ הִיא: בְּרָכָה רִאשׁוֹנָה — בִּרְכַּת ״הַזָּן״, שְׁנִיָּה — בִּרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ, שְׁלִישִׁית — ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״, רְבִיעִית — ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״, וּבְשַׁבָּת — מַתְחִיל בְּנֶחָמָה וּמְסַיֵּים בְּנֶחָמָה, וְאוֹמֵר קְדוּשַּׁת הַיּוֹם בָּאֶמְצַע. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: רָצָה לְאוֹמְרָהּ בַּנֶּחָמָה — אוֹמְרָהּ, בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ — אוֹמְרָהּ, בִּבְרָכָה שֶׁתִּקְּנוּ חֲכָמִים בְּיַבְנֶה — אוֹמְרָהּ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵינוֹ אוֹמְרָהּ אֶלָּא בַּנֶּחָמָה בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: the Sages taught the order of Grace after Meals is as follows: The first blessing is the blessing of: Who feeds the second is the blessing of the land; the third is: Who builds Jerusalem; and the fourth is: Who is good and does good. On Shabbat one begins with consolation and ends with consolation and mentions the sanctity of the day in the middle. Rabbi Eliezer says: If one wishes to recite the blessing of consolation: he recites it in the blessing of the land, he recites it in the blessing instituted by the Sages at Yavne, he recites it And the Rabbis say: He may only recite in the blessing of consolation.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: The order of the Grace after Meals is as follows: The first blessing is "Blessed is He who feeds," the second is the blessing of the land, the third is "Who builds Jerusalem," the fourth is "Who is good and does good." And on Shabbat, one begins with comfort and ends with comfort, and recites the sanctity of the day in the middle. Rabbi Eliezer says: If one wishes to say it with comfort, he may say it with comfort; if in the blessing of the land, he may say it in the blessing of the land; if in the blessing that the Sages instituted in Yavneh, he may say it. And the Sages say: One may only say it with comfort alone.

hebrew_text: חֲכָמִים הַיְינוּ תַּנָּא קַמָּא? — אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ דִּיעֲבַד.
human_translation: The Rabbis is the first tanna . The difference between after the fact.
llm_translation: The sages, is this the first Tanna? — There is a difference between them that occurred.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מִנַּיִן לְבִרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן מִן הַתּוֹרָה? — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָכַלְתָּ וְשָׂבָעְתָּ וּבֵרַכְתָּ״ — זוֹ בִּרְכַּת ״הַזָּן״, ״אֶת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״ — זוֹ בִּרְכַּת הַזִּמּוּן, ״עַל הָאָרֶץ״ — זוֹ בִּרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ, ״הַטּוֹבָה״ — זוֹ ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״הָהָר הַטּוֹב הַזֶּה וְהַלְּבָנוֹן״. ״אֲשֶׁר נָתַן לָךְ״ — זוֹ ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״. אֵין לִי אֶלָּא לְאַחֲרָיו, לְפָנָיו מִנַּיִן? — אָמְרַתְּ קַל וָחוֹמֶר: כְּשֶׁהוּא שָׂבֵעַ מְבָרֵךְ, כְּשֶׁהוּא רָעֵב — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן.
human_translation: The Sages taught From where Grace after Meals is from the Torah? As it is stated: “And you shall eat and be satisfied, and you shall bless And you shall bless, that is the blessing of: Who feeds The Lord, your God, that is the zimmun blessing For the land, that is the blessing of the land; good, that is Who builds Jerusalem, and it also says: “This good mountain and Lebanon” That He gave you, that is: Who is good and does good. I only have after From where before You said an a fortiori inference: When one is satisfied, he recite a blessing when he is hungry, all the more so
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: From where is the obligation of the blessing after meals derived from the Torah? — As it is stated: "And you shall eat and be satisfied and bless" — this is the blessing of "HaZan" (the sustenance), "the Lord your God" — this is the blessing of invitation (Birkat HaZimun), "upon the land" — this is the blessing of the land, "the good" — this is "Who builds Jerusalem," and similarly it says, "This good mountain and the Lebanon." "Which He has given you" — this is "He who is good and does good." I only know the blessing after, from where is the blessing before derived? — You shall say a fortiori: when one is satisfied, he blesses; when he is hungry — all the more so.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר [אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ]: ״וְאָכַלְתָּ וְשָׂבָעְתָּ וּבֵרַכְתָּ״ — זוֹ בִּרְכַּת הַזָּן, אֲבָל בִּרְכַּת הַזִּמּוּן מִ״גַּדְּלוּ לַה׳ אִתִּי״ נָפְקָא. ״עַל הָאָרֶץ״ — זוֹ בִּרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ, ״הַטּוֹבָה״ — זוֹ ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״הָהָר הַטּוֹב הַזֶּה וְהַלְּבָנוֹן״. ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ בְּיַבְנֶה תִּקְּנוּהָ. אֵין לִי אֶלָּא לְאַחֲרָיו, לְפָנָיו מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר נָתַן לָךְ״ — מִשֶּׁנָּתַן לָךְ.
human_translation: Rabbi says: It is not necessary “And you shall eat and be satisfied, and you shall bless,” that is the blessing of: Who feeds however, the zimmun blessing is derived “Praise God with me For the land, that is the blessing of the land. Good, that is Who builds Jerusalem, and it also says: This good mountain and Lebanon. They instituted Who is good and does good, at Yavne I only have after From where before The verse states: That he gave you. from gave it to you,
llm_translation: Rabbi says it is not necessary: "And you shall eat and be satisfied and bless" — this is the blessing of sustenance, but the blessing of invitation is derived from "magnify to the Lord with me." "Upon the land" — this is the blessing of the land, "the good" — this is "Who builds Jerusalem," and so it says, "This good mountain and Lebanon." "The good and the beneficent" in Yavneh they established it. I only have the obligation after him, from where before him? The Talmud teaches: "Which He has given you" — from when He has given you.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִצְחָק אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״וּבֵרַךְ אֶת לַחְמְךָ וְאֶת מֵימֶיךָ״, אַל תִּקְרֵי ״וּבֵרַךְ״ אֶלָּא ״וּבָרֵךְ״. וְאֵימָתַי קָרוּי ״לֶחֶם״ — קוֹדֶם שֶׁיֹּאכְלֶנּוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak says: is not necessary, as it says: “And He will bless your bread and your water” do not read: And He will bless [ uveirakh ], rather: And you will bless [ uvareikh ]. And when is it called bread? Before it is eaten.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yitzchak says: It is not necessary, as he says, "And you shall bless your bread and your water." Do not read "and you shall bless" but rather "and you shall be blessed." And when is it called "bread" - before one eats it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי נָתָן אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״כְּבֹאֲכֶם הָעִיר כֵּן תִּמְצְאוּן אוֹתוֹ בְּטֶרֶם יַעֲלֶה הַבָּמָתָה לֶאֱכוֹל כִּי לֹא יֹאכַל הָעָם עַד בֹּאוֹ כִּי הוּא יְבָרֵךְ הַזֶּבַח אַחֲרֵי כֵן יֹאכְלוּ הַקְּרֻאִים״.
human_translation: Rabbi Natan says: is not necessary, as it says “As soon you come into the city, find him right away, before he goes up to the high place to eat; for the people will not eat until he comes, because he will bless the sacrifice; and afterwards all those who are invited will eat;
llm_translation: Rabbi Nathan says: It is not necessary, as it says, "As soon as you enter the city, you will find him before he goes up to the high place to eat, for the people will not eat until he comes, because he must bless the sacrifice; afterward, those who are invited will eat."

hebrew_text: וְכׇל כָּךְ לָמָּה? לְפִי שֶׁהַנָּשִׁים דַּבְּרָנִיּוֹת הֵן. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: כְּדֵי לְהִסְתַּכֵּל בְּיׇפְיוֹ שֶׁל שָׁאוּל, דִּכְתִיב: ״מִשִּׁכְמוֹ וָמַעְלָה גָּבֹהַּ מִכׇּל הָעָם״. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מַלְכוּת נוֹגַעַת בַּחֲבֶרְתָּהּ אֲפִילּוּ כִּמְלֹא נִימָא.
human_translation: Why so expansively It is because women are chatterers. And Shmuel said in order to gaze upon Saul’s beauty as it is written he was taller than the people from the shoulders up” Rabbi Yoḥanan said one sovereignty does not overlap with its counterpart, even hairbreadth.
llm_translation: And all this, why? Because women are talkative. And Samuel said: In order to contemplate the beauty of Saul, as it is written: "From his shoulders and upward he was higher than any of the people." And Rabbi Yochanan said: Because kingship does not touch her company, even as much as a hair's breadth.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין לִי אֶלָּא בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן. בִּרְכַּת הַתּוֹרָה מִנַּיִן? אָמַר רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: קַל וָחוֹמֶר, עַל חַיֵּי שָׁעָה מְבָרֵךְ, עַל חַיֵּי עוֹלָם הַבָּא לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן. רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר נַחְמָנִי תַּלְמִידוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״עַל הָאָרֶץ הַטּוֹבָה אֲשֶׁר נָתַן לָךְ״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וְאֶתְּנָה לָךְ אֶת לֻחֹת הָאֶבֶן וְהַתּוֹרָה וְהַמִּצְוָה וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: I only have Grace after Meals. From where the blessing of the Torah Rabbi Yishmael said: an a fortiori inference Over temporal life, one recites a blessing, all the more so eternal life. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Naḥmani, student of Rabbi Yishmael, says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: This is not necessary, as it states: “For the good land that He gave [ natan ] you,” and below, it says: “And I will give [ ve’etna ] you the stone tablets, and the Torah and the mitzva,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And I have only the blessing of the meal. How do we know the blessing of the Torah? Rabbi Yishmael said: Kal vachomer, for a temporary life one blesses, for the eternal life to come, all the more so. Rabbi Chiya bar Nachmani, a disciple of Rabbi Yishmael, says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: It is not necessary, for it says, 'on the good land that He has given you,' and elsewhere it says, 'And I will give you the tablets of stone, and the Torah, and the commandment, etc.'"

hebrew_text: רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁכְּשֵׁם שֶׁמְּבָרֵךְ עַל הַטּוֹבָה כָּךְ מְבָרֵךְ עַל הָרָעָה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר נָתַן לְךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״, דַּיָּינְךָ, בְּכָל דִּין שֶׁדָּנְךָ, בֵּין מִדָּה טוֹבָה וּבֵין מִדַּת פּוּרְעָנוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Meir says: From where just as one recites a blessing over the good he recites a blessing over the bad? The verse states: “That the Lord, your God gave you.” your Judge, in whatever judgment that He judges you, whether it is a positive measure of goodness or a measure of calamity.
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir says: And from where do we derive that just as one blesses for the good, so too does one bless for the bad? The verse teaches: "Which the Lord your God has given you," be content with your judgment, whether it is a favorable measure or a measure of retribution.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתֵירָא אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״טוֹבָה״, ״הַטּוֹבָה״. טוֹבָה — זוֹ תּוֹרָה, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״כִּי לֶקַח טוֹב נָתַתִּי לָכֶם״. ״הַטּוֹבָה״ — זוֹ בִּנְיַן יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״הָהָר הַטּוֹב הַזֶּה וְהַלְּבָנוֹן״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: is not necessary, as it says: Tova , that is Torah, as it says: “For I have given you good [ tov ] teachings, hatova , that is the building of Jerusalem, as it says: “This good mountain [ hatov ] and Lebanon.”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Betera says: It is not necessary, for behold he says "good," "the good." Good - this is Torah, and so he also says: "For I have given you a good teaching." "The good" - this is the building of Jerusalem, and so he also says, "This good mountain and Lebanon."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: כׇּל שֶׁלֹּא אָמַר ״אֶרֶץ חֶמְדָּה טוֹבָה וּרְחָבָה״ בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ, וּמַלְכוּת בֵּית דָּוִד בְּ״בוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם״ — לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ. נַחוּם הַזָּקֵן אוֹמֵר: צָרִיךְ שֶׁיִּזְכּוֹר בָּהּ בְּרִית. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: צָרִיךְ שֶׁיִּזְכּוֹר בָּהּ תּוֹרָה. פְּלֵימוֹ אוֹמֵר: צָרִיךְ שֶׁיַּקְדִּים בְּרִית לְתוֹרָה, שֶׁזּוֹ נִתְּנָה בְּשָׁלֹשׁ בְּרִיתוֹת,
human_translation: It was taught Rabbi Eliezer says: Anyone who did not say: A desirable, good, and spacious land in the blessing of the land, and the royal house of David in Who builds Jerusalem, did not fulfill his obligation. Naḥum the Elder says: One must mention the covenant in Rabbi Yosei says: One must mention the Torah in Pelimu, says: He must covenant preceding Torah, as this, was given with three covenants,
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: Anyone who did not say "a desirable, good, and spacious land" in the blessing of the land, and "the kingdom of the house of David" in "Who builds Jerusalem" — he has not fulfilled his obligation. Nahum the Elder says: It is necessary that the covenant be remembered in it. Rabbi Yosei says: It is necessary that the Torah be remembered in it. Pleimo says: It is necessary to prioritize the covenant over the Torah, for the Torah was given with three covenants.

hebrew_text: וְזוֹ נִתְּנָה בִּשְׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה בְּרִיתוֹת.
human_translation: and that, was given with thirteen covenants,
llm_translation: And this was given in thirteen covenants.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אַבָּא אוֹמֵר: צָרִיךְ שֶׁיֹּאמַר בָּהּ הוֹדָאָה תְּחִלָּה וָסוֹף. וְהַפּוֹחֵת לֹא יִפְחוֹת מֵאַחַת. וְכׇל הַפּוֹחֵת מֵאַחַת — הֲרֵי זֶה מְגוּנֶּה.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba says: One must mention thanks at the beginning and the end And one who decreases may not decrease to fewer than one, and anyone decreases to fewer than one, it is reprehensible.
llm_translation: Rabbi Abba says: It is necessary to say in it acknowledgment at the beginning and at the end. And the one who diminishes should not diminish from one. And anyone who diminishes from one — this one is despised.

hebrew_text: וְכׇל הַחוֹתֵם ״מַנְחִיל אֲרָצוֹת״ בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ, וּ״מוֹשִׁיעַ אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל״ בְּ״בוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״ — הֲרֵי זֶה בּוּר. וְכׇל שֶׁאֵינוֹ אוֹמֵר בְּרִית וְתוֹרָה בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ, וּמַלְכוּת בֵּית דָּוִד בְּ״בוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״ — לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ.
human_translation: Anyone who concludes the blessing of the land: Who bequeaths lands and the blessing: Who builds Jerusalem, Who redeems Israel, is an ignoramus, And anyone who does not mention covenant and Torah in the blessing of the land and the royal house of David in Who builds Jerusalem, did not fulfill his obligation.
llm_translation: "And all who concludes 'Who grants lands' in the blessing of the land, and 'Who saves Israel' in 'Who builds Jerusalem' — this is considered a blessing. But anyone who does not mention the covenant and Torah in the blessing of the land, and the kingdom of the house of David in 'Who builds Jerusalem' — he has not fulfilled his obligation."

hebrew_text: מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אִילְעָא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא אָמַר רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב בַּר אַחָא מִשּׁוּם רַבֵּינוּ: כׇּל שֶׁלֹּא אָמַר בְּרִית וְתוֹרָה בְּבִרְכַּת הָאָרֶץ וּמַלְכוּת בֵּית דָּוִד בְּ״בוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״ — לֹא יָצָא יְדֵי חוֹבָתוֹ.
human_translation: This supports Rabbi Il’a, as Rabbi Il’a said Rabbi Ya’akov bar Aḥa said in the name of Rabbeinu, Anyone who did not mention covenant and Torah in the blessing of the land and the royal house of David in Who builds Jerusalem, did not fulfill his obligation.
llm_translation: He assists Rabbi Ilai, for Rabbi Ilai said in the name of Rabbi Yaakov bar Acha in the name of our teacher: Anyone who does not mention the covenant, Torah, the blessing of the land, and the kingdom of the house of David in "Who builds Jerusalem" has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: פְּלִיגִי בַּהּ אַבָּא יוֹסֵי בֶּן דּוֹסְתַּאי וְרַבָּנַן. חַד אָמַר: ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״ צְרִיכָה מַלְכוּת, וְחַד אָמַר: אֵינָהּ צְרִיכָה מַלְכוּת. מַאן דְּאָמַר צְרִיכָה מַלְכוּת קָסָבַר דְּרַבָּנַן. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵינָהּ צְרִיכָה מַלְכוּת קָסָבַר דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: Abba Yosei ben Dostai and the Rabbis disagreed One said: Who is good and does good, requires sovereignty, and one said: It does not require sovereignty. The one who said that it requires sovereignty holds that by the Sages, The one who said that it does not require sovereignty holds that is by Torah law.
llm_translation: They disputed it: Abba Yosei ben Dosatai and the Rabbis. One said: "Good and pleasing" requires kingship, and one said: It does not require kingship. The one who said it requires kingship holds like the Rabbis. And the one who said it does not require kingship holds like the Torah.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַהוּ חוֹתֵם בְּבִנְיַן יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: ״מוֹשִׁיעַ יִשְׂרָאֵל״. ״מוֹשִׁיעַ יִשְׂרָאֵל״ — אִין, ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״ — לָא? אֶלָּא אֵימָא: אַף ״מוֹשִׁיעַ יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
human_translation: what does he conclude the building of Jerusalem? Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda says: Who redeems Israel. Who redeems Israel, yes, The building of Jerusalem, no, Rather, say or even Who redeems Israel.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: What is the seal in the building of Jerusalem? Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: "Savior of Israel." "Savior of Israel" - yes, "Builder of Jerusalem" - no? Rather say: Also "Savior of Israel."

hebrew_text: רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא אִיקְּלַע לְבֵי רֵישׁ גָּלוּתָא, פְּתַח בַּחֲדָא וְסַיֵּים בְּתַרְתֵּי. אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: גְּבוּרְתָּא לְמֶחְתַּם בְּתַרְתֵּי! וְהָתַנְיָא רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: אֵין חוֹתְמִין בִּשְׁתַּיִם!
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna happened to the house of the Exilarch. he opened with one and concluded with two Rav Ḥisda said great fortitude to conclude with two Wasn’t it taught Rabbi says: One may not conclude with two
llm_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna entered the house of Reish Galuta, he began with one topic and concluded with two. Rav Chisda said: "A seal is placed on two matters!" And it was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi says, "We do not seal with two matters!"

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: אֵין חוֹתְמִין בִּשְׁתַּיִם. אֵיתִיבֵיהּ לֵוִי לְרַבִּי, ״עַל הָאָרֶץ וְעַל הַמָּזוֹן״! — אֶרֶץ דְּמַפְּקָא מָזוֹן. ״עַל הָאָרֶץ וְעַל הַפֵּירוֹת״! — אֶרֶץ דְּמַפְּקָא פֵּירוֹת.
human_translation: the matter itself: Rabbi says: One may not conclude with two Levi, raised an objection to Rabbi For the land and for the food. The land that produces food. For the land and for the fruit. The land that produces fruit.
llm_translation: Body. Rabbi says: One does not seal with two. Levi raised an objection to Rabbi, "On the land and on the sustenance!" - Land from which sustenance emerges. "On the land and on the fruits!" - Land from which fruits emerge.

hebrew_text: ״מְקַדֵּשׁ יִשְׂרָאֵל וְהַזְּמַנִּים״! — יִשְׂרָאֵל דְּקַדְּשִׁינְהוּ לִזְמַנִּים. ״מְקַדֵּשׁ יִשְׂרָאֵל וְרָאשֵׁי חֳדָשִׁים״! — יִשְׂרָאֵל דְּקַדְּשִׁינְהוּ לְרָאשֵׁי חֳדָשִׁים.
human_translation: Who sanctifies Israel and the seasons. Who sanctifies Israel, who sanctify the seasons. Who sanctifies Israel and the New Moon. Who sanctifies Israel, who sanctify the New Moons.
llm_translation: "Sanctifying Israel and the appointed times!" - Israel sanctified them for the appointed times. "Sanctifying Israel and the heads of months!" - Israel sanctified them for the heads of months.

hebrew_text: ״מְקַדֵּשׁ הַשַּׁבָּת וְיִשְׂרָאֵל וְהַזְּמַנִּים״! — חוּץ מִזּוֹ.
human_translation: Who sanctifies Shabbat, Israel, and the seasons. Except for that
llm_translation: "Sanctifying the Sabbath and Israel and the appointed times!" — Except for this one.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא? הָכָא חֲדָא הִיא, הָתָם תַּרְתֵּי, כׇּל חֲדָא וַחֲדָא בְּאַפֵּי נַפְשָׁהּ.
human_translation: What is different Here, for one there, two each one is distinct
llm_translation: And what is the difference? Here it is one, there it is two, each one by itself.

hebrew_text: וְטַעְמָא מַאי אֵין חוֹתְמִין בִּשְׁתַּיִם? לְפִי שֶׁאֵין עוֹשִׂין מִצְוֹת חֲבִילוֹת חֲבִילוֹת.
human_translation: And what is the reason that one does not conclude with two Because One does not perform mitzvot in bundles;
llm_translation: The reason why we do not seal with two knots? Because they do not perform mitzvot in bundles.

hebrew_text: מַאי הָוֵי עֲלַהּ?
human_translation: What about it?
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "Alah"?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: פָּתַח בְּ״רַחֵם עַל עַמְּךָ יִשְׂרָאֵל״ — חוֹתֵם בְּמוֹשִׁיעַ יִשְׂרָאֵל. פָּתַח בְּ״רַחֵם עַל יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״ — חוֹתֵם בְּ״בוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״. וְרַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ פָּתַח בְּ״רַחֵם עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל״ — חוֹתֵם בְּ״בוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלָיִם״, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם ה׳ נִדְחֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל יְכַנֵּס״: אֵימָתַי בּוֹנֵה יְרוּשָׁלַיִם ה׳ — בִּזְמַן שֶׁנִּדְחֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל יְכַנֵּס.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said: he opened with: Have compassion on Your people, Israel, he concludes with: Who redeems Israel; he opened with: Have compassion on Jerusalem, he concludes with: Who builds Jerusalem. Rav Naḥman said: Even if he opened with: Have compassion on Israel, he concludes with: Who builds Jerusalem, because it is stated: “The Lord builds Jerusalem; He gathers in the exiles of Israel” When does God build Jerusalem? When He gathers in the exiles of Israel.
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: He who begins with "Have mercy upon Your people Israel" - concludes with "Who saves Israel." He who begins with "Have mercy upon Jerusalem" - concludes with "Who builds Jerusalem."
