llm_translation: There are those who say: Rav Huna said: They only taught that if one did not acquire and then acquired, he does not need to recite a blessing. But if he acquired and then acquired again, he does need to recite a blessing. And Rabbi Yochanan said: Even if he acquired, then acquired again, he must recite a blessing. From the fact that he has it and acquires it, this is the view of all that he must recite a blessing.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: בָּנָה בַּיִת חָדָשׁ וְאֵין לוֹ כַּיּוֹצֵא בּוֹ, קָנָה כֵּלִים חֲדָשִׁים וְאֵין לוֹ כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶם — צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ. יֵשׁ לוֹ כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶם — אֵין צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בֵּין כָּךְ וּבֵין כָּךְ צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ.
human_translation: raises an objection built a new house and does not own a similar or purchased new vessels and does not own similar must recite a blessing. he owns a similar he need not recite a blessing, the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda, says: In either case, he must recite a blessing.
llm_translation: Challenger: He built a new house and does not have its equivalent, he acquired new utensils and does not have their equivalent - he must bless. If he has their equivalent - he does not need to bless, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: Whether this or that, he must bless.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְלִישָּׁנָא קַמָּא — רַב הוּנָא כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. אֶלָּא לְלִישָּׁנָא בָּתְרָא, בִּשְׁלָמָא רַב הוּנָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, אֶלָּא רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמַר כְּמַאן? לָא כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר וְלָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: Granted, according to the first version Rav Huna in accordance with Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Yoḥanan in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda. However, according to the latter version granted, Rav Huna in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, but in accordance with whose did Rabbi Yoḥanan state is neither in accordance with Rabbi Meir nor in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: In truth, regarding the first matter - Rav Huna is like Rabbi Meir, and Rabbi Yochanan is like Rabbi Yehuda. However, regarding the latter matter, in truth, Rav Huna is like Rabbi Yehuda, but Rabbi Yochanan, who does he follow? Not like Rabbi Meir and not like Rabbi Yehuda!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הוּא הַדִּין דִּלְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה קָנָה וְחָזַר וְקָנָה — נָמֵי צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ. וְהָא דְּקָא מִיפַּלְגִי בְּיֵשׁ לוֹ וְקָנָה, לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחוֹ דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר דַּאֲפִילּוּ קָנָה וְיֵשׁ לוֹ — אֵין צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ, וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן קָנָה וְחָזַר וְקָנָה דְּאֵין צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said to you: The same is true according to Rabbi Yehuda’s one has purchased and purchased again, he must recite a blessing. that they disagreed with regard to where he owned and he purchased to convey the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Meir’s ; even one purchased while owning a he need not recite a blessing; all the more so he purchased and then purchased again, he need not recite a blessing.
llm_translation: He said to you, Rabbi Yochanan: The same applies to Rabbi Yehuda, if he acquired and then acquired again - he must recite a blessing. And that which he argues that if one has and acquires, to inform you of the strength of Rabbi Meir, that even if he acquires and has - he does not need to recite a blessing, and all the more so if he acquires and then acquires again, that he does not need to recite a blessing.

hebrew_text: וְלִיפַּלְגוּ בְּקָנָה וְחָזַר וְקָנָה דְּאֵין צָרִיךְ לְבָרֵךְ, לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחוֹ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה! כֹּחַ דְּהֶתֵּירָא עֲדִיף לֵיהּ.
human_translation: And let them disagree with regard to where one purchased and purchased again, one need not recite a blessing, in order to convey the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Yehuda’s the strength of leniency is preferable.
llm_translation: "And they divided in the reed, and he returned and acquired, and acquired, that one does not need to bless, to inform you of the strength of Rabbi Yehuda! The strength of one who is lenient is preferable."

hebrew_text: מְבָרֵךְ עַל הָרָעָה כּוּ׳.
human_translation: One recites a blessing for the bad
llm_translation: Blesses on the evil as well.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? כְּגוֹן דִּשְׁקַל בִּדְקָא בְּאַרְעֵיהּ, אַף עַל גַּב דְּטָבָא הִיא לְדִידֵיהּ, דְּמַסְּקָא אַרְעָא שִׂירְטוֹן וְשָׁבְחָא, הַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא רָעָה הִיא.
human_translation: What are the circumstances? In a case where a dam was breached onto one’s land, despite that this will be beneficial for him, for his land will be covered with sediment which will enhance it is bad at present.
llm_translation: "How are they similar? For example, if one were to take a jug of oil in his field, even though it is good for him, as it fertilizes the field and enhances its growth, now it is harmful to him."

hebrew_text: וְעַל הַטּוֹבָה כּוּ׳.
human_translation: for the good
llm_translation: And on the good, as it is said.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? כְּגוֹן דְּאַשְׁכַּח מְצִיאָה, אַף עַל גַּב דְּרָעָה הִיא לְדִידֵיהּ, דְּאִי שָׁמַע בַּהּ מַלְכָּא שָׁקֵיל לַהּ מִינֵּיהּ, הַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא טוֹבָה הִיא.
human_translation: What are the circumstances? In a case where one found a lost object, despite that it is bad for him if the king heard about it, he would take it from him. it is favorable at present.
llm_translation: "How are the circumstances? For example, if one finds an object, even though it is on his property, since if the king hears about it, he will take it from him, now it is good for him."

hebrew_text: הָיְתָה אִשְׁתּוֹ מְעוּבֶּרֶת וְאָמַר: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן שֶׁתֵּלֵד כּוּ׳״ — הֲרֵי זוֹ תְּפִלַּת שָׁוְא.
human_translation: One whose wife was pregnant and he said: May it be will that will give birth it is a vain prayer.
llm_translation: His wife was barren and he said: "May it be the will that she give birth." - This is a futile prayer.

hebrew_text: וְלָא מַהֲנֵי רַחֲמֵי? מֵתִיב רַב יוֹסֵף: ״וְאַחַר יָלְדָה בַּת וַתִּקְרָא אֶת שְׁמָהּ דִּינָה״: מַאי ״וְאַחַר״? אָמַר רַב: לְאַחַר שֶׁדָּנָה לֵאָה דִּין בְּעַצְמָהּ וְאָמְרָה: שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר שְׁבָטִים עֲתִידִין לָצֵאת מִיַּעֲקֹב, שִׁשָּׁה יָצְאוּ מִמֶּנִּי וְאַרְבָּעָה מִן הַשְּׁפָחוֹת, הֲרֵי עֲשָׂרָה. אִם זֶה זָכָר, לֹא תְּהֵא אֲחוֹתִי רָחֵל כְּאַחַת הַשְּׁפָחוֹת, מִיָּד נֶהֶפְכָה לְבַת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַתִּקְרָא אֶת שְׁמָהּ דִּינָה״. אֵין מַזְכִּירִין מַעֲשֵׂה נִסִּים.
human_translation: Is a prayer ineffective? Rav Yosef raises an objection “And afterwards she bore a daughter, and called her name Dina” What is Afterwards? Rav said: After Leah passed judgment on herself and said: Twelve tribes are destined to descend from Jacob, six came from me and four from the maidservants, that is ten, if this is male, my sister will not be of one the maidservants; immediately was transformed into a daughter, as it is stated: And she called her name Dina; One does not mention miraculous acts
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And not from the mercies? It was asked: Rav Yosef raises an objection: "And afterwards she bore a daughter and called her name Dinah." What is meant by "and afterwards"? Rav said: After Leah judged herself and said: "Twelve tribes are destined to come from Jacob, six have come from me and four from the maidservants, here are ten. If this one is a male, my sister Rachel will not be like one of the maidservants. Immediately she was transformed into a daughter, as it is stated: "And she called her name Dinah." Miracles are not mentioned.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: מַעֲשֶׂה דְּלֵאָה בְּתוֹךְ אַרְבָּעִים יוֹם הֲוָה. כִּדְתַנְיָא: שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים — יְבַקֵּשׁ אָדָם רַחֲמִים שֶׁלֹּא יַסְרִיחַ. מִשְּׁלֹשָׁה וְעַד אַרְבָּעִים יְבַקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים שֶׁיְּהֵא זָכָר. מֵאַרְבָּעִים יוֹם וְעַד שְׁלֹשָׁה חֳדָשִׁים — יְבַקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא סַנְדָּל. מִשְּׁלֹשָׁה חֳדָשִׁים וְעַד שִׁשָּׁה — יְבַקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא נֵפֶל. מִשִּׁשָּׁה וְעַד תִּשְׁעָה — יְבַקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים שֶׁיֵּצֵא בְּשָׁלוֹם.
human_translation: And if you wish, say story of Leah was within forty days As it was taught the first three days one should pray that not putrefy, From the third until the fortieth, one should pray that it will be male. From the fortieth until three months, one should pray that it will not be flat fish, From the third month until the sixth, one should pray that it will not be stillborn. from the sixth until the ninth, one should pray that it will be emerge safely.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: There was a case where it was within forty days. As it was taught: The first three days - a person should request mercy that it not putrefy. From three to forty days - one should request mercy that it be remembered. From forty days to three months - one should request mercy that it not become a sandal. From three months to six - one should request mercy that it not be a miscarriage. From six to nine - one should request mercy that it come out in peace.

hebrew_text: וּמִי מַהֲנֵי רַחֲמֵי? וְהָאָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אַמֵּי: אִישׁ מַזְרִיעַ תְּחִלָּה — יוֹלֶדֶת נְקֵבָה, אִשָּׁה מַזְרַעַת תְּחִלָּה — יוֹלֶדֶת זָכָר. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִשָּׁה כִּי תַזְרִיעַ וְיָלְדָה זָכָר״! הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — כְּגוֹן שֶׁהִזְרִיעוּ שְׁנֵיהֶם בְּבַת אַחַת.
human_translation: Is prayer effective Didn’t Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Ami, say: man emits seed first, gives birth to a female; woman emits seed first, she gives birth to a male, as it is stated: “When a woman emitted seed and bore a male” With what are we dealing here? with a case where they both emit seed simultaneously.
llm_translation: And who are the ones that have mercy? And Rav Yitzchak, son of Rav Ammi, said: A man who first sows - begets a female, a woman who first sows - begets a male. As it is said: "When a woman conceives and gives birth to a male child"! What are we dealing with here - for example, when they both sowed at the same time.

hebrew_text: הָיָה בָּא בַּדֶּרֶךְ.
human_translation: One who was walking along the way
llm_translation: He was coming on the way.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּהִלֵּל הַזָּקֵן שֶׁהָיָה בָּא בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְשָׁמַע קוֹל צְוָחָה בָּעִיר, אָמַר: מוּבְטָח אֲנִי שֶׁאֵין זֶה בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתִי. וְעָלָיו הַכָּתוּב אוֹמֵר: ״מִשְּׁמוּעָה רָעָה לֹא יִירָא נָכוֹן לִבּוֹ בָּטֻחַ בַּה׳״. אָמַר רָבָא: כׇּל הֵיכִי דְּדָרְשַׁתְּ לְהַאי קְרָא מֵרֵישֵׁיהּ לְסֵיפֵיהּ — מִדְּרִישׁ, מִסֵּיפֵיהּ לְרֵישֵׁיהּ — מִדְּרִישׁ: מֵרֵישֵׁיהּ לְסֵיפֵיהּ מִדְּרִישׁ — ״מִשְּׁמוּעָה רָעָה לֹא יִירָא״, מַה טַּעַם? — ״נָכוֹן לִבּוֹ בָּטֻחַ בַּה׳״. מִסֵּיפֵיהּ לְרֵישֵׁיהּ מִדְּרִישׁ — ״נָכוֹן לִבּוֹ בָּטֻחַ בַּה׳, מִשְּׁמוּעָה רָעָה לֹא יִירָא״.
human_translation: The Sages taught: There was an incident involving Hillel the Elder, who was coming on the road when he heard a scream in the city. He said: I am certain that is not from my house. And of him, the verse says: “He shall not be afraid of evil tidings; his heart is steadfast, trusting in the Lord” Rava said: Any way that you interpret this verse, It interpreted from beginning to end it interpreted from end to beginning. It interpreted from beginning to end: Why is it that: He shall not be afraid of evil tidings? his heart is steadfast, trusting in the Lord. And it interpreted from end to beginning: heart is steadfast, trusting in the Lord shall not be afraid of evil tidings.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: There was an incident involving Hillel the Elder who was traveling on the road and heard a cry in the city. He said: "I am confident that this is not inside my house." And the verse says about him: "He shall not fear bad news; his heart is steadfast, trusting in the Lord." Rava said: In every way that you interpret this verse from the beginning to the end - from the end to the beginning, he interprets: from the beginning to the end - "He shall not fear bad news," what is the reason? - "His heart is steadfast, trusting in the Lord." From the end to the beginning he interprets: "His heart is steadfast, trusting in the Lord, he shall not fear bad news."

hebrew_text: הַהוּא תַּלְמִידָא דַּהֲוָה קָא אָזֵיל בָּתְרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּשׁוּקָא דְצִיּוֹן. חַזְיֵיהּ דְּקָא מְפַחֵיד. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: חַטָּאָה אַתְּ, דִּכְתִיב: ״פָּחֲדוּ בְצִיּוֹן חֲטָאִים״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְהָכְתִיב ״אַשְׁרֵי אָדָם מְפַחֵד תָּמִיד״! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הַהוּא בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה כְּתִיב.
human_translation: This student was once walking after Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, in the marketplace of Zion. saw that was afraid. He said to him: You are a sinner, as it is written: “The transgressors in Zion are afraid, replied: And is it not written: “Happy is the man that fears always” said to him: That is written with regard to matters of Torah,
llm_translation: That disciple who was walking behind Rabbi Yishmael, the son of Rabbi Yose, in the marketplace of Tzion, saw that he was trembling. He said to him: "You have sinned, as it is written: 'The sinners in Tzion are afraid.'" He said to him: "But it is also written: 'Happy is the man who is always afraid!'" He said to him: "That is written concerning matters of Torah."

hebrew_text: יְהוּדָה בַּר נָתָן הֲוָה שָׁקֵיל וְאָזֵיל בָּתְרֵיהּ דְּרַב הַמְנוּנָא. אִתְּנַח. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: יִסּוּרִים בָּעֵי הַהוּא גַּבְרָא לְאֵתוּיֵי אַנַּפְשֵׁיהּ? דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי פַחַד פָּחַדְתִּי וַיֶּאֱתָיֵנִי וַאֲשֶׁר יָגֹרְתִּי יָבֹא לִי״! וְהָא כְּתִיב: ״אַשְׁרֵי אָדָם מְפַחֵד תָּמִיד״! הָהוּא בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה כְּתִיב.
human_translation: Yehuda bar Natan was coming and going after Rav Hamnuna. sighed; said to him: Do you wish to bring suffering upon yourself; as it is stated: “For that which I did fear is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of has overtaken me” Is it not said: “Happy is the man who fears always”? That is written with regard to matters of Torah.
llm_translation: Judah bar Nathan was walking and going after Rav Hamnuna. He caught up with him. He said to him: Does that man need afflictions to come upon himself? As it is written: "For I feared a fear, and it came upon me, and what I dreaded came to me!" But isn't it also written: "Happy is the man who is always fearful"? That is written concerning matters of Torah.

hebrew_text: הַנִּכְנָס לִכְרַךְ.
human_translation: We learned One who enters a large city
llm_translation: He who enters to read.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: בִּכְנִיסָתוֹ מַהוּ אוֹמֵר? — ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי שֶׁתַּכְנִיסֵנִי לִכְרַךְ זֶה לְשָׁלוֹם״. נִכְנַס, אוֹמֵר: ״מוֹדֶה אֲנִי לְפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי שֶׁהִכְנַסְתַּנִי לִכְרַךְ זֶה לְשָׁלוֹם״. בִּקֵּשׁ לָצֵאת, אוֹמֵר: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי וֵאלֹהֵי אֲבוֹתַי, שֶׁתּוֹצִיאֵנִי מִכְּרַךְ זֶה לְשָׁלוֹם״. יָצָא, אוֹמֵר: ״מוֹדֶה אֲנִי לְפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי שֶׁהוֹצֵאתַנִי מִכְּרַךְ זֶה לְשָׁלוֹם. וּכְשֵׁם שֶׁהוֹצֵאתַנִי לְשָׁלוֹם, כָּךְ תּוֹלִיכֵנִי לְשָׁלוֹם, וְתִסְמְכֵנִי לְשָׁלוֹם, וְתַצְעִידֵנִי לְשָׁלוֹם, וְתַצִּילֵנִי מִכַּף כׇּל אוֹיֵב וְאוֹרֵב בַּדֶּרֶךְ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught Upon his entrance what does he recite? May it be Your will, O Lord my God, that You bring me into this city to peace. he entered he recites: I thank You, O Lord my God that You brought me into this city to peace. seeks to leave he recites: May it be Your will, O Lord my God and God of my ancestors, that You take me out of this city to peace. he left, he recites: I give thanks before You, O Lord my God, that You took me out of this city to peace; and just as You took me out to peace, so too lead me to peace, support me to peace, direct my steps to peace, and rescue me from the hand of any enemy or lying in ambush along the way.
llm_translation: The sages taught: Upon entering, what does one say? "May it be Your will, Lord my God, that You bring me into this study hall in peace." Upon entering, one says: "I give thanks before You, Lord my God, for You have brought me into this study hall in peace." When one wishes to leave, one says: "May it be Your will, Lord my God and God of my ancestors, that You take me out from this study hall in peace." Upon leaving, one says: "I give thanks before You, Lord my God, for You have taken me out from this study hall in peace. And just as You have taken me out in peace, so may You lead me in peace, support me in peace, guide me in peace, and save me from the hand of every enemy and ambush on the way."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב מַתְנָא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בִּכְרַךְ שֶׁאֵין דָּנִין וְהוֹרְגִין בּוֹ, אֲבָל בִּכְרַךְ שֶׁדָּנִין וְהוֹרְגִין בּוֹ — לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Mattana said: This was taught only with regard to a city where are not tried and executed, However, in a city where are tried and executed, do not apply,
llm_translation: Rav Matna said: They only taught this regarding a "kerach" where one does not judge and execute, but in a "kerach" where they do judge and execute - we do not have it.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַב מַתְנָא: אֲפִילּוּ בִּכְרַךְ שֶׁדָּנִין וְהוֹרְגִין בּוֹ, זִימְנִין דְּלָא מִתְרְמֵי לֵיהּ אִינָשׁ דְּיָלֵיף לֵיהּ זְכוּתָא.
human_translation: Some say Rav Mattana said Even in a city where are tried and executed as sometimes he may not encounter a person who will plead in his favor.
llm_translation: There are those who say, Rav Matna said: Even in a city where they judge and execute by the sword, there are times when a person who is not deserving of it is killed unjustly.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַנִּכְנָס לְבֵית הַמֶּרְחָץ, אוֹמֵר: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי שֶׁתַּצִּילֵנִי מִזֶּה וְכַיּוֹצֵא בּוֹ, וְאַל יֶאֱרַע בִּי דְּבַר קַלְקָלָה וְעָוֹן. וְאִם יֶאֱרַע בִּי דְּבַר קַלְקָלָה וְעָוֹן — תְּהֵא מִיתָתִי כַּפָּרָה לְכׇל עֲוֹנוֹתַי״.
human_translation: The Sages taught: One who enters a bathhouse, says: May it be Your will, O Lord my God, that you save me from this and similar and do not let ruin or iniquity befall me, and if ruin or iniquity does befall me, let my death be atonement for all of my transgressions.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One who enters the bathhouse should say: "May it be Your will, Lord my God, that You save me from this and similar situations, and may no harm or transgression occur to me. But if harm or transgression does occur to me, may my death serve as atonement for all my sins."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לָא לֵימָא אִינָשׁ הָכִי, דְּלָא לִפְתַּח פּוּמֵּיהּ לְשָׂטָן. דְּאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, וְכֵן תָּנָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵי: לְעוֹלָם אַל יִפְתַּח אָדָם פִּיו לַשָּׂטָן.
human_translation: Abaye said: One should not say: so as not to open his mouth to Satan As Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said and as it was taught in the name of Rabbi Yosei: One should never open his mouth to Satan
llm_translation: Abaye said: A person should not speak in this manner, so as not to open his mouth to the Satan. As Reish Lakish said, and similarly it was taught in the name of Rav Yosei: A person should never open his mouth to the Satan.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מַאי קְרָאָה — דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּמְעָט כִּסְדֹם הָיִינוּ לַעֲמֹרָה דָּמִינוּ״, מַאי אַהְדַּר לְהוּ נָבִיא — ״שִׁמְעוּ דְּבַר ה׳ קְצִינֵי סְדֹם וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: What is the verse As it is written: “We should have almost been as Sodom, we should have been like unto Gomorrah” what did reply to them? “Hear the word of the Lord, rulers of Sodom;
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: What is the verse referring to? As it is written: "We were like Sodom, we resembled Gomorrah." How did the prophet rebuke them? "Hear the word of the Lord, rulers of Sodom, etc."

hebrew_text: כִּי נָפֵיק מַאי אוֹמֵר? אָמַר רַב אַחָא: ״מוֹדֶה אֲנִי לְפָנֶיךָ ה׳ שֶׁהִצַּלְתַּנִי מִן הָאוּר״.
human_translation: When he emerges what does he say? Rav Aḥa said: I give thanks to You, Lord, that You saved me from the fire.
llm_translation: When what does he say? Rav Acha said: "I acknowledge before You, Hashem, that You have saved me from the fire."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ עָל לְבֵי בָנֵי. אִפְּחִית בֵּי בָנֵי מִתּוּתֵיהּ, אִתְרְחִישׁ לֵיהּ נִיסָּא קָם עַל עַמּוּדָא, שֵׁזִיב מְאָה וְחַד גַּבְרֵי בְּחַד אֵבְרֵיהּ. אֲמַר: הַיְינוּ דְּרַב אַחָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu entered a bathhouse when the bathhouse collapsed beneath him and a miracle transpired on his behalf. He stood on a pillar and saved one hundred and one men with one arm. He said: This is of Rav Aḥa,
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu went to the house of the sons. He knocked on the door of the sons, they opened for him a miracle happened, a pillar rose up, on it sat one hundred and one men with one of their limbs. He said: "This is like what Rav Acha said."

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַב אַחָא: הַנִּכְנָס לְהַקִּיז דָּם, אוֹמֵר: ״יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי שֶׁיְּהֵא עֵסֶק זֶה לִי לִרְפוּאָה, וּתְרַפְּאֵנִי. כִּי אֵל רוֹפֵא נֶאֱמָן אָתָּה וּרְפוּאָתְךָ אֱמֶת, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין דַּרְכָּן שֶׁל בְּנֵי אָדָם לְרַפּאוֹת אֶלָּא שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ״.
human_translation: As Rav Aḥa said: One who enters to let blood says: May it be Your will, O Lord my God, that this enterprise be for healing and that You should heal me. As You are a faithful God of healing and Your healing is truth. Because it is not the way of people to heal, but they have become accustomed.
llm_translation: As Rav Acha said: One who enters to let blood, he says: "May it be Your will, Lord my God, that this act be for healing for me, and heal me. For You are a faithful healer and Your healing is true, for it is not the way of humans to heal, only that which is customary."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לָא לֵימָא אִינָשׁ הָכִי, דְּתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״וְרַפֹּא יְרַפֵּא״ — מִכָּאן שֶׁנִּיתְּנָה רְשׁוּת לָרוֹפֵא לְרַפּאוֹת.
human_translation: Abaye said: One should not say this, as taught the school of Rabbi Yishmael “And shall cause him to be thoroughly healed” from here that permission is granted to a doctor to heal.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Do not say it like this, as it was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: "And he shall surely heal" — from here it was given permission to the healer to heal.

hebrew_text: כִּי קָאֵי מַאי אוֹמֵר? — אָמַר רַב אַחָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … רוֹפֵא חִנָּם״.
human_translation: When one stands what does he say? Rav Aḥa said: Blessed…Who heals without payment.
llm_translation: When it stands, what does it say? — Rav Acha said: "Blessed is... who heals for free."

hebrew_text: הַנִּכְנָס לְבֵית הַכִּסֵּא, אוֹמֵר: ״הִתְכַּבְּדוּ מְכוּבָּדִים קְדוֹשִׁים מְשָׁרְתֵי עֶלְיוֹן, תְּנוּ כָּבוֹד לֵאלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, הַרְפּוּ מִמֶּנִּי עַד שֶׁאֶכָּנֵס וְאֶעֱשֶׂה רְצוֹנִי וְאָבֹא אֲלֵיכֶם״. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לָא לֵימָא אִינָשׁ הָכִי, דִּלְמָא שָׁבְקִי לֵיהּ וְאָזְלִי. אֶלָּא לֵימָא: ״שִׁמְרוּנִי שִׁמְרוּנִי, עִזְרוּנִי עִזְרוּנִי, סִמְכוּנִי סִמְכוּנִי, הַמְתִּינוּ לִי הַמְתִּינוּ לִי עַד שֶׁאֶכָּנֵס וְאֵצֵא, שֶׁכֵּן דַּרְכָּן שֶׁל בְּנֵי אָדָם״. כִּי נָפֵיק, אוֹמֵר: ״בָּרוּךְ. אֲשֶׁר יָצַר אֶת הָאָדָם בְּחׇכְמָה, וּבָרָא בּוֹ נְקָבִים נְקָבִים, חֲלָלִים חֲלָלִים, גָּלוּי וְיָדוּעַ לִפְנֵי כִּסֵּא כְּבוֹדֶךָ שֶׁאִם יִפָּתֵחַ אֶחָד מֵהֶם אוֹ אִם יִסָּתֵם אֶחָד מֵהֶם אִי אֶפְשָׁר לַעֲמוֹד לְפָנֶיךָ״.
human_translation: One who enters a bathroom says Be honored, honorable holy ones, servants of on High, give honor to the God of Israel, leave me until I enter and do my will and come to you. Abaye said: A person should not say this, lest they abandon him and go. Rather he should say: Guard me, guard me, help me, help me, support me, support me, wait for me, wait for me until I enter and come out, as this is the way of man. Upon exiting, one says: Blessed…Who formed man in wisdom, and created in him many orifices and cavities. It is revealed and known before the throne of Your glory that were one of them to be ruptured or blocked, it would be impossible to survive and stand before You.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If one enters the bathroom, he should say: "Honored and holy ones, servants of the Most High, give honor to the God of Israel, depart from me until I enter and fulfill my will and come to you." Abaye said: A person should not say this, for perhaps he will leave it and then go. Rather, he should say: "Guard me, guard me, help me, help me, support me, support me, wait for me, wait for me until I enter and leave, for such is the way of people." When he exits, he should say: "Blessed is He who formed man with wisdom and created within him many openings, many cavities, many ducts, revealed and known before Your glorious throne, that if one of them were to be opened or one of them were to be closed, it would be impossible to stand before You."

hebrew_text: מַאי חָתֵים? אָמַר רַב: ״רוֹפֵא חוֹלִים״. אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: קָא שַׁוִּינְהוּ אַבָּא לְכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא קְצִירֵי. אֶלָּא: ״רוֹפֵא כׇל בָּשָׂר״. רַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: ״מַפְלִיא לַעֲשׂוֹת״. אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הִלְכָּךְ נֵמְרִינְהוּ לְתַרְוַיְיהוּ — ״רוֹפֵא כׇל בָּשָׂר וּמַפְלִיא לַעֲשׂוֹת״.
human_translation: what conclude Rav said: Healer of the sick. Shmuel said: Abba, has rendered everyone sick. Rather, Healer of all flesh. Rav Sheshet said: Who performs wondrous deeds. Rav Pappa said: Therefore, let us say them both: Healer of all flesh, Who performs wondrous deeds.
llm_translation: What is "Chateem"? Rav said: "Healer of the sick." Shmuel said: Abba compared him to all the people of the world. Rather: "Healer of all flesh." Rav Sheshet said: "Performing wonders." Rav Papa said: Therefore, we conclude regarding them both - "Healer of all flesh and performing wonders."

hebrew_text: הַנִּכְנָס לִישַׁן עַל מִטָּתוֹ, אוֹמֵר מִ״שְּׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל״ עַד ״וְהָיָה אִם שָׁמוֹעַ״, וְאוֹמֵר: ״בָּרוּךְ … הַמַּפִּיל חַבְלֵי שֵׁינָה עַל עֵינַי וּתְנוּמָה עַל עַפְעַפַּי, וּמֵאִיר לְאִישׁוֹן בַּת עָיִן. יְהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי, שֶׁתַּשְׁכִּיבֵנִי לְשָׁלוֹם, וְתֵן חֶלְקִי בְּתוֹרָתֶךָ, וְתַרְגִּילֵנִי לִידֵי מִצְוָה, וְאַל תַּרְגִּילֵנִי לִידֵי עֲבֵירָה, וְאַל תְּבִיאֵנִי לִידֵי חֵטְא, וְלֹא לִידֵי עָוֹן, וְלֹא לִידֵי נִסָּיוֹן, וְלֹא לִידֵי בִזָּיוֹן. וְיִשְׁלוֹט בִּי יֵצֶר טוֹב, וְאַל יִשְׁלוֹט בִּי יֵצֶר הָרָע. וְתַצִּילֵנִי מִפֶּגַע רַע, וּמֵחֳלָאִים רָעִים. וְאַל יְבַהֲלוּנִי חֲלוֹמוֹת רָעִים וְהִרְהוּרִים רָעִים. וּתְהֵא מִטָּתִי שְׁלֵמָה לְפָנֶיךָ. וְהָאֵר עֵינַי פֶּן אִישַׁן הַמָּוֶת. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה ה׳ הַמֵּאִיר לָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ בִּכְבוֹדוֹ״.
human_translation: One who enters to sleep on his bed recites from Shema Yisrael to VeHaya Im Shamoa . Then he recites: Blessed…Who makes the bands of sleep fall upon my eyes and slumber upon my eyelids, and illuminates the pupil of the eye. May it be Your will, O Lord my God, that You make me lie down in peace and give me my portion in Your Torah, accustom me to mitzvot and do not accustom me to transgression, lead me not into error, nor into iniquity, nor into temptation nor into disgrace. May the good inclination have dominion over me and may the evil inclination not have dominion over me. Save me from an evil mishap and evil diseases. Let neither bad dreams nor troubling thoughts disturb me. May my bed be flawless before You, Enlighten my eyes lest I sleep death, Blessed are You, O Lord, Who gives light to the whole world in His glory.
llm_translation: The one who enters to sleep on his bed, says "Hear, O Israel" until "And it shall come to pass, if you shall hearken," and says: "Blessed is He who... who causes cords of sleep to fall upon my eyes and slumber upon my eyelids, and illuminates the sleep of the eye. May it be Your will, Lord my God, that You lay me down in peace, and place my portion in Your Torah, and accustom me to the performance of mitzvot, and do not accustom me to transgression, and do not bring me into the hands of sin, nor into iniquity, nor into trial, nor into disgrace. And let the good inclination rule over me, and let not the evil inclination rule over me. And save me from evil mishap, and from evil illnesses. And let not bad dreams and evil thoughts hasten me. And may my bed be complete before You. And enlighten my eyes lest I sleep the sleep of death. Blessed are You, Lord, who illuminates the entire world with His glory."

hebrew_text: כִּי מִתְּעַר אוֹמֵר: ״אֱלֹהַי, נְשָׁמָה שֶׁנָּתַתָּ בִּי טְהוֹרָה. אַתָּה יְצַרְתָּהּ בִּי, אַתָּה נְפַחְתָּהּ בִּי, וְאַתָּה מְשַׁמְּרָהּ בְּקִרְבִּי, וְאַתָּה עָתִיד לִיטְּלָהּ מִמֶּנִּי וּלְהַחֲזִירָהּ בִּי לְעָתִיד לָבֹא. כׇּל זְמַן שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה בְּקִרְבִּי מוֹדֶה אֲנִי לְפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי וֵאלֹהֵי אֲבוֹתַי, רִבּוֹן כׇּל הָעוֹלָמִים, אֲדוֹן כׇּל הַנְּשָׁמוֹת. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה ה׳, הַמַּחֲזִיר נְשָׁמוֹת לִפְגָרִים מֵתִים״.
human_translation: When one awakens, he recites: My God, the soul You have placed within me is pure. You formed it within me, You breathed it into me, and You guard it while it is within me. One day You will take it from me and restore it within me in the time to come. As long as the soul is within me, I thank You, O Lord my God and God of my ancestors, Master of all worlds, Lord of all souls. Blessed are You, O Lord, who restores souls to lifeless bodies.
llm_translation: When one wakes up, he says: "My God, the soul that You have placed within me is pure. You formed it within me, You breathed it into me, and You safeguard it within me. And You will eventually take it from me, and restore it to me in the future to come. As long as the soul is within me, I give thanks before You, Lord my God and God of my ancestors, Master of all worlds, Sovereign of all souls. Blessed are You, Lord, who restores souls to lifeless bodies."

hebrew_text: כִּי שָׁמַע קוֹל תַּרְנְגוֹלָא, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … אֲשֶׁר נָתַן לַשֶּׂכְוִי בִּינָה לְהַבְחִין בֵּין יוֹם וּבֵין לָיְלָה״. כִּי פָּתַח עֵינֵיהּ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … פּוֹקֵחַ עִוְּרִים״. כִּי תָּרֵיץ וְיָתֵיב, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … מַתִּיר אֲסוּרִים״. כִּי לָבֵישׁ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … מַלְבִּישׁ עֲרוּמִּים״. כִּי זָקֵיף, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … זוֹקֵף כְּפוּפִים״. כִּי נָחֵית לְאַרְעָא, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … רוֹקַע הָאָרֶץ עַל הַמָּיִם״. כִּי מְסַגֵּי, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … הַמֵּכִין מִצְעֲדֵי גָבֶר״. כִּי סַיֵּים מְסָאנֵיהּ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … שֶׁעָשָׂה לִי כׇּל צׇרְכִּי״. כִּי אָסַר הֶמְיָינֵיהּ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … אוֹזֵר יִשְׂרָאֵל בִּגְבוּרָה״. כִּי פָּרֵיס סוּדָרָא עַל רֵישֵׁיהּ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … עוֹטֵר יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּתִפְאָרָה״.
human_translation: Upon hearing the sound of the rooster, one should recite: Blessed…Who gave the heart [ sekhvi ] understanding to distinguish between day and night. Upon opening his eyes, one should recite: Blessed…Who gives sight to the blind. Upon sitting up straight, one should recite: Blessed…Who sets captives free. Upon dressing, one should recite: Blessed…Who clothes the naked, Upon standing up straight, one should recite: Blessed…Who raises those bowed down. Upon descending to the ground, one should recite: Blessed…Who spreads the earth above the waters, Upon walking, one should recite: Blessed…Who makes firm the steps of man. Upon putting on his shoes, one should recite: Blessed…Who has provided me with all I need, Upon putting on his belt, one should recite: Blessed…Who girds Israel with strength. Upon spreading a shawl upon his head, one should recite: Blessed…Who crowns Israel with glory.
llm_translation: When one hears the voice of the rooster, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who gave the rooster understanding to distinguish between day and night." When one opens his eyes, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who opens the eyes of the blind." When one stretches and sits up, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who releases the bound." When one dresses, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who clothes the naked." When one stands upright, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who straightens the bent." When one descends to the ground, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who spreads the earth upon the waters." When one completes his steps, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who establishes the steps of man." When one removes his garments, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who has provided me with all my needs." When one ties his belt, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who girds Israel with strength." When one places a head covering on his head, let him say: "Blessed is He ... who crowns Israel with glory."

hebrew_text: כִּי מִעֲטַף בְּצִיצִית, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … אֲשֶׁר קִדְּשָׁנוּ בְּמִצְוֹתָיו וְצִוָּנוּ לְהִתְעַטֵּף בְּצִיצִית״. כִּי מַנַּח תְּפִילִּין אַדְּרָעֵיהּ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … אֲשֶׁר קִדְּשָׁנוּ בְּמִצְוֹתָיו וְצִוָּנוּ לְהַנִּיחַ תְּפִילִּין״, אַרֵישֵׁיהּ, לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … אֲשֶׁר קִדְּשָׁנוּ בְּמִצְוֹתָיו וְצִוָּנוּ עַל מִצְוַת תְּפִילִּין״. כִּי מָשֵׁי יְדֵיהּ ,לֵימָא: ״בָּרוּךְ … אֲשֶׁר קִדְּשָׁנוּ בְּמִצְוֹתָיו וְצִוָּנוּ עַל נְטִילַת יָדַיִם״. כִּי מָשֵׁי אַפֵּיהּ, לֵימָא: בָּרוּךְ … הַמַּעֲבִיר חֶבְלֵי שֵׁינָה מֵעֵינָי וּתְנוּמָה מֵעַפְעַפָּי. וִיהִי רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנֶיךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהַי, שֶׁתַּרְגִּילֵנִי בְּתוֹרָתֶךָ, וְדַבְּקֵנִי בְּמִצְוֹתֶיךָ, וְאַל תְּבִיאֵנִי לֹא לִידֵי חֵטְא, וְלֹא לִידֵי עָוֹן, וְלֹא לִידֵי נִסָּיוֹן, וְלֹא לִידֵי בִזָּיוֹן. וְכוֹף אֶת יִצְרִי לְהִשְׁתַּעְבֵּד לָךְ. וְרַחֲקֵנִי מֵאָדָם רָע, וּמֵחָבֵר רָע. וְדַבְּקֵנִי בְּיֵצֶר טוֹב וּבְחָבֵר טוֹב בְּעוֹלָמֶךָ. וּתְנֵנִי הַיּוֹם וּבְכׇל יוֹם לְחֵן וּלְחֶסֶד וּלְרַחֲמִים בְּעֵינֶיךָ וּבְעֵינֵי כׇּל רוֹאַי, וְתִגְמְלֵנִי חֲסָדִים טוֹבִים. בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה ה׳ גּוֹמֵל חֲסָדִים טוֹבִים לְעַמּוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
human_translation: Upon wrapping himself in ritual fringes, one should recite: Blessed…Who has made us holy through His commandments and has commanded us to wrap ourselves in ritual fringes. Upon donning his phylacteries on his arm, one should recite: Blessed…Who has made us holy through His commandments and has commanded us to don phylacteries. on his head one should recite: Blessed…Who has made us holy through His commandments and has commanded us with regard to the mitzva of phylacteries. Upon washing his hands: Blessed…Who has made us holy through His commandments and has commanded us with regard to the washing of the hands. Upon washing his face, one recites: Blessed…Who removes the bands of sleep from my eyes and slumber from my eyelids. And may it be Your will, O Lord my God, to accustom me in Your Torah, attach me to Your mitzvot, and lead me not into transgression, nor into error, nor into iniquity, nor into temptation nor into disgrace. Bend my inclination to be subservient to You, and distance me from an evil person and an evil acquaintance. Help me attach myself to the good inclination and to a good friend in Your world. Grant me, today and every day, grace, loving-kindness, and compassion in Your eyes and the eyes of all who see me, and bestow loving-kindness upon me. Blessed are You, O Lord, Who bestows loving-kindness on His people, Israel.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: When one wraps oneself in tzitzit, let him say: "Blessed... Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us to wrap ourselves in tzitzit." When one places tefillin on his arm, let him say: "Blessed... Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us to lay tefillin." At the beginning of the head, let him say: "Blessed... Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us regarding the mitzvah of tefillin." When one washes his hands, let him say: "Blessed... Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us regarding the washing of hands." When one wipes his eyes, let him say: "Blessed... Who removes the bonds of sleep from my eyes and drowsiness from my eyelids. May it be Your will, Lord my God, to accustom me to Your Torah, and attach me to Your commandments, and do not bring me into the hands of sin, nor into the hands of iniquity, nor into the hands of trial, nor into the hands of disgrace. Subdue my inclination to serve You. Distance me from an evil person, and from an evil companion. Attach me to a good inclination and to a good companion in Your world. Grant me grace, kindness, and mercy in Your eyes and in the eyes of all who see me, and bestow upon me good kindness. Blessed are You, Lord, who bestows good kindness upon His people Israel." English translation:

hebrew_text: חַיָּיב אָדָם לְבָרֵךְ כּוּ׳: מַאי ״חַיָּיב לְבָרֵךְ עַל הָרָעָה כְּשֵׁם שֶׁמְּבָרֵךְ עַל הַטּוֹבָה״? אִילֵּימָא כְּשֵׁם שֶׁמְּבָרֵךְ עַל הַטּוֹבָה ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״, כָּךְ מְבָרֵךְ עַל הָרָעָה ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״, וְהָתְנַן עַל בְּשׂוֹרוֹת טוֹבוֹת אוֹמֵר ״הַטּוֹב וְהַמֵּטִיב״, עַל בְּשׂוֹרוֹת רָעוֹת אוֹמֵר ״בָּרוּךְ … דַּיַּין הָאֱמֶת״! אָמַר רָבָא: לֹא נִצְרְכָה, אֶלָּא לְקַבּוֹלִינְהוּ בְּשִׂמְחָה.
human_translation: One is obligated to recite a blessing What One is obligated to recite a blessing for the bad just as for the good? If we say just as one recites a blessing for a positive event Who is good and does good, so too one recites a blessing for a calamity Who is good and does good, didn’t we learn over good tidings one recites: Who is good and does good, over bad tidings one recites: Blessed…the true Judge? Rava said: was only necessary to accept with joy
llm_translation: A person is obligated to bless as follows: What is "obligated to bless for the bad just as one blesses for the good"? If you say just as one blesses for the good "He is good and does good," so too one blesses for the bad "He is good and does good." And we learned in a Mishnah: For good tidings one says "He is good and does good," for bad tidings one says "Blessed is the true Judge!" Rava said: It is not necessary, rather to accept them with joy.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַחָא מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי לֵוִי: מַאי קְרָא — ״חֶסֶד וּמִשְׁפָּט אָשִׁירָה לְךָ ה׳ אֲזַמֵּרָה״. אִם חֶסֶד — אָשִׁירָה, וְאִם מִשְׁפָּט — אָשִׁירָה.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa said in the name of Rabbi Levi: What verse “I will sing of loving-kindness and justice; unto You, O Lord, will I sing praises” If loving-kindness, I will sing, and if justice, I will sing.
llm_translation: Rav Ahah said in the name of Rabbi Levi: What is the verse — "Kindness and justice I will sing to You, O Lord, I will make music." If kindness — I will sing, and if justice — I will sing.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר, מֵהָכָא: ״בַּה׳ אֲהַלֵּל דָּבָר בֵּאלֹהִים אֲהַלֵּל דָּבָר״. בַּה׳ אֲהַלֵּל דָּבָר — זוֹ מִדָּה טוֹבָה, בֵּאלֹהִים אֲהַלֵּל דָּבָר — זוֹ מִדַּת פּוּרְעָנוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said: from here, “In God, I will praise His word; in the Lord, I will praise His word” In God, I will praise His word; that is attribute of benevolence, In the Lord, I will praise His word; that is the attribute of suffering;
llm_translation: Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said, from here: "In God I will praise a word, in God I will praise a word." "In God I will praise a word" - this is a measure of goodness, "in God I will praise a word" - this is a measure of punishment.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי תַּנְחוּם אָמַר: מֵהָכָא: ״כּוֹס יְשׁוּעוֹת אֶשָּׂא וּבְשֵׁם ה׳ אֶקְרָא״, ״צָרָה וְיָגוֹן אֶמְצָא וּבְשֵׁם ה׳ אֶקְרָא״.
human_translation: Rabbi Tanḥum said: from here, “I will lift up the cup of salvation and call upon the name of the Lord” “I found trouble and sorrow, but I called upon the name of the Lord”
llm_translation: Rabbi Tanhum said: From here: "I will lift up the cup of salvation and call upon the name of the Lord," "I find distress and sorrow and call upon the name of the Lord."

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן אָמְרִי, מֵהָכָא: ״ה׳ נָתָן וַה׳ לָקָח יְהִי שֵׁם ה׳ מְבֹרָךְ״.
human_translation: And the Rabbis said: from here, “The Lord has given and the Lord has taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord”
llm_translation: The Sages said, from here: "The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר, וְכֵן תָּנָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: לְעוֹלָם יְהֵא אָדָם רָגִיל לוֹמַר: ״כׇּל דְּעָבֵיד רַחֲמָנָא לְטָב עָבֵיד״.
human_translation: Rav Huna said Rav said Rabbi Meir said; and so it was taught in the name of Rabbi Akiva: One must always accustom oneself to say: Everything that God does, He does for the best.
llm_translation: Rav Huna said in the name of Rav Meir, and similarly it was taught in the name of Rabbi Akiva: A person should always accustom himself to say, "Everything that the Merciful One does, He does for the good."

hebrew_text: כִּי הָא דְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא דַּהֲוָה קָאָזֵיל בְּאוֹרְחָא. מְטָא לְהַהִיא מָתָא, בְּעָא אוּשְׁפִּיזָא לָא יָהֲבִי לֵיהּ. אֲמַר: ״כׇּל דְּעָבֵיד רַחֲמָנָא — לְטָב״. אֲזַל וּבָת בְּדַבְרָא, וַהֲוָה בַּהֲדֵיהּ תַּרְנְגוֹלָא וַחֲמָרָא וּשְׁרָגָא. אֲתָא זִיקָא כַּבְיֵיהּ לִשְׁרָגָא. אֲתָא שׁוּנָּרָא אַכְלֵיהּ לְתַרְנְגוֹלָא. אֲתָא אַרְיָה אַכְלֵיהּ לַחֲמָרָא. אֲמַר: ״כׇּל דְּעָבֵיד רַחֲמָנָא — לְטָב״. בֵּיהּ בְּלֵילְיָא אֲתָא גְּיָיסָא, שַׁבְיַיהּ לְמָתָא. אֲמַר לְהוּ: לָאו אֲמַרִי לְכוּ כׇּל מַה שֶּׁעוֹשֶׂה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא
human_translation: Like this when Rabbi Akiva was walking along the road and came to a certain city, he inquired about lodging and they did not give him He said: Everything that God does, He does for the best. He went and slept in a field, and he had with him a rooster, a donkey and a candle. A wind came and extinguished the candle; a cat came and ate the rooster; and a lion came and ate the donkey. He said: Everything that God does, He does for the best. That night, an army came and took the city into captivity. He said to them: Didn’t I tell you? Everything that God does,
llm_translation: The one of Rabbi Akiva who was walking on the road. He came to that city, he asked for a place to stay, they did not give him. He said: "All that the Merciful One does, He does for good." He went and stayed in the field, there was with him a rooster, a donkey, and a candle. A gust of wind came and blew out the candle. A cat came and ate the rooster. A lion came and ate the donkey. He said: "All that the Merciful One does, He does for good." That night a legion came, captured the city. He said to them: Did I not tell you, all that the Holy One, blessed be He, does...

hebrew_text: הַכֹּל לְטוֹבָה.
human_translation: He does for the best.
llm_translation: All for good.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר: לְעוֹלָם יִהְיוּ דְּבָרָיו שֶׁל אָדָם מוּעָטִין לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אַל תְּבַהֵל עַל פִּיךָ וְלִבְּךָ אַל יְמַהֵר לְהוֹצִיא דָבָר לִפְנֵי הָאֱלֹהִים כִּי הָאֱלֹהִים בַּשָּׁמַיִם וְאַתָּה עַל הָאָרֶץ עַל כֵּן יִהְיוּ דְבָרֶיךָ מְעַטִּים״.
human_translation: And Rav Huna said Rav said in the name of Rabbi Meir: One’s words should always be few before the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is stated: “Be not rash with your mouth and let not your heart be hasty to utter a word before God; for God is in heaven, and you upon earth. Therefore, let your words be few”
llm_translation: And Rav Huna said in the name of Rav Meir: Always let a person's words be few before the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is stated: "Do not be hasty with your mouth, and do not let your heart be quick to utter a word before God, for God is in heaven, and you are upon the earth; therefore let your words be few."

hebrew_text: דָּרַשׁ רַב נַחְמָן בַּר רַב חִסְדָּא: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״וַיִּיצֶר ה׳ אֱלֹהִים אֶת הָאָדָם״ בִּשְׁנֵי יוֹדִין? — שְׁנֵי יְצָרִים בָּרָא הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, אֶחָד יֵצֶר טוֹב וְאֶחָד יֵצֶר רָע.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda interpreted homiletically: What is the meaning of that which is written: “Then the Lord God formed [ vayyitzer ] man” with a double yod ? the Holy One, Blessed be He, created two inclinations; one a good inclination and one an evil inclination.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Rav Chisda expounded: What is the meaning of the verse, "And Hashem, God, formed man" with two yods? — The Holy One, blessed be He, created two inclinations, one good and one evil.

hebrew_text: מַתְקִיף לַהּ רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, בְּהֵמָה דְּלָא כְּתִיב בַּהּ ״וַיִּיצֶר״ לֵית לַהּ יִצְרָא? וְהָא קָא חֲזֵינַן דְּמַזְּקָא וְנָשְׁכָא וּבָעֲטָא! אֶלָּא כִּדְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי ״אוֹי לִי מִיּוֹצְרִי וְאוֹי לִי מִיִּצְרִי״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak strongly objects to this: If that is so, an animal, with regard to whom vayyitzer is not written not have an inclination? Don’t we see that it causes damage and bites and kicks? Rather, in accordance with Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, as Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said: woe unto me from my Creator [ yotzri ] and woe unto me from my inclination [ yitzri ].
llm_translation: Challenges her Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: Rather, from now on, an animal that does not have written in it "and He formed" does not have a yetzer? But we see that it spits, bites, and kicks! Rather, like Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, who said, Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said, "Woe to me from my Creator, and woe to me from my inclination."

hebrew_text: אִי נָמֵי כִּדְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: דּוּ פַּרְצוּפִין בָּרָא הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בָּאָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אָחוֹר וָקֶדֶם צַרְתָּנִי״.
human_translation: Alternatively, in accordance with Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar, as Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, created two faces [ du partzufin ] on Adam the first as it is stated: “You have formed me [ tzartani ] behind and before”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ii namei kid'Rabbi Yirmeyah ben Elazar. D'amar Rabbi Yirmeyah ben Elazar: Du partsufin bara HaKadosh Baruch Hu ba'adam harishon, shene'emar: 'Achor va'kedem tsartani'." English translation: "Is it not so as stated by Rabbi Yirmeyah ben Elazar, for Rabbi Yirmeyah ben Elazar said: The Holy One, blessed be He, created composite beings in the first man, as it is stated: 'Behind and before You have formed me.'"

hebrew_text: ״וַיִּבֶן ה׳ אֱלֹהִים אֶת הַצֵּלָע״.
human_translation: “And the tzela which the Lord, God, He made
llm_translation: "And Hashem Elokim built the rib."

hebrew_text: רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל: חַד אָמַר פַּרְצוּף. וְחַד אָמַר זָנָב.
human_translation: Rav and Shmuel One said: face. And one said: tail,
llm_translation: Rav and Shmuel: one said "parzuf" and one said "zanav."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פַּרְצוּף — הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב ״אָחוֹר וָקֶדֶם צַרְתָּנִי״. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר זָנָב, מַאי ״אָחוֹר וָקֶדֶם צַרְתָּנִי״? כִּדְרַבִּי אַמֵּי, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: ״אָחוֹר״ — לְמַעֲשֵׂה בְרֵאשִׁית, ״וָקֶדֶם״ — לְפוּרְעָנוּת.
human_translation: Granted, to the one who said face; that is it is written: “You have formed me [ tzartani ] behind and before.” However, to the one who said tail, what is “You have formed me [ tzartani ] behind and before”? in accordance with Rabbi Ami, as Rabbi Ami said: Behind the act of creation; and before for punishment.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: In truth, according to the one who says "parzuf" — that is as it is written, "Behind and before You have hemmed me in." But according to the one who says "zanav," what is "Behind and before You have hemmed me in"? Like Rabbi Ammi said, as Rabbi Ammi said: "Behind" — for the act of Creation, "and before" — for retribution. English translation:

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא ״אָחוֹר״ לְמַעֲשֵׂה בְרֵאשִׁית — דְּלָא אִבְּרִי עַד מַעֲלֵי שַׁבְּתָא, אֶלָּא ״וָקֶדֶם״ לְפוּרְעָנוּת, פּוּרְעָנוּת דְּמַאי? אִילֵּימָא פּוּרְעָנוּת דְּנָחָשׁ, וְהָתַנְיָא רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: בִּגְדוּלָּה מַתְחִילִין מִן הַגָּדוֹל, וּבִקְלָלָה מַתְחִילִין מִן הַקָּטָן.
human_translation: Granted, behind, in the act of creation, he was not created until Shabbat eve; however, before, for punishment, what punishment If you say for punishment the snake, wasn’t it taught Rabbi says: In honor, one begins with the greatest; in cursing, one begins with the least significant.
llm_translation: In truth, "behind" in the account of Genesis - for it does not create until the end of the Sabbath, but "and before" for punishment, what is the punishment of what? If you say the punishment of the serpent, and it was taught: Rabbi says: In greatness, we begin with the great, and in curse, we begin with the small.

hebrew_text: בִּגְדוּלָּה מַתְחִילִין מִן הַגָּדוֹל — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיְדַבֵּר מֹשֶׁה אֶל אַהֲרֹן וְאֶל אֶלְעָזָר וְאֶל אִיתָמָר בָּנָיו הַנּוֹתָרִים קְחוּ וְגוֹ׳״. בִּקְלָלָה מַתְחִילִין מִן הַקָּטָן — בַּתְּחִלָּה נִתְקַלֵּל נָחָשׁ, וּלְבַסּוֹף נִתְקַלְּלָה חַוָּה, וּלְבַסּוֹף נִתְקַלֵּל אָדָם!
human_translation: In honor, one begins with the greatest, as it is written: “And Moses said unto Aaron, and Elazar and Itamar, his remaining sons: Take in cursing, one begins with the least significant, first snake was cursed, then Eve was cursed, and ultimately Adam was cursed.
llm_translation: In greatness, we begin from the elder - as it is written: "And Moses spoke to Aaron and to Eleazar and to Ithamar, his remaining sons, 'Take...'" (Leviticus 10:12). In degradation, we begin from the younger - initially the serpent was cursed, and in the end Eve was cursed, and ultimately Adam was cursed!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פּוּרְעָנוּת דְּמַבּוּל, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּמַח אֶת כׇּל הַיְקוּם אֲשֶׁר עַל פְּנֵי הָאֲדָמָה מֵאָדָם וְעַד בְּהֵמָה״, בְּרֵישָׁא אָדָם וַהֲדַר בְּהֵמָה.
human_translation: Rather, the punishment of the flood, as it is written: “And He blotted out every living substance which was upon the face of the ground, both man and cattle, began with man, then the animals,
llm_translation: Rather, the punishment of the Flood, as it is written: "And He blotted out every living substance which was upon the face of the ground, from man to cattle," initially man, and afterwards cattle.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פַּרְצוּף, הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב ״וַיִּיצֶר״ בִּשְׁנֵי יוֹדִין. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר זָנָב, מַאי ״וַיִּיצֶר״?
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said face that is it is written vayyitzer , However, according to the one who said tail, what is vayyitzer
llm_translation: In peace, according to the one who said "parzuf," that is as it is written "and He formed" with two yods. But according to the one who said "zanav," what is "and He formed"?

hebrew_text: כִּדְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי: ״אוֹי לִי מִיּוֹצְרִי אוֹי לִי מִיִּצְרִי״.
human_translation: in accordance with Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, as Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said: Woe unto me from my Creator and woe unto me from my inclination.
llm_translation: As Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said, as Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said: "Woe is me from my Creator, woe is me from my inclination."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פַּרְצוּף, הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב ״זָכָר וּנְקֵבָה בְּרָאָם״, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר זָנָב, מַאי ״זָכָר וּנְקֵבָה בְּרָאָם״? כִּדְרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ רָמֵי: כְּתִיב: ״זָכָר וּנְקֵבָה בְּרָאָם״, וּכְתִיב ״כִּי בְּצֶלֶם אֱלֹהִים עָשָׂה אֶת הָאָדָם״! הָא כֵּיצַד? — בַּתְּחִלָּה עָלָה בְּמַחְשָׁבָה לִבְרֹאת שְׁנַיִם, וּלְבַסּוֹף לֹא נִבְרָא אֶלָּא אֶחָד.
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said face, that is it is written: “Male and female, He created them” However, according to the one who said tail, what is “Male and female, He created them”? Rabbi Abbahu. Rabbi Abbahu raised a contradiction it is written: “Male and female, He created them,” and it is written: “For in the image of God He made man” How, then, At first, the thought entered to create two, and ultimately, only one was created.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: In truth, according to the one who says "parzuf," this is as it is written, "male and female He created them." But according to the one who says "zanav," what is "male and female He created them"? Like Rabbi Avahu said, for Rabbi Avahu raised an objection: It is written, "male and female He created them," and it is also written, "for in the image of God He made man"! How so? — Initially, it arose in thought to create two, but in the end, only one was created.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פַּרְצוּף, הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב ״וַיִּסְגֹּר בָּשָׂר תַּחְתֶּנָּה״, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר זָנָב, מַאי ״וַיִּסְגֹּר בָּשָׂר תַּחְתֶּנָּה״? אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב זְבִיד, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: לֹא נִצְרְכָה אֶלָּא לִמְקוֹם חֲתָךְ.
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who said face, that is it is written: and closed up the place with flesh in its place” However, according to the one who said tail, what is “And closed up the place with flesh in its place”? Rabbi Yirmeya said, and some say Rav Zevid and some say Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak It was necessary only with regard to the place of the incision.
llm_translation: In peace, according to the one who says "parzuf," that is as it is written, "and he closed the flesh underneath it." But according to the one who says "zanav," what is "and he closed the flesh underneath it"? Rabbi Yirmeya said, and some say Rav Zevid, and some say Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: It was necessary only for the place of the cut.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר זָנָב, הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּבֶן״, אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פַּרְצוּף, מַאי ״וַיִּבֶן״?
human_translation: Granted, according to the one tail, that is it is written: “And built However, according to the one who said face what is “And He built”?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: In truth, according to the one who said "zanav," that is what is written: "and he built," but according to the one who said "parzuf," what is "and he built"?

hebrew_text: לְכִדְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן מְנַסְיָא. דְּדָרֵשׁ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן מְנַסְיָא: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״וַיִּבֶן ה׳ אֶת הַצֵּלָע״? מְלַמֵּד שֶׁקִּלְּעָהּ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְחַוָּה, וֶהֱבִיאָהּ לְאָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן — שֶׁכֵּן בִּכְרַכֵּי הַיָּם קוֹרִין לְקַלָּעִיתָא ״בַּנָּיְיתָא״.
human_translation: in accordance with Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya, as Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya interpreted homiletically: What is that which is written: “And the Lord God built the tzela ”? teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, braided Eve’s and brought her to Adam, as in the coastal towns, they call braiding building.
llm_translation: Regarding Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya. For Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya expounded: What is the meaning of the verse "And the Lord God built the rib"? It teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, formed it for Chava, and brought her to Adam the first man — for in the waves of the sea they call a rib "building."

hebrew_text: דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״וַיִּבֶן״, אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ בְּמַתְנִיתָא תָּנָא: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁבְּנָאָהּ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְחַוָּה כְּבִנְיַן אוֹצָר, מָה אוֹצָר זֶה קָצָר מִלְּמַעְלָה וְרָחָב מִלְּמַטָּה כְּדֵי לְקַבֵּל אֶת הַפֵּירוֹת, אַף אִשָּׁה קְצָרָה מִלְּמַעְלָה וּרְחָבָה מִלְּמַטָּה כְּדֵי לְקַבֵּל אֶת הַוָּלָד.
human_translation: Alternatively, And He built, Rav Ḥisda said, and some say that it is taught in a baraita : teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, built Eve like the structure of a storehouse. Just as a storehouse is narrow on top and wide on the bottom, in order to hold produce so too a woman narrow on top and wide on the bottom, in order to hold the fetus.
llm_translation: Another explanation: "And He built," Rav Ḥisda said, and some say it was taught in a baraita: It teaches that in building her, the Holy One, blessed be He, made her like the building of a treasury. Just as this treasury is narrower above and wider below in order to receive the fruits, so too a woman is narrower above and wider below in order to receive the child.

hebrew_text: ״וַיְבִיאֶהָ אֶל הָאָדָם״, אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שׁוֹשְׁבִין לְאָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן, מִכָּאן לִמְּדָה תּוֹרָה דֶּרֶךְ אֶרֶץ שֶׁיַּחֲזוֹר גָּדוֹל עִם קָטָן בְּשׁוֹשְׁבִינוּת, וְאַל יֵרַע לוֹ.
human_translation: “And brought her unto the man” Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar said: teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, was Adam the first best man. From here, the Torah taught that it is a desired mode of behavior for a greater individual to seek out a lesser individual to serve as his best man. and should not feel badly
llm_translation: "And He brought her to the man," Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar said: This teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, acted as a matchmaker for the first man. From here the Torah teaches proper behavior, that one should be careful in matching a great person with a lesser one in their relationship, and it should not be detrimental to him.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״פַּרְצוּף״, הֵי מִינַּיְיהוּ סַגִּי בְּרֵישָׁא? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: מִסְתַּבְּרָא דְּגַבְרָא סַגִּי בְּרֵישָׁא. דְּתַנְיָא: לֹא יְהַלֵּךְ אָדָם אֲחוֹרֵי אִשָּׁה בַּדֶּרֶךְ, וַאֲפִילּוּ אִשְׁתּוֹ. נִזְדַּמְּנָה לוֹ עַל הַגֶּשֶׁר — יְסַלְּקֶנָּה לִצְדָדִין. וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר אֲחוֹרֵי אִשָּׁה בַּנָּהָר — אֵין לוֹ חֵלֶק לְעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
human_translation: And according to the one who said face which one of them walked in front? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is reasonable that the man walked in front, as it is taught A man should not walk behind a woman on a path, even if it is his wife.  happens upon him along a bridge, he should move her to sides And anyone who walks behind a woman in a river has no portion in the World-to-Come.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And according to the one who says 'Parzuf,' what is the reason? He should be considered a sage from the beginning? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: It is logical that a man is considered a sage from the beginning. As it was taught: A man should not walk behind a woman on the road, even if she is his wife. If he encounters her on a bridge, he should move her to the side. And anyone who walks behind a woman by the river - he has no share in the World to Come."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַמַּרְצֶה מָעוֹת לְאִשָּׁה מִיָּדוֹ לְיָדָהּ כְּדֵי לְהִסְתַּכֵּל בָּהּ, אֲפִילּוּ יֵשׁ בְּיָדוֹ תּוֹרָה וּמַעֲשִׂים טוֹבִים כְּמֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ — לֹא יִנָּקֶה מִדִּינָהּ שֶׁל גֵּיהִנָּם. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״יָד לְיָד לֹא יִנָּקֶה רָּע״ — לֹא יִנָּקֶה מִדִּינָהּ שֶׁל גֵּיהִנָּם.
human_translation: The Sages taught: One who counts money for a woman from his hand to her hand in order to look upon her, even if he has accumulated Torah and good deeds like Moses our teacher, he will not be absolved from the punishment of Gehenna, as it is stated: “Hand to hand, the evil man shall not go unpunished” he will not be absolved from the punishment of Gehenna,
llm_translation: The sages taught: One who gives coins to a woman directly into her hand in order to gaze at her, even if he has Torah and good deeds like our teacher Moses, he will not be exempt from the judgment of Gehenna. As it is stated, "Hand to hand, he will not be unpunished" - he will not be exempt from the judgment of Gehenna.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: מָנוֹחַ עַם הָאָרֶץ הָיָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֵּלֶךְ מָנוֹחַ אַחֲרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman said: Manoah, was an ignoramus, as it is written: “And Manoah…went after his wife”
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: Manoach was at ease, as it is written: "And Manoach went after his wife."

hebrew_text: מַתְקִיף לַהּ רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, גַּבֵּי אֶלְקָנָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֵּלֶךְ אֶלְקָנָה אַחֲרֵי אִשְׁתּוֹ״, וְגַבֵּי אֱלִישָׁע, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּקׇם וַיֵּלֶךְ אַחֲרֶיהָ״, הָכִי נָמֵי אַחֲרֶיהָ מַמָּשׁ? אֶלָּא אַחֲרֵי דְבָרֶיהָ וְאַחֲרֵי עֲצָתָהּ, הָכָא נָמֵי אַחֲרֵי דְבָרֶיהָ וְאַחֲרֵי עֲצָתָהּ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak strongly objects to this: If that is so with regard to Elkana, as it is written: “And Elkana walked after his wife,” with regard to Elisha, as it is written: “And he arose and followed her” Does mean literally walked after her? Rather, he followed her words and advice. Here, too, followed words and followed her advice,
llm_translation: Challenges her Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak: Rather, from now on, regarding Elkanah, as it is written: "And Elkanah went after his wife," and regarding Elisha, as it is written: "And he arose and went after her," is it really going after her literally? Rather, after her words and after her advice, here too, after her words and after her advice.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: וּלְמַאי דְּקָאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן, מָנוֹחַ עַם הָאָרֶץ הָיָה — אֲפִילּוּ בֵּי רַב נָמֵי לָא קְרָא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַתָּקׇם רִבְקָה וְנַעֲרֹתֶיהָ וַתִּרְכַּבְנָה עַל הַגְּמַלִּים וַתֵּלַכְנָה אַחֲרֵי הָאִישׁ״ — וְלֹא לִפְנֵי הָאִישׁ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: And according to what Rav Naḥman said, Manoah was an ignoramus; he did not even read in school, as it is stated: “Rebecca arose, and her damsels, and they rode upon the camels, and followed the man” not before the man.
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: And for what purpose did Rav Nachman say, "He was a resting man of the land"? Even the household of Rav Nami did not read, as it is stated: "And Rebecca arose, and her maidens, and they rode upon the camels, and followed the man" - and not before the man.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֲחוֹרֵי אֲרִי וְלֹא אֲחוֹרֵי אִשָּׁה, אֲחוֹרֵי אִשָּׁה וְלֹא אֲחוֹרֵי עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, אֲחוֹרֵי עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וְלֹא אֲחוֹרֵי בֵּית הַכְּנֶסֶת בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁהַצִּבּוּר מִתְפַּלְּלִין.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: behind a lion and not behind a woman, behind a woman and not behind idolatry, behind idolatry and not behind a synagogue when the congregation is praying,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Behind a lion and not behind a woman, behind a woman and not behind idol worship, behind idol worship and not behind the synagogue when the congregation is praying.

hebrew_text: וְלָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא דְּלָא דָּרֵי מִידֵּי, וְאִי דָּרֵי מִידֵּי — לֵית לַן בַּהּ. וְלָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא דְּלֵיכָּא פִּתְחָא אַחֲרִינָא, וְאִי אִיכָּא פִּתְחָא אַחֲרִינָא — לֵית לַן בַּהּ. וְלָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא דְּלָא רְכִיב חֲמָרָא, אֲבָל רְכִיב חֲמָרָא — לֵית לַן בַּהּ. וְלָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא דְּלָא מַנַּח תְּפִילִּין, אֲבָל מַנַּח תְּפִילִּין — לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
human_translation: And we only said in a case where he is not carrying something, and if he is carrying something, this does not apply, And we only said in a case where there is no other entrance and if there is another entrance, this does not apply. And we only said in a case where he is not riding a donkey, and if he is riding a donkey, this does not apply. And we only said in a case where he is not donning phylacteries, but if he is donning phylacteries, this does not apply.
llm_translation: We did not say except that it does not come from his own, and if it comes from his own - we do not have it. And we did not say except that there is no other entrance, and if there is another entrance - we do not have it. And we did not say except that he did not ride a donkey, but if he rode a donkey - we do not have it. And we did not say except that he did not place tefillin, but if he placed tefillin - we do not have it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: יֵצֶר הָרָע דּוֹמֶה לִזְבוּב וְיוֹשֵׁב בֵּין שְׁנֵי מִפְתְּחֵי הַלֵּב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״זְבוּבֵי מָוֶת יַבְאִישׁ יַבִּיעַ שֶׁמֶן רוֹקֵחַ״. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: כְּמִין חִטָּה הוּא דּוֹמֶה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לַפֶּתַח חַטָּאת רוֹבֵץ״.
human_translation: Rav said: The evil inclination is like a fly and it sits between the two entrances of the heart, as it is stated: “Dead flies make the ointment of the perfumer fetid and putrid” And Shmuel said: is like a type of wheat, as it is stated: “Transgression [ ḥatat ] couches at the door”
llm_translation: Rav said: The evil inclination is like a fly and sits between the two openings of the heart, as it is stated: "The flies of death will putrefy a perfumer's ointment." And Shmuel said: It is like a type of wheat, as it is stated: "Sin crouches at the door."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שְׁתֵּי כְּלָיוֹת יֵשׁ בּוֹ בְּאָדָם, אַחַת יוֹעַצְתּוֹ לְטוֹבָה וְאַחַת יוֹעַצְתּוֹ לְרָעָה. וּמִסְתַּבְּרָא דְּטוֹבָה לִימִינוֹ וְרָעָה לִשְׂמֹאלוֹ, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֵב חָכָם לִימִינוֹ וְלֵב כְּסִיל לִשְׂמֹאלוֹ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught A person has two kidneys; one advises him to good and one advises him to evil. And it stands to reason good is to his right and evil is to his left, as it is written: “A wise man’s understanding is at his right hand, but a fool’s understanding is at his left”
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: There are two kidneys in a person, one advises him for good and one advises him for evil. And it turns out that the good is to his right and the evil to his left, as it is written: "A wise heart is to the right, and a foolish heart is to the left."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: כְּלָיוֹת יוֹעֲצוֹת, לֵב מֵבִין, לָשׁוֹן מְחַתֵּךְ, פֶּה גּוֹמֵר, וֶשֶׁט מַכְנִיס וּמוֹצִיא כׇּל מִינֵי מַאֲכָל, קָנֶה מוֹצִיא קוֹל,
human_translation: the Sages taught The kidneys advise, the heart understands, the tongue shapes mouth completes esophagus takes in and lets out all kinds of food, trachea produces the voice,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: The kidneys advise, the heart understands, the tongue cuts, the mouth completes, the esophagus brings in and takes out all kinds of food, the windpipe emits sound.

hebrew_text: רֵיאָה שׁוֹאֶבֶת כׇּל מִינֵי מַשְׁקִין, כָּבֵד כּוֹעֵס, מָרָה זוֹרֶקֶת בּוֹ טִפָּה וּמְנִיחָתוֹ, טְחוֹל שׂוֹחֵק, קֻרְקְבָן טוֹחֵן, קֵיבָה יְשֵׁנָה, אַף נֵעוֹר. נֵעוֹר הַיָּשֵׁן יָשֵׁן הַנֵּעוֹר — נִמּוֹק וְהוֹלֵךְ לוֹ. תָּנָא: אִם שְׁנֵיהֶם יְשֵׁנִים אוֹ שְׁנֵיהֶם נֵעוֹרִים — מִיָּד מֵת.
human_translation: lungs draw all kinds of liquids, liver becomes angry, gall injects a drop into allays spleen laughs, maw grinds stomach sleep, nose awakens. the sleep awaken, the awakens sleep, would gradually deteriorate. It was taught: If both sleep or both awaken, immediately dies.
llm_translation: Sight absorbs all kinds of liquids, liver gets angry, bile throws a drop and leaves it, spleen laughs, stomach grinds, old intestines, and youth. An old youth is an old youth - he softens and goes to him. It was taught: If both are old or both are young - they die immediately.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: צַדִּיקִים יֵצֶר טוֹב שׁוֹפְטָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלִבִּי חָלַל בְּקִרְבִּי״. רְשָׁעִים יֵצֶר רַע שׁוֹפְטָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״נְאֻם פֶּשַׁע לָרָשָׁע בְּקֶרֶב לִבִּי אֵין פַּחַד אֱלֹהִים לְנֶגֶד עֵינָיו״. בֵּינוֹנִים — זֶה וָזֶה שׁוֹפְטָן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יַעֲמֹד לִימִין אֶבְיוֹן לְהוֹשִׁיעַ מִשֹּׁפְטֵי נַפְשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: it was taught Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: The good inclination rules the righteous, as it is stated: “And my heart is dead within me” evil inclination rules the wicked, as it is stated: “Transgression speaks to the wicked, there is no fear of God before his eyes” Middling people are ruled by both as it is stated: “Because He stands at the right hand of the needy, to save him from them that rule his soul”
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean says: The righteous, their good inclination judges them, as it is said: "And my heart is wounded within me." The wicked, their evil inclination judges them, as it is said: "The pronouncement of transgression to the wicked within my heart; there is no fear of God before his eyes." The intermediate ones - both this one and that one, their inclination judges them, as it is said: "He will stand at the right hand of the needy, to save him from those who judge his soul."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: כְּגוֹן אָנוּ בֵּינוֹנִים. אָמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: לָא שָׁבֵיק מָר חַיֵּי לְכׇל בְּרִיָּה?
human_translation: Rabba said: like us middling. Abaye, said to him: the Master does not leave any creature to live.
llm_translation: Rabba said: "For example, we are in a state of uncertainty." Abaye said to him: "Did Master not leave any life for all of creation?"

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: לָא אִיבְּרִי עָלְמָא אֶלָּא לְרַשִּׁיעֵי גְּמוּרֵי אוֹ לְצַדִּיקֵי גְּמוּרֵי. אָמַר רָבָא: לִידַּע אִינָשׁ בְּנַפְשֵׁיהּ אִם צַדִּיק גָּמוּר הוּא אִם לָאו. אָמַר רַב: לָא אִיבְּרִי עָלְמָא אֶלָּא לְאַחְאָב בֶּן עָמְרִי וּלְרַבִּי חֲנִינָא בֶּן דּוֹסָא. לְאַחְאָב בֶּן עָמְרִי — הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, וּלְרַבִּי חֲנִינָא בֶּן דּוֹסָא — הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
human_translation: And Rava said: The world was created only for the full-fledged wicked or the full-fledged righteous; Rava said: One should know of himself whether or not he is completely righteous, Rav said: The world was only created for Ahab ben Omri and for Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa. Ahab ben Omri, this world and Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa, the World-to-Come
llm_translation: And Rava said: The world was only created for complete wicked people or for complete righteous people. Rava said: A person should know within himself whether he is a complete righteous person or not. Rav said: The world was only created for Achav son of Omri and for Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa. For Achav son of Omri - this world, and for Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa - the world to come.

hebrew_text: ״וְאָהַבְתָּ אֵת ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אִם נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכָל נַפְשְׁךָ״, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכָל מְאֹדֶךָ״?, וְאִם נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכָל מְאֹדֶךָ״, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכָל נַפְשְׁךָ״? אֶלָּא אִם יֵשׁ לְךָ אָדָם שֶׁגּוּפוֹ חָבִיב עָלָיו מִמָּמוֹנוֹ — לְכָךְ נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכָל נַפְשְׁךָ״. וְאִם יֵשׁ לָךְ אָדָם שֶׁמָּמוֹנוֹ חָבִיב עָלָיו מִגּוּפוֹ — לְכָךְ נֶאֱמַר ״בְּכָל מְאֹדֶךָ״. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: ״בְּכָל נַפְשְׁךָ״ אֲפִילּוּ נוֹטֵל אֶת נַפְשְׁךָ.
human_translation: “And you shall love the Lord your God it was taught Rabbi Eliezer says: If it is stated: “With all your soul,” why does it state: “With all your might”? if it stated: “With all your might,” why does it state: “With all your soul”? Rather, if one’s body is dearer to him than his property, therefore it is stated: “With all your soul”; And if one’s money is dearer to him than his body, therefore it is stated: “With all your might”; Rabbi Akiva says: “With all your soul” Even if takes your soul.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And you shall love the Lord your God." It was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: If it is stated "with all your soul," why is it stated "with all your might"? And if it is stated "with all your might," why is it stated "with all your soul"? Rather, if you have a person whose body is dearer to him than his money - for this reason it is stated "with all your soul." And if you have a person whose money is dearer to him than his body - for this reason it is stated "with all your might." Rabbi Akiva says: "With all your soul" even if He takes your soul.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: פַּעַם אַחַת גָּזְרָה מַלְכוּת הָרְשָׁעָה שֶׁלֹּא יַעַסְקוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בַּתּוֹרָה. בָּא פַּפּוּס בֶּן יְהוּדָה וּמְצָאוֹ לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שֶׁהָיָה מַקְהִיל קְהִלּוֹת בָּרַבִּים וְעוֹסֵק בַּתּוֹרָה. אָמַר לוֹ: עֲקִיבָא אִי אַתָּה מִתְיָרֵא מִפְּנֵי מַלְכוּת?
human_translation: The Sages taught: One time, the evil empire decreed that Israel may not engage in Torah. Pappos ben Yehuda came and found Rabbi Akiva, who was convening assemblies in public and engaging in Torah said to him: Akiva, are you not afraid of the empire?
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One time the evil kingdom decreed that the Israelites should not engage in Torah study. Pappus ben Yehudah came and found Rabbi Akiva, who was gathering congregations in public and engaging in Torah study. He said to him: Akiva, are you not afraid of the kingdom?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: אֶמְשׁוֹל לְךָ מָשָׁל, לְמָה הַדָּבָר דּוֹמֶה — לְשׁוּעָל שֶׁהָיָה מְהַלֵּךְ עַל גַּב הַנָּהָר, וְרָאָה דָּגִים שֶׁהָיוּ מִתְקַבְּצִים מִמָּקוֹם לְמָקוֹם. אָמַר לָהֶם: מִפְּנֵי מָה אַתֶּם בּוֹרְחִים? אָמְרוּ לוֹ: מִפְּנֵי רְשָׁתוֹת שֶׁמְּבִיאִין עָלֵינוּ בְּנֵי אָדָם. אָמַר לָהֶם: רְצוֹנְכֶם שֶׁתַּעֲלוּ לַיַּבָּשָׁה, וְנָדוּר אֲנִי וְאַתֶּם, כְּשֵׁם שֶׁדָּרוּ אֲבוֹתַי עִם אֲבוֹתֵיכֶם? אָמְרוּ לוֹ: אַתָּה הוּא שֶׁאוֹמְרִים עָלֶיךָ פִּקֵּחַ שֶׁבַּחַיּוֹת?! לֹא פִּקֵּחַ אַתָּה, אֶלָּא טִפֵּשׁ אַתָּה! וּמָה בִּמְקוֹם חִיּוּתֵנוּ, אָנוּ מִתְיָרְאִין, בִּמְקוֹם מִיתָתֵנוּ — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה. אַף אֲנַחְנוּ עַכְשָׁיו שֶׁאָנוּ יוֹשְׁבִים וְעוֹסְקִים בַּתּוֹרָה, שֶׁכָּתוּב בָּהּ: ״כִּי הוּא חַיֶּיךָ וְאֹרֶךְ יָמֶיךָ״, כָּךְ, אִם אָנוּ הוֹלְכִים וּמְבַטְּלִים מִמֶּנָּה — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה!
human_translation: answered him: I will relate a parable. To what can this be compared? a fox walking along a riverbank when he sees fish gathering from place to place. said to them: From what are you fleeing? They said to him: from the nets that people cast upon us. He said to them: Do you wish to come up onto dry land, and we will reside together just as my ancestors resided with your ancestors? said to him: You are the one of whom they say, he is the cleverest of animals? You are not clever; you are a fool. If we are afraid in our habitat life, in a habitat death, all the more so. So too, we now that we sit and engage in Torah about which it is written: “For that is your life, and the length of your days” to this extent; if we proceed to idle from its all the more so
llm_translation: He said to them: I will give you a parable. To what is this matter similar? It is similar to a fox that was walking along the bank of the river and saw fish gathering from place to place. He said to them: Why are you fleeing? They said to him: Because of the nets that humans bring upon us. He said to them: Do you wish to come up onto dry land, and we will make a pact, just as my ancestors made with your ancestors? They said to him: You are the one they call the wisest of animals?! You are not wise, but foolish! In a place where our lives are in danger, we are afraid; in a place where our deaths are certain — how much more so. Even we who are now sitting and engaging in Torah study, as it is written in it: "For it is your life and the length of your days," if we were to neglect it — how much more so!

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ: לֹא הָיוּ יָמִים מוּעָטִים, עַד שֶׁתְּפָסוּהוּ לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וַחֲבָשׁוּהוּ בְּבֵית הָאֲסוּרִים, וְתָפְסוּ לְפַפּוּס בֶּן יְהוּדָה וַחֲבָשׁוּהוּ אֶצְלוֹ. אָמַר לוֹ: פַּפּוּס, מִי הֲבִיאֲךָ לְכָאן? אָמַר לוֹ: אַשְׁרֶיךָ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שֶׁנִּתְפַּסְתָּ עַל דִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה. אוֹי לוֹ לְפַפּוּס שֶׁנִּתְפַּס עַל דְּבָרִים בְּטֵלִים.
human_translation: said: Not a few days passed until they seized Rabbi Akiva and incarcerated him in prison, and seized Pappos ben Yehuda and incarcerated him alongside him. said to him: Pappos, who brought you here? replied: Happy are you, Rabbi Akiva, for you were arrested on Torah Woe unto Pappos who was seized on idle matters.
llm_translation: They said: There were not many days until they arrested Rabbi Akiva and imprisoned him in the prison, and they arrested Pappus ben Yehudah and imprisoned him with him. He said to him: Pappus, who brought you here? He said to him: Fortunate are you, Rabbi Akiva, that you were arrested for matters of Torah. Woe to Pappus who was arrested for trivial matters.

hebrew_text: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁהוֹצִיאוּ אֶת רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא לַהֲרִיגָה זְמַן קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע הָיָה, וְהָיוּ סוֹרְקִים אֶת בְּשָׂרוֹ בְּמַסְרְקוֹת שֶׁל בַּרְזֶל, וְהָיָה מְקַבֵּל עָלָיו עוֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם. אָמְרוּ לוֹ תַּלְמִידָיו: רַבֵּינוּ, עַד כָּאן?! אָמַר לָהֶם: כׇּל יָמַי הָיִיתִי מִצְטַעֵר עַל פָּסוּק זֶה ״בְּכָל נַפְשְׁךָ״ אֲפִילּוּ נוֹטֵל אֶת נִשְׁמָתְךָ. אָמַרְתִּי: מָתַי יָבֹא לְיָדִי וַאֲקַיְּימֶנּוּ, וְעַכְשָׁיו שֶׁבָּא לְיָדִי, לֹא אֲקַיְּימֶנּוּ? הָיָה מַאֲרִיךְ בְּ״אֶחָד״, עַד שֶׁיָּצְתָה נִשְׁמָתוֹ בְּ״אֶחָד״. יָצְתָה בַּת קוֹל וְאָמְרָה: ״אַשְׁרֶיךָ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שֶׁיָּצְאָה נִשְׁמָתְךָ בְּאֶחָד״.
human_translation: When they took Rabbi Akiva out to be executed, it was time for the recitation of Shema . And they were raking his flesh with iron combs, and he was accepting upon himself the yoke of Heaven. His students said to him: Our teacher, even now, He said to them: All my days I have been troubled by the verse: With all your soul, Even if God takes your soul. I said When will the be afforded me to fulfill this Now that it has been afforded me, shall I not fulfill it? He prolonged One, until his soul left One. A voice descended and said: Happy are you, Rabbi Akiva, that your soul left as One.
llm_translation: At the time when they took out Rabbi Akiva to be executed, it was the time for reciting the Shema, and they were raking his flesh with iron combs, and he was accepting upon himself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven. His students said to him: "Our teacher, even up to here?!" He said to them: "All my days I have been distressed over this verse 'with all your soul,' even if He takes your soul. I said: When will it come to my hand that I may fulfill it, and now that it has come to my hand, shall I not fulfill it? He prolonged the word 'One' until his soul departed on 'One.' A heavenly voice came out and said: "Fortunate are you, Rabbi Akiva, that your soul departed on 'One.'"

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת לִפְנֵי הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: זוֹ תּוֹרָה וְזוֹ שְׂכָרָהּ? ״מִמְתִים יָדְךָ ה׳ מִמְתִים וְגוֹ׳״! אָמַר לָהֶם: ״חֶלְקָם בַּחַיִּים״. יָצְתָה בַּת קוֹל וְאָמְרָה: ״אַשְׁרֶיךָ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שֶׁאַתָּה מְזוּמָּן לְחַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא״.
human_translation: The ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: This is Torah and this its reward? “From death, by Your hand, O Lord, from death said to “Whose portion is in this life.” a Divine Voice emerged and said: Happy are you, Rabbi Akiva, as you are destined for life in the World-to-Come,
llm_translation: The angels of service said before the Holy One, blessed be He: "Is this Torah and this its reward? 'You will surely die, Hashem, you will surely die,' etc.!" He said to them: "Their portion is in the life." A Bat Kol went out and said: "Fortunate are you, Rabbi Akiva, that you are prepared for the life of the World to Come."

hebrew_text: לֹא יָקֵל אָדָם אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ כְּנֶגֶד שַׁעַר הַמִּזְרָח שֶׁהוּא מְכוּוָּן כְּנֶגֶד בֵּית קׇדְשֵׁי הַקֳּדָשִׁים וְכוּ׳. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לֹא אָמְרוּ אֶלָּא מִן הַצּוֹפִים וְלִפְנִים, וּבְרוֹאֶה. אִיתְּמַר נָמֵי: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא, הָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא אָמְרוּ אֶלָּא מִן הַצּוֹפִים וְלִפְנִים, וּבְרוֹאֶה וּבְשֶׁאֵין גָּדֵר, וּבִזְמַן שֶׁהַשְּׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה.
human_translation: one may not act irreverently opposite the Eastern Gate, which is aligned with the Holy of Holies. Rav Yehuda said Rav said: They only said from Scopus [ Tzofim ] and within, and one can see It is also stated: Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, said: Rabbi Yoḥanan said the following: They only said Scopus and within, one can see, and when there is no fence and when the Divine Presence is resting
llm_translation: A person should not make light of his head opposite the eastern gate, which is aligned opposite the entrance of the Holy of Holies, etc. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: They only said this regarding those facing inward, and those who are discerning. It was stated similarly: Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Chiyya bar Abba, said thus in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: They only said this regarding those facing inward, and those who are discerning, and in a place where there is no barrier, and when the Divine Presence is dwelling.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַנִּפְנֶה בִּיהוּדָה, לֹא יִפָּנֶה מִזְרָח וּמַעֲרָב, אֶלָּא צָפוֹן וְדָרוֹם. וּבַגָּלִיל לֹא יִפָּנֶה אֶלָּא מִזְרָח וּמַעֲרָב. וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי מַתִּיר. שֶׁהָיָה רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: לֹא אָסְרוּ אֶלָּא בְּרוֹאֶה, וּבְמָקוֹם שֶׁאֵין שָׁם גָּדֵר, וּבִזְמַן שֶׁהַשְּׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹסְרִים.
human_translation: the Sages taught: One who defecates in Judea should not defecate east and west, rather facing north and south. But in the Galilee one should only defecate east and west. Rabbi Yosei permits as Rabbi Yosei was wont to say: They only prohibited one can see where there is no fence, and when the Divine Presence is resting And the Rabbis prohibit
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: One who turns to Judea should not turn to the east or west, but rather to the north and south. And in the Galilee, one should only turn to the east and west. And Rabbi Yosei permits it, for Rabbi Yosei used to say: They only prohibited it in a place where there is a fence, and at a time when the Divine Presence dwells. But the Sages prohibit it.

hebrew_text: חֲכָמִים הַיְינוּ תַּנָּא קַמָּא! אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ צְדָדִין.
human_translation: Rabbis, is first tanna, between them is the sides,
llm_translation: The sages, that is, the first Tanna! There is a difference between them on the sides.
